column2: TPP2 - Life Works: increasing life chances
column3: The group will provide mentoring and opportunities to develop work skills for ex-offenders and people who have been homeless. The project will provide a dedicated space with a variety of meaningful activities, improving the health and wellbeing of those involved, and supporting them to reintegrate back into the community as healthy and confident members of society.

The group will provide one to one and group support with regards to finances, for offenders released from prison or referred by the Probation Service, to improve understanding of debt management, paying bills and housing costs, with the aim of addressing the issues of homelessness and reoffending.

This group will use its two year grant to run their 'Creative Natives' programme in partnership with Edinburgh Cyrenians. This will allow young people who have left school but are unemployed, and who have a background in care or have been affected by homelessness, to participate in a range of creative activities, such as print and web design, campaigning, social media and e-commerce. The creative process will be used to improve the lives of the young people involved and help them to learn new skills.

This funding will allow the organisation to continue its work with 16-25 year olds from from the Cowal Peninsula and the Isle of Bute who are homeless, at risk of becoming homeless, or are coming out of care. Young people are referred to HELP by a number of organisations or via self-referral. The young people will have the chance to take part in a range of activities to develop skills and to increase their confidence to engage in their local community.

This group will develop their project to run a support service for vulnerable, disadvantaged homeless adults in Kent. A support centre ‘Hub’ will be developed to include a social space, an IT suite, cafe, shower facilities and a range of supporting activities. The project will offer a social space and a support worker to signpost to organisations or activities, and provide access to an IT suite for employment and training opportunities. Peer-to-peer learning and vocational programmes will be delivered.

column3: They would like to offer basic digital skills learning to their tenants aged 55+, with a key focus on people over 65. The aim of this project is to help more people to get online and help reduce isolation and poverty. Tutor supportwill be secured from the the digital skills academy to help tenants develop the skills and confidence to use technology and the internet. The plan is to offer a mixture of informal group sessions for up to 8 people delivered in a café style atmosphere, with an option of 1 - 1 support as a follow up if needed. 10 sheltered housing developments have been identified across Edinburgh - each development will be offered a weekly, 3 hour learning session for a period of 10 weeks. The tutor will use tailored themes (hooks) based on the interest residents have expressed. The experienced tutors will then build in specific skills that will benefit our customers within the lessons such as security and staying safe online.

This is a partnership bid with Glasgow Life/Glasgow Libraries, Glasgow Homelessness Network, Nan McKay Memorial Hall, Govan and Craigton Integration Network and Glasgow Clyde College. Southside Housing Association is the lead partner.     The project will take place within the Pollokshields and Cardonald/Craigton areas of Glasgow. The project broadly aims to support people currently not digitally engaged but who would benefit greatly.    Key elements of the project include:  Installation of Wi-Fi and IT equipment within 4 community bases; providing local, safe and welcoming environments for learning. The bases are community flats (or resident lounge within sheltered housing complexes) converted into common space for local people to come together and participate in positive activities. Current activities include easy exercise, storytelling, arts, and healthy cooking. By providing Wi-Fi and IT equipment we will be able to extend these activities to include digital learning. It should be noted that we have 3 other community bases with Wi-Fi, and we work in close partnership with the Nan McKay Memorial Hall as a welcoming base for learning. These spaces will be used within the project, however in order to reach the target groups outlined above, and a greater number of individuals, this project requires additional support in the form of further Wi-Fi installation, IT equipment and in-kind support from partners.    Delivery of a range of courses (by Glasgow Clyde College) within each community base covering the basic digital skills. By doing so we hope to provide people with the skills to improve their ability to connect with others, save money online, enquire and apply for benefits, carry out research and work together to improve, develop and connect within their local areas. We also envisage that by providing Wi-Fi people may choose to bring their own IT equipment to the bases at a time that suits them (outwith the structured learning/activity times).     We have completed the delivery of 3 courses, 2 in our Sheltered Housing bases in Pollokshields and one within our Berryknowes Base in Cardonald. 7 people attended each programme, all 21 attendees were taught the basics in using tablets, setting up their own email accounts, send and receive emails and searching online. Some participants brought their own laptops or tablets and used their own equipment to build their confidence and existing skills. We will be running another 2 courses over the summer.     Ensuring that people are not simply offered the opportunity of participating in digital learning and using Wi-Fi in their own time (within the bases), but that they are encouraged to connect with existing services and organisations, thus using the project as a foundation for creating pathways to these services and therefore greater outcomes for participants. These other services are currently offered within local libraries, Glasgow Clyde College, the Nan McKay Memorial Hall, Glasgow Homelessness Network and the Govan and Craigton Integration Network. We recognise the importance of ensuring people know what other support exists, which is why this project will be delivered in partnership. Each course incorporated a workshop delivered by Glasgow Libraries where all attendees were informed of the various services the library has to offer. All attendees were given the opportunity to refer themselves to the Glasgow Libraries IT workshops to continue their learning and utilise other services relevant to their needs.     Southside Housing Association (SHA) also purchased and donated IT equipment to other local services. We donated a Smart Board to the Glasgow and Craigton Integration Network (GCIN) to support them in delivering a series of ESOL and IT workshops. We also donated a number of tablets to the Nan Makcay Hall to support them in delivering a similar series of Digital learning workshops. By delivering this project we hope to address some of the barriers people find to going online. Some of which include “it’s too difficult to learn”; “it’s too expensive”; “worrying about privacy/viruses;”; “no connection/computer”’ (CarnegieUK Trust, 2013. Across the Divide –Tackling Digital Exclusion in Glasgow).     Prior to running these courses, Southside Housing Association coordinated a series of consultation meetings within each base and also distributed a feedback questionnaire to all tenants living local to our bases. The consultations and findings of the questionnaire revealed that a significantly high number of tenants were keen to take part in Digital Learning course but felt they were “too old now” or “it’s too hard to learn that stuff”. We also found that many tenants did not have the finances to install Wi-Fi in their homes and purchase equipment of their own. The local bases provide a safe and free space to learn and break down some of these barriers.     At the beginning of each course we asked attendees to complete a Digital inclusion questionnaire, this captured their current skill level and attitudes. We also asked all attendees to complete the questionnaire after the course had completed. We found that all attendees had learned a new skill and most were fairly confident in sending and receiving emails on their own. We observed a change in attitude, particularly amongst older participants who previously believed they were too old to participate. It is good to note that 6 of our older participants now attend the library once a week, use the computer their and also utilise other services the library has to offer.     We have just completed and 8 week Keys to Learn programme, delivered in partnership with Glasgow Homelessness Network (GHN) and City of Glasgow College. The programme works with people at risk of losing their tenancies due to debt, mental health issues, drugs, alcohol etc. The Keys to Learn programme introduces participants to different skills and pathways that could resolve or alleviate such issues. The programme includes cooking on a budget, learning digital skills, budgeting and debt management, managing stress etc. Part of the programmes is also to introduce participants to services offer by SHA and within the local community. For example, participants took part in a session with SHA’s Welfare Rights department and were presented with knowledge and information relevant to their needs. They were also offered individual appointments for additional support needed, in the same way, participants completed a session with the Epic 360 service which offer support to people living in Glasgow with budgeting and debt management. Participants have been encouraged to use their local community bases at meeting spaces for such services and to continue accessing the internet.

The Drop-ins provide a welcome centre for asylum seekers and refugees living locally in Bristol and the opportunity to meet in a place of safety where they can access advice and offer support to each other.  Our members live on very restricted funds or receive no funding at all. They rely on charities to meet their basic needs such as eating a hot meal, learning English and getting donated clothes etc. and because the Drop-ins have been running successfully for some years we are recognised within this community for this work. Asylum seekers and refugees are encouraged to access training and take leadership roles within the charities within the legal boundaries of their status. _x000D_
We have a large and growing number of registered volunteers who want to offer their help to asylum seekers and refugees and the Drop-ins provide a local opportunity for this and to be part of a community group with others. All volunteers are trained; references are required and ongoing support is provided to them. The Drop-ins provide special welcome centres where everyone grows together. _x000D_
Over the past year we have seen increased demand for our services with more asylum seekers and refugees attending our welcome centres and increased enquiries about volunteering from members of the public. We have also developed our skills in fundraising and actively seek funds from faith and community groups locally and nationally in addition to applying to charitable grant-making trusts. We evaluate and monitor our projects to make them even more effective.

Move On will provide IT Literacy skills to service users in Glasgow who have experienced homelessness or the care system. This will be delivered by literacy tutors through one-to-one and group sessions on common IT tasks including internet/e-mail, intro to word processing and spreadsheets.     Service users will be identified through personal plans drawn up at the beginning of their engagement with our existing literacy programme.    The project will also include setting up and moderating a secure online group for current and past service users to practise their skills and to facilitate monitoring their ongoing use of IT and the overall impact their increased skills and knowledge has on their lives.

The funding will be used to develop services supporting people who have experienced addiction issues, homelessness or have been to prison. The project aims to support people to sustain a tenancy, reintegrate into the community and gain work. Training is provided by peers supported by local universities and businesses and takes place in progressive stages. Each stage helps participants build their skills and confidence until they can put these into action at a work placement or a specific project.

To strengthen the homelessness sector (voluntary, public and private) to work more collaboratively.  To bring sectors together to better understand, define and identify their role in preventing homelessness. To support frontline providers and commissioners to be responsive to changing patterns of need, policy, legislation and equalities issues. To build the capacity of frontline providers to improve service delivery and effectiveness and ultimately be more sustainable.  With the ultimate aim of achieving improved outcomes for those at risk of or experiencing homelessness.   Activities: o providing specialist advice, support, training and information o supporting and improving working relationships between the VCS, boroughs and landlords through forums  o improving collaboration and communication between the homelessness, employment, domestic/sexual violence, substance use, and health sectors through relationship brokerage, bespoke support and peer networks o providing quality policy, law and research information identifying London specific impact and trends through briefings and bulletins o testing new models through special initiatives responding to the London specific context.  Outcomes delivered:  o Higher quality, more responsive and effective service delivery (measured against a baseline , and using an external evaluation) o More effective cross sector/priority collaboration to deliver more effective services o Improved and focussed response to prevention o Better evidence of successful creative interventions responsive to specific London context.

column3: This project aims to raise the aspirations and life chances of people living in unsupported temporary accommodation in Openshaw and Ardwick, Manchester. Working across two hubs in these locations, a range of drop-in and outreach sessions will build skills in relationship-building, money management and self-confidence, connecting with services and independent living. The majority of the 600 men and women supported will be hidden homeless aged 30 to 50, who have had an unsettled housing history.

column2: A4A - Force Of Nature - Youth Community Environmental Project

This will enable the group to engage vulnerable young people in community action to improve their local environment as well as develop a youth-led environmental charter that will be made available online to other young people.

This new project is based on the organisationâ€™s current work supporting veterans. It will provide a range of basic life skills, confidence raising and job skills. The services will be aimed at veterans who have mental health issues and are vulnerable to unemployment, becoming homeless and misusing alcohol. The project will take place at supported housing schemes for homeless veterans in Aldershot and Catterick and enable a positive independent life which is sustained through stable employment.

column2: Rites of Passage - Inspiring the Next Generation
column3: This project will enable young adults aged 18 to 28 with challenging life stories (such as homelessness, drug or alcohol misuse, etc.), who are ready and willing to take control of their lives but may be struggling to become independent and move forward. Participants will be encouraged to take responsibility for themselves and others, making them more mature and employable individuals through learning to plan, solve problems, work with others, manage time, and build and maintain positive relationships.

This group provide support and accommodation to homeless men and women. Its aim is to focus on ex-offenders living with isolation, complex needs and behavioural issues, and will address the lack of mental health provision available for this group in Peterborough, Norwich and Bedford. The project will offer long-term individual support to improve mental health, wellbeing along with access to other support services to assist recovery and generally increase their quality of life.

column2: Mutual Home Ownership Coops - the answer to affordable rural housing
column3: The organisations aim is to assist rural communities to relieve poverty by alleviating rural homelessness and poor housing conditions. This project will work with the three community groups of Blackhaugh Farm, Tombreck and Comrie in Perthshire involving them in the research and study of how homes can be owned by a Mutual Home Ownership Society (MHOS). This type of organisation is controlled by its members who are the residents of the homes it provides.

The organisation will provide winter shelter accommodation in several local venues for people who are homeless and sleeping rough. They will provide people with the basics as well as offering advice and guidance on secure housing, training and work.

The project aims to change misconceptions about homeless people in order to strengthen the community and promote integration of hostel dweller into the community.

column2: Evolve (Energy, Voice, Overcoming, Learning, Valuing, Empowering)
column3: The project will empower women living with extreme hardship to achieve better long-term outcomes for themselves and their children through tailored support and providing them with new skills including finance. The most vulnerable women including homelessness, victims of domestic and sexual violence will reached through support services they attend.

This project will use mediation to help families resolve conflict, improve relationships and prevent children from being looked after by social services or made homeless at the age of 16. Conflict in the home can affect many areas of a childâ€™s life including school attendance, educational attainment and antisocial behaviour. Activities will be tailored for each family, and will tackle some of these issues by encouraging listening, understanding each otherâ€™s perspectives and productive communication.

column2: Better Outcomes - Involving hyh Stakeholders to Measure Impact
column3: The organisation will use the funding to work with a consultant and their stakeholders in order to gather evidence to better understand the impact of their work. This will enable the group to gather data and evidence in order to improve and strengthen the capability of the organisation.

This project will use the funding to deliver a programme of one to one life coaching sessions and group work for the benefit of vulnerable homeless people. This will support beneficiaries to rediscover their confidence, self-esteem and empower them to rebuild their lives and make positive changes.

The funding will enable this homelessness charityâ€™s 24 hour helpline and rough sleeper service to continue. The helpline offers support, signposting and advice to people who are homeless, at risk of homelessness or having housing issues. The helpline also acts as an entry point to specialised homelessness advice and services for the professional support community. Any reports to the helpline of someone sleeping rough will alert a member of staff to go out to offer immediate assistance and support to them.

The Immigration Advice Capacity Network will build a network of London organisations providing OISC advice, to facilitate cross sector collaboration through improved signposting, referral pathways and immigration advice skill development. Through the network CHC will establish a more effective system for immigration casework referrals across the network to ensure those with the most complex cases are able to access specialist advice.

column3: Towards support for marginalised women in King's Cross, London to break free from prostitution, drugs and alcohol, homelessness and domestic abuse.

This group will use the funding for a wellbeing project for homeless people who live in the organisationâ€™s temporary and supported accommodation units.

Following a successful two year pilot in partnership with Pompey in the Community they will provide a sports and education rehabilitation programme for vulnerable adults (18+) at risk of homelessness. Working with a mentor and volunteer support they will develop new skills and confidence through individual and group sessions. A range of physical activities including fishing, cycling, box-fit, badminton and sailing will also be used to engage them.

The project aims to provide emergency accommodation and support to young homeless people aged 16-25. Issues which lead to their homelessness will be addressed and preventative support will be given to young people at risk of homelessness. Individuals will be provided with a safe environment with access to food, shower and washing facilities.  Support is tailored to their individual needs. This will be delivered through advice and access to interventions such as counselling.

The funding will be used to develop a social impact bond that allows increasing numbers of people with complex needs across Northamptonshire who are experiencing homelessness to move on and thrive in their communities at less cost. The development grant will be used engage with potential investors and for other technical support.

This project will support people with money and debt issues across the Vale of Aylesbury. One-to-one and group training sessions will be provided to help people develop the skills to successfully manage their everyday finances and avoid problems arising in the future. The training will be delivered to anyone that needs it, in particular targeting people at risk of homelessness, families experiencing poverty, older people, people with disabilities and those experiencing mental health issues.

column2: Exploring homelessness through film with Reel Access Ltd.
column3: The project will produce a film made by homeless people and those in vulnerable housing to raise awareness of the issues, stigma and stereotyping they experience. The project will help participants develop film making skills and improve their health, wellbeing, confidence and aspirations.

A creative project to provide well-being support for people with experience of issues around mental health, substance abuse and isolation who are either homeless or living in supported housing. The scheme will enable beneficiaries to create pieces of artwork inspired by museum collections, become museum volunteers and help create new opportunities for up to 200 participants to gain greater independence.

Funding will be used to continue and develop a project that aims to prevent or reduce the impact of youth homelessness amongst young people, aged 16-25 in Nottingham and Derbyshire. The project will provide support through workshops that will be delivered by those who have previously experienced homelessness. Telephone and online help, emergency food and toiletries provision, training and volunteering opportunities will also be available to empower and educate young people around the causes of homelessness.

column2: Moving Out of Hardship: Supporting vulnerable migrants in London
column3: Migrant families and young people who have reached a crisis situation where their support networks have been exhausted or have become victims of domestic violence/trafficking will be supported. Many will already be or on the brink of, becoming street homeless or live in insecure/inadequate accommodation. They will be provided with immediate short-term practical support. People will be supported to improve their circumstances through the provision of specialist advocacy and advice.

This is the expansion of a project supporting refugees, asylum seekers and vulnerable migrants with mental health issues to cope and overcome barriers in their lives. People will help one another through peer support, and there will be activities like public speaking to help improve confidence, self-worth and communication, and training at a community radio station to help people reach a wider audience. The group will also provide advice around homelessness, unemployment, education and health.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column3: 4Front Learning

This project aims to engage and support hard to reach young people including those who are homeless, at risk of homelessness, experiencing violence or sexual exploitation, migrant, Gypsy and Roma, be subject to benefits sanctions or who are unemployed and are facing hardship crisis.

Support within the large Portuguese community in Stockwell for those who are facing extreme hardship. A triage style assessment will provide emergency support to those without funds or at risk of homelessness. Support will include advice, form filling, appeals, job searches, CVs, interview skills and improvement of their English and IT skills. Working with volunteers they will also develop community links within the Portuguese and wider community.

A new project to support Portsmouth residents who are in hardship crisis due to a wide variety of causes, including debt, unemployment, low pay, relationship breakdown, domestic abuse, homelessness and disability. Immediate support will include clothes, nappies, and utility top-ups. A Circle of Support worker will work with beneficiaries to their strengths, skills and the root cause of the current issues and bring together local agencies to provide longer term personalised support.

column2: Supporting the needy - making it sustainable
column3: The group will recruit additional sessional staff to provide support for homeless people or those who are vulnerably housed. This will enable the group to meet the demand for their services, ascertain the needs and priorities of service users and ensure the sustainability of the organisation.

Through provision of temporary accommodation with host families, and family mediation,this project will aim to improve the life-chances of disadvantaged homeless young people aged 16 to 25 by offering stability and re-strengthening the family unit. Through increased advice, support and sign-posting to appropriate agencies, it also aims to tackle associated issues including alcohol/ drug abuse to improve their physical and mental well-being.
column17: Wyre Forest Nightstop And Mediation Scheme

column3: Front-line staff will assess the immediate needs of individuals and provide subsistence such as food and clothing for non EU migrants who are sleeping rough or at risk of homelessness. The support team will link them with advice services including mental health support, asylum support and voluntary return options. Staff and volunteers will work with individuals to devise a plan for addressing the issues around homelessness and immigration issues and help them source accommodation.
To employ a dedicated Welfare and Benefits Advisor who will provide specialist support to 150 new beneficiaries.

column2: Grant to Holy Trinity Church Bracknell Shelter
column3: To buy 20 beds, sleeping bags and liners for homeless people, and an external metal storage unit.

This project will continue to provide, one-to-one peer support, adult mentoring, and training programmes to support vulnerable LGBT young people to reduce the risks and pressures they face including homelessness, self-harm, attempted suicide and to challenge the barriers of homo/bi/transphobia.

The project will support those in hardship with complex needs such as unemployment, debt, mental health issues, learning disabilities, alcohol and drug misuse, homeless and threat of homelessness. It will provide advice and sessions around living skills, confidence building and social inclusion, basic cooking skills, cooking on a budget, and managing money, and provide peer befrienders to act as mentors and advocates. The scheme will also provide support for immediate needs such as food warmth and shelter.

The housing association will build on its successful pilot project working with homeless people from the Horn of Africa in the organisations hostelâ€™s located in Lambeth, Southwark and Wandsworth to improve their life skills and health in order to rebuild their lives. This will include workshops four days per week in English, maths and ICT as well as therapeutic and arts based activities to improve mental and physical wellbeing.

The group will use the funding to build, equip and furnish an extension in order to accommodate hygiene facilities and a counselling service for homeless people. This will enable beneficiaries to access hygiene facilities and counselling services, leading to improved mental and physical health.

The group will use the funding to run DIY workshops for young homeless people to prepare them for moving into their own accommodation. This will enable beneficiaries to develop skills to improve their chances of maintaining a tenancy and will build self confidence.

The group will use the funding to provide sexual health workshops in an area that is lacking this kind of health awareness provision. This will raise awareness of, and help address specific health issues affecting young people.

This project will continue to support people in the local community affected by unemployment, homelessness, benefit reductions and low incomes, or who do not have access to a computer or the internet. By developing its one-stop-shop for advice and practical support, the project aims to help reduce exclusion and isolation. It will offer advice, mentoring, training and workshops, and provide access to emergency accommodation, foodbanks, help with Local Welfare Provision fund applications and IT facilities.

The group will run a recovery cafÃ© which will support 225 people and 40 volunteers in the Oban area affected by homelessness, alcohol and drug addiction and mental health issues.The Recovery CafÃ© will be a three year project, to provide one to one support, peer support and sign post to specialist services. The cafÃ© will be open one day per week with two full time staff, and will include home visits, with assessments in the morning and activities in the afternoon.

The development funding will be used to develop a monitoring and evaluation programme and associated training for partners, events for partnership work and staff costs.

column2: Grant to Developing Initiatives for Support in the Community

The award supports a two year programme to bring 20 abandoned properties back into use and to purchase a further 20 properties across Teesside and County Durham.

column3:
YMCA North Tyneside owns a large building in North Tyneside which has been recently refurbished. It runs a large well equipped gym with a café, provides training and education, support to families and young people and emergency accommodation for young homeless people, many of whom have just left local authority care. 
Last year it was awarded £41,393 to employ one full-time tenancy officer and to provide additional sessional worker support to enable the young people it houses to better manage their tenancies and to help them to secure and maintain move-on accommodation. To continue this activity it has applied to the Foundation for £49,702 to run an employment programme and to employ a part-time Enterprise Development Manager to support the increasing number of social enterprises owned and run by the charity.

Berwick Youth Project (BYP) runs a youth club, an information and advice service and a supported accommodation project in Berwick Upon Tweed.  Until 2016, it had 11 bed spaces to accommodate homeless young people from the town. Following the end of a long-term lease on a large property it managed in the centre of Berwick, BYP is reduced to using the six bed spaces it has on the first floor of its purpose built headquarters. 

The grant to BYP will enable them to continue to employ a support worker. Their role is to support existing tenants, help them to move into rented accommodation and help the increasing numbers of young people that cannot be accommodated in the centre to find and keep rented accommodation in other properties in Berwick.

column2: Kitchen Kick Start: Supporting young people
column3: The organisation will use the funding to run a programme of community workshops to teach young people who are vulnerable life and social skills, specifically relating to healthy eating, budgeting, independent living and social skills. This will provide the life and social skills to enable young people leaving care, those that are homeless or from unstable family backgrounds to gain the skills and confidence to improve their life and live a healthy and independent life.

column2: Horn of Africa Health and Wellbeing Project
column3: This project will support vulnerable adults from African minority groups, helping improve life chances and reduce homelessness through addressing multiple issues people face. As well as access to facilities like showering, laundry and medical specialists at the groupâ€™s Broadway Centre, information will be available on health and social services, with referrals to more intensive services. There will be workshops on topics like mental and physical health, and peer support to meet others with lived experience.

column2: Improving Life Chances - Moving on from Homelessness
column3: This project will support unemployed people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness to improve their work skills. Following referral through hostels and advice services, people be assessed to identify their goals and develop an action plan looking at things like literacy and numeracy, job searches, training and building confidence. There will be opportunities identified by service users, such as dog walking and fishing, to help people build local networks and secure volunteering opportunities.

The funding will be used to develop a stage two proposal with the help of a dedicated development manager to in turn align with the over-arching aim of encouraging the local community to help the homeless. The grant will be also be used for a partnership engagement meetings, project information systems development, stakeholder and user consultation, travel expenses, partner planning costs, as well as central costs including finance support, printing and postage.

This project will support people who are homeless and living in temporary hostel accommodation. The group will provide cognitive behavioural therapy to help people address mental health issues, and increase awareness amongst hostel staff to better support residents. The project aims to reduce substance misuse, anti-social behaviour and victimisation, and help people engage with training, education or employment. Residents will be involved in decision-making, promoting the service and organising events.

The organisation will use the funding to offer conversational and accredited courses in English and mentoring to 30 homeless people in the local community to help participants integrate more effectively into social life and enhance their prospects of finding work or securing places on vocational courses. This will equip participants with new, work-related skills and qualifications that improve their chances of getting a job or accessing further learning, increase confidence and reduce social isolation.

column2: STEP: Skills Development, Training and Employability
column3: This project, delivered in partnership with Glasgow Kelvin College, will respond to a significant increase in demand by supporting individuals who are affected by homelessness and multiple barriers to moving on such as addiction, offending and mental ill health. The project will help individuals to sustain tenancies, reduce likelihood of reoffending, and gain qualifications.

column2: Life and Work Skills Training for Individuals with Complex Needs
column3: This group will use the funding to start a pilot project for individuals who experience homelessness, substance misuse, addictions and long term unemployment to break out of negative lifestyles through innovative training programmes. This will provide beneficiaries with life skills to restore relationships and become ready to engage in employment.
New Beginnings

column2: Transforming the lives of Bradford's most vulnerable through fitness.
column3: The will use the funding to offer a health and fitness programme to vulnerable and homeless young people. This will encourage people to live a healthier lifestyle and improve general wellbeing.
For an outreach worker to work with disengaged and disadvantaged young people in Bristol, providing tailored 1-1 support.
For practical and emotional support for the vulnerable and disadvantaged young people 13-24 with drug, alcohol, pregnancy, homelessness, crime offending issues.

column2: Sentient City - the Julian Trust Night Shelter at 30 years old!
column3: Working with Julian Trust Night Shelter users and volunteer staff, this project involves gathering stories, memories and history of the site from its 30 years in operation.
As requested by the donor towards support for homeless people.
Year one of a three-year grant towards a community vehicle project where young people are trained to work in the motor vehicle industry and gain skills for employment.
As requested by the donor

This project will target people who are homeless and living in temporary accommodation in the city centre of Inverness. It will complement current service delivery, and provide an opportunity for homeless people to find out what the internet can offer them, what services they can access online, and how these services can help to improve their lives. Many existing service users are not engaging with any other support service or agency, and many do not have the digital skills to access the support they need. The project will take place from 1200 midday to 1600 alongside the food service, and will provide learning activities and resources along with opportunities for social interaction, delivered with a soft touch, non-threatening approach.

This project will use the funding to develop the services it provides to people who are unemployed and may have been previously homeless, may be misusing drug and alcohol, and/or have mental health issues. People will be referred to the project and a range of regular activities such as cookery and gardening, and an individual support plan will be created. A range of opportunities will be available including peer mentoring, work placements with local businesses, vocational qualifications.

This project will develop to help reduce re-offending rates within high risk and gang affiliated young people aged 16-25. Many will be short-term and repeat offenders trapped in a cycle of poverty, homelessness, addiction, and mental ill health. The project will help to increase their self-confidence and help them make better lifestyle choices. A range of interventions will be used including support in prison, day centre provision offering support and advice, recreational activities and training.
column75: St. Pancras and Somers Town Ward

column2: Employment Pathways at Crisis Skylight Oxford
column3: The project's aim is to transform the lives of single homeless people by improving their employability, financial independence and housing stability. By participating in a range of accredited pre-employment and pre-tenancy training, beneficiaries will work towards their education, employment and housing goals.

This project will provide training in cycle maintenance for local people who are at risk of, or have experienced homelessness. This will mean they can refurbish pre-owned bikes, offer bike rides and hold pop-up shops offering affordable and well-maintained bikes to the surrounding community. This will boost employment prospects for homeless people and encourage more people to take up cycling, improving their physical and mental health, and providing more social opportunities.

column2: IT upgrades to education centre and meeting rooms
column3: The organisation will use the funding to upgrade its current IT system which is used by local people to access free online courses and debt and homelessness advice. This will ensure that the system is fit for purpose and enable the group to support the increase in demand for the services.

The organisation will use the funding to deliver one-to-one and small group pre-employment skills training and support to formerly homeless people living in supported independent tenancies. This will improve the life chances of participants by increasing their confidence and ability to apply for further education or job vacancies and present themselves effectively to prospective employers.

A project to provide support to people in Wigan who are homeless or at risk of homelessness, in severe hardship and needing support to re-engage themselves in their communities. The project will provide support dealing with domestic violence and help accessing GP, dentist, optician and drug and alcohol services, and . offer life skills training such as debt management,cooking on a budget or gardening. It will also provide emergency support including accommodation and food parcels.

The organisation will use the funding to run a series of activity sessions that will focus on health and wellbeing as well as physical activity sessions. This will enable the organisation to help improve the physical and mental health of homeless people and those at risk of homelessness.

This is a project by a charity in Gateshead serving people in South Tyneside. The project will purchase IT equipment and develop an IT suite to provide training for homeless people and community groups in South Shields. Training will focus on internet access, film making, CV writing, job searches and information gathering. This will enable people to tell their stories through film, and develop confidence and transferable skills to help them towards employment.

The organisation will use the funding to deliver demonstrations and training in cooking and healthy eating to service users attending its Freedom Programme designed to support disadvantaged people who have a combination of homeless, mental health difficulties, substance misuse, resettlement from prison issues. This will increase their health and wellbeing by improving their ability to cook nutritious food for themselves.

The organisation will use funding to deliver therapeutic art sessions for service users, including those who are substance misusers, experience poor mental health and offenders. This will provide beneficiaries with the opportunity to explore their feelings and emotions regarding their personal circumstances, with the aim of reducing addiction and reoffending and promoting wellbeing.
column17: St Anthonys Project for Homeless Addicts

column2: Changing Faces - Mask Construction and Storytelling for People Experie
column3: The group will use the funding to deliver an outreach hostel tour programme of their therapeutic theatre activities using mask construction and storytelling for people experiencing homelessness. This will allow marginalised beneficiaries to articulate thoughts and feelings regarding their experiences, improving health and wellbeing.

This is the expansion of a project supporting people and communities most in need in Sussex, Essex and Yorkshire, using local churches to deliver social action projects. An intensive programme of support and tools will be offered to 30 churches, who will identify which projects best meet local need and recruit volunteers. Examples of projects include befriending services for people vulnerable to homelessness, money advice services and early intervention in primary schools for those at risk of exclusion.

This project will provide a drop in service and employability sessions to homeless young people in Leyland. It will increase emotional well-being improve life skills and improve engagement with employment.
The Interact project is a programme of positive healthy activities for young people who are homeless in Crewe Cheshire.
The Roundabout Schools Mediation Project will deliver proactive work and mediation sessions to young people on the verge of or already experiencing homelessness.

Homeless teenagers including mums and pregnant girls will be supported through training workshops to achieve qualifications including parenting awareness.  This will help increase confidence and self-esteem knowledge and improve life skills.

This project provides weekly art workshops for pre-school children living in families who are homeless or at risk of homelessness.  Children will feel more confident have better communication and feel ready to go to school.

The project will provide film based activities and training for children and young people affected by deprivation homelessness and those who are in care. The project will develop skills improve self confidence and increase educational engagement.

column3: Trust Counselling Service for People affected by Homelessness

column2: Training in Cookery Skills for Homeless People
column3: The Foxton Centre offers a drop-in facility for homeless people on a Wednesday and Friday afternoon. Up to six volunteers work with a cook/facilitator to prepare healthy meals for up to 60 clients. The volunteers will be taught cooking and shopping skills, healthy eating/basic food hygiene and will also be involved in the planning of menus. The volunteers will develop personal confidence and self-esteem, and gain experience in preparing meals for when they move into independent accommodation.
£52,600 over 3 years (£18,000; £18,000; £16,600) towards the costs of engaging homeless people in food growing initiatives.

The organisation will use the funding to create a new youth project providing drop-in advice and support to young people who are at risk of or have experience of homelessness, particularly those vulnerable to exploitation and crime either as perpetrators or victims. This will enable the group to support vulnerable young people in accessing help, benefits, local services, and in understanding and attending probation or court appointments to encourage positive changes to reduce crime and deprivation.

column2: Glinc/1/1-Greater Lincolnshire MOVE (Moving on, Volunteering & E
column3: A project supporting unemployed people to get into work, including those with learning disabilities, caring responsibilities and those experiencing homelessness.

column2: Your Voice - Improving Outcomes for Homeless People in Hertfordshire
column3: This project will undertake a stakeholder consultation project to develop a better understanding of the impact they have on service users and how to improve their services. This will build the capacity of the organisation so that it is able to provide a better homeless support service.

This is the development of a project providing immediate and long-term support to homeless and recently-housed people, including ex-offenders and those with mental health, substance misuse and domestic violence issues. Each person will be assigned a support worker and personal action plan, with skills training and advice on healthy lifestyles, money and household management. The project will also provide essentials like bedding and furniture, and offer volunteering and work experience opportunities.

column2: Overcoming the Odds â€“ helping young adults in hardship crisis
column3: Support for adults up to age 26 in or at risk of hardship crisis, primarily through homelessness, street homeless or sofa surfing and financial issues. Immediate help will be offered by skilled youth advisers, providing a range of advice and resources including food, showers and laundry. Individual assessments will be undertaken to fully understand the range of complex issues that underpin the crisis to put in place a plan to enable to take back control of their lives in the future.

This charity will use the funding to provide guidance to young homeless people leaving care accommodation who have lost links with society and help them to re-engage with professional agencies. This will provide beneficiaries with specialist support to develop life skills, future plans, find housing and deal with their emotions.
column17: Xtrax (Hastings and Rother Drop in Centre)

column2: Volunteer led 'step down' support for families and young people
column3: The organisation will use the funding to train and support volunteers to deliver support to young people affected by homelessness, leaving care and no longer eligible for support from mainstream statutory services. The programme of emotional, one to one and practical support will help to reduce the risk of them regressing.
column17: Tees Valley Young Men's Christian Association

column3: This is a new projectthat aims to provide a holistic approach to breaking the cycle of homelessness, offering primary healthcare and wellbeing facilities to those who are homeless, in temporary or insecure accommodation or at risk of homelessness in Colchester.

The organisation will use the funding to continue to run a twice-weekly knitting and crochet group for people with mental health issues, where they will knit items for the homeless and local hospital baby units. This will help to increase self-esteem, self worth and confidence of these beneficiaries.

The organisation will use funding to implement a development plan for their group. This will enable them to support additional homeless people and assist them into community living, with the aim of promoting wellbeing and independence.

This project will continue and expand their existing work to address a range of issues which affect homeless people who use the Anchor House facility either to stay as a resident or access the services, particularly in assisting them to gain or maintain employment.

This project will produce an informative video relating to homelessness, including advice and signposting. This will enable the organisation to provide important information and support for vulnerable people, as well as raise awareness of the issue of homelessness.

The organisation will use the funding to develop their community cafÃ© services. This will provide a safe venue and healthy refreshments for local people who are vulnerably housed or homeless, and provide access to volunteering opportunities and healthy meals to improve their employability and health and wellbeing.

The organisation will use the funding to run a project aimed at training and developing the charityâ€™s workers (paid and unpaid) to better support complex individuals who have defined support needs and requirements. Preventative or early intervention support will be provided through four drop- in surgeries at key locations across Merseyside, offering housing advice, basic financial tips and general support.

This project is screen printing workshops and retail work experience opportunities for people who are homeless or at risk of being homeless. This will enable people to learn transferable skills, including team work, time keeping and customer service, with the aim of developing confidence and raising aspirations.

column2: The Arts Training & Careers Project/Finding Work Through Art
column3: The group will use the funding to develop the skills of homeless people by using art work placements to increase prospects. This will develop confidence and skillsets of beneficiaries, improving chances of employability.

The group will use the funding to hold a weekly lunch club and meeting place for local asylum seekers, refuges and homeless people. They will have access to a kitchen for cookery sessions and support with language and IT skills. This will provide users with access to hot food, shelter, skill building opportunities and support with accessing local services.

The organisation will use funding to deliver a series of activities for people who are at risk of being or are homeless and or have complex health and social care requirements. This will provide beneficiaries with the opportunity to remove themselves from their current situations and discuss issues pertaining to them, with the aim of reducing isolation and promoting wellbeing.

This project aims to improve health and wellbeing outcomes for children and families in the poorest communities by making food fun, providing advice and information on how to eat healthily and cheaply and making food in the community. The project will continue and expand to include engagement with adults with complex needs (mental ill health, substance misuse, homelessness).

Support for LGBTQ adults and young people currently in hardship crisis, or at risk, primarily through homelessness, unemployment, mental health issues, substance abuse, social isolation and suicidal distress who are less likely to access help due to fear of discrimination. Immediate support will provide practical support with food parcels and advocacy. Individual action plans will be developed to enable the individual to be more in control of their lives longer-term.

column3: This organisation will use the grant to deliver a free legal advice support service for young people in Edinburgh who are experiencing or are at risk of homelessness. The organisation will work with Streetwork to form an outreach scheme where young people will initially get advice from Streetwork and then be referred onto Clan Childlaw. The organisation will train Streetwork workers in the specifics of housing law in Scotland so that this information can be used in Streetwork's outreach work.

The organisation will use the funding to continue to run music sessions, recording, engineering and production for people who have experienced homelessness, mental health problems leading to serious substance misuse. This will provide a vehicle to offer support and offer a bridge between a range of recovery provisions, raising aspirations, building confidence and access to further opportunities in life for homeless people and those affected by substance addictions.

A project to support veterans, primarily Early Service Leavers or institutionalised older veterans and their partners who are finding it hard to make the transition back into civilian life.  The project will address issues, including poor mental health, PTSD, homelessness, unemployment, poor life-skills, low levels of education, drug /alcohol misuse, or anti-social behaviour and crime.

A five-year funded project to raise awareness and provide support for victims of violence against women and girls particularly amongst communities where it is seen as a family matter. Support will include safe and secure housing, counselling, access to job and life skills. Homeless and vulnerable women, many of whom are pregnant, or with a newborn baby will be given support to stabilise their lives. Amirah aims to change the lives and futures of women and break the cycle of abuse, violence and isolation.
The organisation will use the funding to employ a dedicated sessional worker, along with a team of volunteers. This will allow them to better engage with and support homeless people.

The organisation will use the funding to train volunteers to provide support and signpost other facilities to aid homeless people on the streets of Manchester City Centre. This will enable the organisation to provide ongoing support and assistance to the homeless and those in need of support.

This charity will use the funding to employ a sessional drop-in centre manager and mentoring staff who will provide advice and guidance to homeless people, and provide temporary accommodation. This will support beneficiaries to understand the help and training opportunities available in the local area and encourage them to make positive changes to improve their life.

column2: St Laurence's Larder - Winter Clean to provide better kitchen, toile
column3: The group will use the funding to refurbish and extend their toilets and kitchen. This will enable them to provide extra support to homeless and other vulnerable people who use their facilities to access basic services including meals and clothing.
IT support sessions will be delivered to people who are experiencing the effects of being homeless. This will equip them with new skills and create pathways to employment.

column2: High street humanity - using social business to transform the lives of
column3: This project will support homeless people affected by mental health and/or substance use to move away from homelessness. The project will work with local partners to offer a range of support opportunities based at each of the Social Bite shops afterhours.

The Derry/Londonderry organisation provides educational and personal development programmes to people facing disadvantage. They are using the Â£10,000 to provide a programme of DJ workshops to increase the skills and confidence of 40 women affected by homelessness.
The group will use the funding to provide a breakfast club for homeless people. This will give beneficiaries the opportunity to get a hot meal and talk to people about their problems and addictions.
This new organisation will provide a series of workshops in various art forms to residents of a homeless shelter in Loughborough. The award is for professional fees, materials and T shirts.
£55,000 for a third and final year for a full-time Wellbeing Manager plus running costs to deliver mental health support services for homeless people living at Evolve Housing + Support units.

The group provides support and facilities for homeless families.  The grant will assist the group to provide support to vulnerable adults and children by running afterschools clubs, schemes and events.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group from Edinburgh provide a drop in cafe with laundry facilities for homeless people, they also provide support, information and advice incorporating outreach work. Grant will allow the group to provide self-confidence training for people who cannot access this type of support through conventional means or facilities and enable them to develop the photography skills of members to help educate the local community about homelessness issues.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: The group provide services to combat homelessness in the Rotherham area.  They will use the award to provide an art based project including formal lessons to allow individuals to produce art which expresses their situation. art equipment, art consumables, room hire.

The group works with vulnerable young people, giving them access to arts and theatre activities. A cast of 25 homeless people will be recruited to take part in drama rehearsals, resulting in a public performance.

A project to support disadvantaged young people in Worcestershire. The project has two interdependent elements. Firstly, it will provide a Peer Education Training programme, designed to train young people who have experienced homelessness to become peer educators. Secondly, it will deliver a Homelessness Prevention Programme which will provide information, advice and guidance on preventing homelessness, and will give young people the opportunity to share their experiences.

Workers' Educational Association aims to help adults increase their knowledge and skills through taking part in training workshops.  With a Lottery award it will buy additional new video equipment to run a project with people who have experienced homelessness.  It will provide training in video and film making techniques and provide these disadvantaged people with a way of expressing their feelings.  The completed films will be shown at a range of festivals.

column2: Day centre for the homeless. Help drug prevention, self harm, provides trai
column3: The project will enable the group to continue offering their Day Service aimed at individuals who use drugs. The project will direct individuals to services and advice that leads to decreased drug use, minimises harm and leads to a reduction in crime. The project will also provide training, education, development and job opportunities eventually leading to better self esteem and a lack of dependence on drugs.

column2: Support and Advocacy and Preventative and Awareness Service
column3: The project will provide a new service in Gloucester City working with young people to raise their awareness about the service offered by Glofysh as well as the options and choices they may face if they are at risk of homelessness. It will employ two staff to work more proactively with young people to prevent homelessness.

column2: Emmaus Sheffield Alchemists Crafting From Scrap
column3: The organisation will use funding to deliver therapeutic art and craft sessions, for homeless people living in shelters in the community. This will provide beneficiaries with the opportunity to express themselves through art as a calming therapy, away from external influences, with the aim of reducing anxiety and depression and promoting wellbeing.

With the development of ‘digital by default’ systems e.g. universal credit, digital capability has never been more important to tackle poverty, isolation and disadvantage facing communities. ‘Beyond the Screen’ aims to make the large and expansive digital world seem that much smaller – increasing confidence and knowledge of frontline workers to support the community in their digital needs and equip the community themselves with skills to use and enjoy all that the world-wide-web has to offer.     IT suites within the bureau and in partnership with Airdrie Library will have a dedicated Adviser with access to PC, Laptop, tablet and mobile phone to provide one-to-one support. Using SCVO Digital Charter online resources, clients will be supported and assisted in using digital mediums to apply for welfare benefit applications, carry out web searches, open and maintain email accounts, understand safe browsing and basic MS Office packages. Individuals will be made aware of advantage of Apps and their ease of use in travelling, managing budgets and accessing information.    Front-line workers will receive support, ensuring they are up-to-date with digital developments and confident in directing communities to maximise use of them. Volunteers, being at the heart of our services, will support the project at every stage - improving our communities’ digital presence and participation.
Funding to extend the community nursery enterprise that generates income to provide housing and living support to young people at risk of homelessness.

column2: Gardening Project - Boosting the Well-Being of Homeless People
column3: The organisation will use the funding to purchase gardening equipment and materials so they can make better use of their outdoor space and provide structured outdoor activity for people who want help to get their lives back on track after experiencing homelessness. This will encourage service users to participate in a regular activity, develop skills, access support and make a positive impact on the community by helping to create a welcoming space for all to use.

The funding will be used to run youth drama sessions for homeless and disadvantaged young people in the local community. The project aims to improve access to extracurricular activities and develop confidence, teamwork and communication skills.

This project will support Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic women to understand and access welfare rights and giving them the opportunity to escape or stay away from abusive relationships. Delivered by an experienced welfare rights advice worker, individuals will receive support on entitlements for benefits, debt management, housing and homelessness, immigration, and financial inclusion. With this project, people will have better living conditions which enable them to live safer independent lives.

The group will use the funding to deliver a series of creative workshops for homeless people to include oral storytelling, role playing, drama and musical activities. This will use the arts as a vehicle to enhance the confidence and inter-personal skills of participants, including the gradual reintegration of homeless persons into mainstream society.

A project to support people with learning disabilities who are in crisis, at risk of crisis or homelessness. The scheme will provide help with accommodation, food and clothing and access to advice and advocacy including budgeting, handling money, paying bills, travel, and organising medical appointments. The project aims to support beneficiaries to develop the skills, confidence and ability to find their voice, access mainstream services, and build the resilience to take back control of their lives.

column2: Lon/2/18 - Tackling Multiple Disadvantage Through Employability
column3: The funding will be used to develop project expansion costs to support single homeless people by delivering life changing services and campaigning for change, consulting costs with existing and prospective clients and consultancy fees for service user involvement in a project that will use a personalised coaching methodology to improve the skills, resilience and employment prospects of 600 people experiencing severe and multiple disadvantage.

column2: Surrey Law Centre Legal Advice Clinics
column3: Venue hire, administration and staff costs for operating free legal advice clinics across Surrey for the most vulnerable of people.

The group will use the funding to provide workshops and training for people who have experienced homelessness. This will enable beneficiaries to access opportunities to learn new skills and achievements.

column2: Veterans Personal Development and Mentoring Programme
column3: The funding will be used to develop a peer mentoring service for ex-service personnel in the local community. The project aims to improve access to advice and support and address community issues including mental health, homelessness, unemployment, physical health, domestic violence.

The organisation will use the funding to design and deliver confidence building activities for women in probation, women recovering from domestic violence, women with alcohol or substance abuse issues and adults experiencing homelessness. This will improve the confidence and self esteem of participants and reduce incidences of self harm and mental health problems amongst vulnerable women.

column3: This project will deliver a range of workshops, covering topics including literacy and numeracy, for the benefit of people who are homeless and/or those wishing to overcome substance misuse. This will enable them to improve their numeracy and literacy skills with the aim of improving their future employability and life chances.

This is a project offering mentoring services to young people who are homeless and sofa surfing. This will provide a training and mentoring service offering practical and emotional support, help with independent living skills, mental and physical health, relationship issues and household finance budgets to aid the transition into secure accommodation and independent living.

The funding will be used to equip a kitchen used to prepare hot food for vulnerable and homeless families, adults and young people. This projects aims to help the charity to maintain and expand its service to benefit more people.

This organisation will use the funding to train eight young people to deliver regular sessions and support to prevent youth homelessness. This will expand the organisation's capacity to provide support for young people who are either homeless or potentially homeless.

This organisation will use the funding to provide IT training for local people looking to obtain employment after a prolonged absence. In particular the sessions will focus on those with Aspergerâ€™s or mental, learning or cognitive impairments, or people whoâ€™ve been absent through ill health, homelessness or injury. This will develop the skills of beneficiaries to help them find employment.

The funding will be used to provide life skills training and qualifications to homeless people in the local community. The project aims to improve employment prospects and help those involved to make long term, sustainable life changes.

column2: Pre-Tenancy Training Project with the Stone Foundation
column3: This charity will use the funding to provide a training programme for local people living in high supported accommodation. The programme will enable them to be better skilled and more confident in managing their tenancy and to build their knowledge in money management, paying bills and understanding financial priorities and debt management. This will reduce homelessness, increase independence and improve life skills amongst vulnerable people.
This project will use funding to make weekly provisions including nutritious meals, drinks and toiletries for people who are homeless, have mental ill health and refugees.

The funding will be used to refurbish the kitchen in its community building by installing facilities for coffee mornings and community meals. This will make it suitable for community groups and make it possible to run a wider range of activities, as well as being able to prepare food for projects supporting vulnerable and homeless adults.

This project will run a gardening and enterprise scheme for homeless young people, providing activities which benefit their skills, health, wellbeing and confidence.

The group will use the funding to deliver a series of sessions for homeless and socially isolated people, these will focus on improving their wellbeing and each session will conclude with the beneficiaries cooking and eating a healthy meal. This will encourage participants to take responsibility for their own health and enable them to live healthier lives.

column2: A4A - Your Next Step - Supporting Positive Change
column3: The organisation will use the funding to engage a mentor to work with vulnerable adults who have completed life skills courses with the organisation. This will enable the organisation to take the beneficiaries forward, improve their employment skills and help them into employment or volunteering roles.

This will improve the intergration of the school into the wider community and improve intergenerational cohesion through engagement with a residential home for older people and a homeless shelter by sharing skills.

This is the development of a project that delivers support and prevention programmes to homeless young people aged 16-25. Volunteers will be trained as hosts and will provide emergency accommodation and supported lodgings placements. Following a needs and risk assessment, an emergency action plan will be created to help with securing long-term accommodation. People will receive access to a personalised programme including supported accommodation and a chance to learn independent living skills.

This project will use funding to work with the local housing trust to identify, recruit, train and support local young people who are homeless or experiencing vulnerable living conditions. The young people will become accredited community reporters and run youth engagement activities by initiating and developing a range of youth focused projects and programmes. This will improve the skills, knowledge, capabilities and resilience of local young people with multiple and complex needs.

column2: The Only Way Is UPP - Catering On A Budget
column3: The group will use the funding to inspire young homeless people living in a hostel to live independently by providing them with cooking workshops, information, advice and a completion of programme ceremony. This will develop life skills and so promote personal independence and interactions with others.

column3: The organisation will use the funding to offer a drop-in service providing benefits advice, counselling, translation services and help with completing forms or sourcing food, clothes and survival equipment. column2: A pioneering charity for the homeless.
column3: The project will provide food for homeless people to meet their basic needs and build a stronger community.

Support for people in crisis to meet their immediate needs, resolve problems and provide a platform of stability and support enabling people to take control. They will provide all year round crisis support to homeless people, at risk of losing their home, or with mental health or substance issues. People with lived experience of crisis will be trained as volunteer peer supporters for outreach support with hard to reach communities to engage the most vulnerable people.

The organisation will use funding to purchase tumble dryers, bikes and laptops for their â€˜housing the homeless accommodationâ€™, as well as provide outings for service users. This will empower residents to do their own laundry for attending appointments and interviews, have access to affordable transport and online advice and information, with the overall aim of promoting independence and wellbeing.

The organisation will use the funding to train young people in order that they can support homeless people in Sheffield to make the transition back into formal learning, employment and training. This will build capacity to sustain the work of community leaders and groups improving the life choices of people who are homeless.

This will improve the health and wellbeing of beneficiaries by providing them with basic facilities to wash themselves and be fed, as well as emotional support by talking to organisation members.

The funding will be used to provide a programme of culturally diverse activities, including craft sessions, breakfast clubs and support services for homeless people and refugees living in Manchester. The project aims to support the confidence, mental health, learning and social skills of refugees and homeless people and improve their health and wellbeing.

Homeless and ex-homeless people will work with professional film makers to produce a DVD film and other educational resources for homelessness prevention work.

The organisation was set up in 1971 to support homeless people aged 16-25. They provide accommodation to vulnerable and socially excluded young people, supporting them to develop skills and build confidence. The project will build the capacity of the organisation to deliver appropriate and tailored services to vulnerable and isolated refugee and asylum seekers which constitute 20% of the organisation's service users.

column3: The project will provide a mentoring programme for homeless people to help them towards living independently. It will encourage its users to set up their own activities such as education opportunities, employment, voluntary work and hobbies.

Fareshare is a newly formed organisation arising from the Crisis Fareshare project which collects 'surplus' food from retailers and suppliers and distributes it to hostels, day centres and other community organisations dealing with the homeless and disadvantaged.

column2: Provide rent deposit guarantee to enable homeless people move into accommod
column3: A project to enable homeless people to enter rented accommodation. The one year grant provides funds for rent guarantees. This enables low income single parent families and other homeless people to obtain rented accommodation. The funds are re-used if the tenancy ends.

Churches Acting Together works to address the needs of young homeless people in North Tyneside.  The project is to offer courses in independent living skills to young people in its care.  The 1 year Big Lottery Fund grant will fund a new full time post of Project Leader to coordinate the training courses.

The group plans to help people secure and maintain accommodation, manage daily tasks and provide a place where homeless people, people with a learning disability, and people addicted to drugs and alcohol can obtain food, clothing and advice.

The group will develop a new project to assist local people who are excluded because of drug dependency, alcohol abuse, being ex-offenders, coping with mental health and behavioural conditions, many of whom are homeless. Working with other partners, the organisation will provide information and signposting services, help in finding accommodation and training, volunteering and employment advice.

This will develop their life skills and support them to become active members of the community.

A log cabin and landscape area will be installed, which will be used to carry out a bike hub service. Young people who are not in employment, education or training, or who are disengaged or homeless, will be trained in bike mechanics, helping them to develop new skills.

Project Summary :  This organisation will use the funding to deliver creative writing workshops to people who are homeless or making the transition to securing a home following a period of homelessness. This will enable participants to improve their communication, literacy skills and confidence, as well as use creative writing as a means of telling their stories and expressing themselves, which will culminate in a public exhibition to raise awareness of homelessness.

The Marylebone Project is a supported housing project and daily drop-in centre that provides a range of support services for homeless women. The project offers access to a nurse one day per week, food, warmth, shelter, clothing and washing and laundry facilities as well as accommodation, general support, specialist support, advocacy, life skills, personal/professional skills development and move on/resettlement services.

column2: Stonewall Housing's LGBT Advice and Support Project
column3: Stonewall Housing provides the only homelessness advice service to lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people in London, thanks to funding from London Councils.  Our aim is to build on the success of this service by developing a partnership approach with Shelter, AdviceUK's BME Advice Network and the Royal Association for Deaf People to ensure more LGBT people have improved access to the best advice and information to prevent homelessness and to find them suitable accommodation earlier.  As part of this project, Stonewall Housing also developed an innovative pan-London tenancy sustainment service and group support programme designed specifically for LGBT people.

The overall aim was to prevent people from London boroughs from becoming street homeless in Westminster by giving newly arrived people access to advice and other services to both reconnect them to their home area and to provide them with support services and alternative housing options where this process is not straightforward. The London Connections project provided assessment, referral, reconnection and advocacy for homeless people from all London boroughs who are arriving on the street or at our centre in Westminster. also engagement and skills training activities together with structured progression to training and employment.  The project provided access to healthcare, food and hygiene services. Specialist services for BAMER and LGBT people, women, older people and those with mental health or other disabilities.
