column2: Expanding impact of Kitezh Community for Orphans model on therapeutic education
column3: In Russia, social and economic changes have led to over one million children living in orphanages and on the streets where many of them are exposed to cruelty, neglect and abuse. State orphanages are often not able to deal with the children's special needs with many becoming homeless and unable to find work in later life, and falling victim to crime or prostitution.

column2: Development of family support and home visiting service
column3: The project will provide support to families with children under the age of five who are suffering stress, through providing home visits and a drop-in service. It will also support homeless families who live in temporary accommodation.

The project focusses on people who are homeless, the long term unemployed and those in recovery from alcohol or drug addiction. They will be given the opportunity to participate in short courses, helping them to improve their chances of recovery and opening up new opportunities to them. The fundamental element of the project is the learning of basic, personal and social skills and the gaining of confidence and self esteem.

The project will provide a free independent housing advice service for homeless people and people in housing need in Doncaster, leading to a reduction in the isolation and social exclusion experienced by homeless people and improvements in health and working practices.

This charity will use the funding to pilot a new support service for homeless and vulnerable people to include mental health awareness training for staff, courses designed to help people cope with life, as well as a work and wellbeing programme for those experiencing mental health issues. This will provide a mental health programme to help sufferers manage anxiety, depression and stress.

This group will pilot a service for young people aged between 16 and 25 living in Glasgow and at risk of rough sleeping. They will receive 3-5 nights of accommodation and safety in the homes of approved nightspot volunteers. In addition they will receive one to one support developing a support package that will allow them to address the issues leading towards homelessness. They will also be supported in working towards the longer term options of housing, training and employment opportunities.

A project in Sandwell to provide advocacy, information and advice to vulnerable residents with complex issues around employment, housing, homelessness, care packages, childrenâ€™s education, relationships, debt, benefits and domestic violence. The project will support 650 people over five years.

The project will purchase laptops and deliver a weekly digital inclusion club for young people who are homeless. This will help the young people develop IT skills that will help them to access services online including housing, and improve their employment opportunities.

This project will run a drop-in centre that will give housing and benefits advice to vulnerable young people, aged 16 â€“ 25 who are, or at risk of becoming homeless. Run by Housing Needs Advisors, and supported by volunteers, the drop-in centre will provide advice, support and access to services as well as fortnightly and monthly courses focusing on life skills and preparing young people for independent living.

Injured servicemen will benefit from a project which will support their rehabilitation, retraining and resettlement. The project will focus on veterans with multiple and complex issues including mental health, homelessness and substance misuse, to help them reintegrate back into society. Coaches will offer training to improve job skills such as construction, security, warehouse work, CV writing and interview skills. Health trainers will advice on nutrition, stopping smoking, and exercise regimes.

This project will ensure every person with multiple needs is supported by effective, coordinated services and are empowered to tackle their problems, reach their full potential and contribute to their community. This will be achieved by supporting local authority areas to develop the â€˜Making Every Adult Matterâ€™ approach, which is a practical, seven-stage approach to redesigning and delivering services for individuals with multiple and complex needs.

column2: South London YMCA Work and Learning Programme
column3: This is a new project delivered by South London YMCA (SLYMCA) that aims to improve the life chances of hundreds of homeless people staying in SLYMCA's supported accommodation over the life of the project. Volunteering opportunities and work placements will also be offered with local employers.

column2: Glinc/1/2 Your Learning Journey - Welcome aboard!
column3: This grant will be used to develop plans for a project to support workless people to get into employment, including those who are homeless, at risk of offending, drug or alcohol dependent and those living with disabilities. The development funding will be used to fund a project manager, a system to track and monitor the project, workshops and legal advice on working with partners.

The group will use the funding to provide practical employability sessions aimed at young vulnerable and homeless people. This will improve beneficiariesâ€™ aspirations, confidence and employability skills.

column2: Development of LHM's Education and Training Programme
column3: The project will drive our education work forward to deliver a combination of soft and hard learning outcomes bringing 2000 unemployed and homeless individuals from the East End of Glasgow nearer to the work place, but also building their self esteem and self respect so that it is easier for them to live positive healthier lifestyles.This will be done through a rolling programme of 26 different activities and courses, including ICT learning courses and signposting to drug and alcohol support and advice.

The group provides help and assistance to vulnerable homeless and less abled families.  It also delivers an after schools club and mother & toddlers group.  The project will enhance the skills, knowledge and quality of life of homeless families.

The Day Centre would like to run weekly session for homeless women and those in inadeequate accommodation. Workshop providers (£2500), art, craft equip (£500), rent of premises (£2000)

The project will allow participants to demonstrate the capacity to sustain an activity over a period of time, and where appropriate access educational courses to develop further skills that may lead to employment opportunities.

The aim of the project is to develop a group of peer educators who are young people aged between 18 and 25 who have personal experience of homelessness, who will be given training and support to develop a presentation package to be delivered in schools on the realities of homelessness and avenues of support for those at risk.

column2: Pure Insight - Places to belong & people to belong to
column3: Pure Insight delivers a range of projects providing practical and emotional support to young people who have left or are about to leave statutory care in Stockport and Cheshire East. This projects focuses on care leavers in Macclesfield addressing a range of serious issues including; homelessness, loneliness and isolation, poor mental/physical health and lack of opportunities, helping young care leavers develop support networks, improve their emotional wellbeing and mental health, by providing a base where young people feel they belong and have people to belong to. The grant will make a contribution towards the salary costs of a part time development youth worker and associated activity costs.

The Oasis Trust provide safe and secure housing for homeless and vulnerable young women. The Trust will improve the security system at one of their hostels. They will install CCTV outside the main door, put in shatter-proof glass, shutters for the main office and a panic alarm linked to Peckham Police station.

column2: BYPASS - Bolton Young People's Advice and Support Service

The group will appoint a part time learning mentor to build on the success of its basic skills tutor by providing an innovative education curriculum and support network. This pilot project will help to address barriers in learning for clients with learning difficulties and mental health problems by providing a role model, active listener, observer, encourager and professional friend who will challenge assumptions, be a guide and target negotiator to order to increase participation in education.

The group will set up a growing project to encourage homeless people or people in housing poverty to work on the land, to grow their own food, then cook and eat it at the day centre.  The clients would be involved in the development of the site and would help with the planting of seeds and day to day management of the plot.  The project aims to promote healthy living and the skills the clients develop could help them gain employment with commercial food projects in the future.

column3: The project is to enable homeless people to develop an allotment. The money is for gardening tools, storage sheds and recycling equipment.

This three year project will recruit and train 450 volunteers from the students of Aberdeen College to undertake coaching, supporting and mentoring roles for 150 Aberdeen Foyer clients. The Foyer works with 16-25 year olds who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. They may have drug/alcohol problems, mental health concerns, be a young offender or at risk of offending. The project will increase their physical activity and will lead to an increase of coaches/volunteers for the Foyer and the College.
column17: Aberdeen College and Aberdeen Foyer In Partnership

column3: The project will continue work funded under an earlier grant from the Big Lottery Fund. It will provide a housing advice service for young people, in poor housing or at risk of homelessness. It will also provide peer education to young people to help prevent homelessness and will help develop capacity within other voluntary organisations to deal with young people's housing problems.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: The project will provide homeless people with literacy and lifeskills courses, and offer access to computers, the internet and learndirect. It will also run groupwork sessions, discussing topics affecting its beneficiaries. They will improve their reading and writing skills and at the same time build social skills, confidence and self esteem.  The grant, over three years, will fund the salaries of two new full time lifeskills and training workers, recruitment, travel and line management costs.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column3: The project is to provide training in basic skills for homeless people by way of individually tailored learning plans which will offer users the opportunity to identify and achieve their own specific short and long term goals with a high level of support enabling them to then move on to mainstream training and skill provision.

The Advice and Advocacy Project has three main aims. Firstly it will address the need for advice, information and advocacy by homeless families by helping them to access services such as statuatory, public and voluntary sector health and education. Secondly, it will involve and motivate users by providing volunteering opportunities, thereby improving their confidence and skills. Finally, it will provide a structured playgroup for children under five so that parents are free to access services.
column17: Finsbury Park Homeless Families Project Limited

column3: The Money Advice Service provides money advice, debt counselling and welfare rights advice to Ipswich Housing Action Group's clients who are predominantly single, homeless and in a state of poverty. The grant, over three years, will fund existing posts (full-time money advice manager, project administrator/ volunteer co-ordinator) new full-time money adviser, recruitment costs, running expenses, producing information, training for staff and volunteers, consultancy and advice, room hire and office equipment.
To provide residents at the homeless project for young people with access to gym equipment to develop health and fitness and build self esteem.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group from Glasgow operates various services for homeless people.  Grant will allow the group to provide training equipment and facilities for members of the group who wish to be considered for entry into a team participating at the homeless football world cup in Gothenburg.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group raises awareness of homelessness, facilitates joint working and influences policy and provision of services. The grant is for microsoft sharepoint software and staff training.

To continue a succcessful Lottery-funded community project for people experiencing stress and breakdown of relationships. Services such as drop-in clinics, counselling and craft activities are open to the whole community and especially homeless people and people with mental health problems.

column2: Construction of a hostel for homeless people
column3: This project will build a new training centre in Newark which will be attached to a new building housing up to fifteen homeless people in temporary short to medium term accommodation. The centre will be open all year and provide training in life-skills, basic skills, IT and vocational tasters.  It will also be used by homeless people in the surrounding area and newly housed people who are having difficulties maintaining their own home.

column2: Developing community-led water & sanitation initiatives in 3 cities in Mala
column3: The populations of informal urban settlements in the Malawian cities of Blantyre, Lilongwe and Mzuzu suffer from very limited access to basic services. They are often forced to pay for water, which can become prohibitively expensive, whether from local vendors or through corrupt government departments. Supplies are intermittent and are frequently cut off to extort money. In some areas there is no local source at all and slum dwellers have to walk long distances to collect water.

The Barons Court project is a small day centre for people vulnerable through mental health issues and / or homelessness. The group aim is to provide a safe and welcoming environment that can meet the needs of the user community. The project is geared around a drink and drug free daily open access drop in 2-5pm that offers practical support in the form of showers, laundry and cut price cafe.

The centre provides support for homeless or recently re-housed people.  This project is to recruit a People and Project Manager who will work with each member of the centre to proactively develop and individual care plan. This plan will outline the activities each member will undertake and the skills they will develop, giving every member the chance to develop their skills and improve their chance of getting a job.

Street Level Art will stage an exhibition of art, sculpture, crafts and photography in Guildford as part of the Mayoral Mental Health Awareness Week. The group will run afternoon workshops for homeless people with mental health problems where they will develop new artwork, invitations and cards and learn how to frame and mount work. The exhibition will help raise awareness of the group's work helping homeless people to overcome their problems and reintegrate into community life.
The project is a series of short films about homelessness. The money is for equipment, materials, hire of digital edit suite and travel costs.

The project will integrate its existing day centre and cafe and develop activities for homeless people to improve their skills and abilities. It will ensure that there is an integrated 'first stop', providing services and activities for people with a wide range of needs.
The award will help to employ a housing needs officer, and a private sector liason worker who will concentrate specifically on developing links with the business.
column75: St. Peter and the Waterfront Ward

column3: The project will work with homeless people with mental health difficulties to help them to find suitable accommodation and then to sustain their tennancies. A specialist worker will provide advice on diet and the management of personal finances, training in life skills and advice on other agencies.

This project will give advice, advocacy, resettlement support and family mediation to young homeless people or those at risk of homelessness in Redbridge, Barking & Dagenham. Alongside advice on the multiple needs of this group, the organisation will also develop links with permanent housing providers, local authorities and Connexions to ensure ongoing provision.

column2: Shaidy Characters - Young Homeless People's Volunteering Programme
column3: Shaidy Characters is a volunteer programme for service users of SHAID and other disadvantaged young people, which will provide the opportunity for work based learning at the individual's own ability and pace. Participants will gain practical skills and confidence through their involvement in training and projects designed to develop their entrepreneurial skills and by taking responsibility for the running of the group.
column17: SINGLE HOMELESS ACTION INITIATIVE IN DURHAM LIMITED
column34: YPF and Reaching Out - Grants to Orgs

column3: The Trust provides housing, advice and support to lesbian, gay and bisexual young people who are homeless, living in a hostile environment or in crisis. The Trust will train and develop volunteers and staff who will service a mobile outreach service to be situated in Central Manchester. The project is being run as a pilot in partnership with other organisations who will provide various aspects of the funding to ensure the service runs.

column2: Provision of second-hand furniture for deprived groups
column3: The project will provide furniture to ex-homeless and re-housed people so that they can live independently. People from all walks of life will benefit, including people on low incomes, lone parents and families. The grant, over three years, will part fund a part time office manager, casual loaders and drivers; rent and storage facilities.

This project will work with young people (16-25 years) who access a range of this organisation's services (targeted at young homeless people and those at risk of exclusion). The project will offer informal learning, training and volunteering opportunities and support, to enable users to move on from their crisis situation. The beneficiaries will be encouraged to take a managing role within this project and volunteer to act as 'buddies' for the next generation of project users.

column2: Information and advice for homeless people
column3: The project will provide rent deposits and information and advice to help homeless people secure accommodation. This will enable them to develop independence and stability, with signposting to other support services they may need.  The three year grant will part fund the salary of a part time project manager, part time project officer and part time administration assistant; running expenses, training and associated project costs.

The Jobs, Education and Training (JET) project will work with homeless people to assess their needs and agree action plans with them. This tailor made approach will remove barriers to their progress and allow them to access education, training or employment. It will provide continuous support and encouragement throughout the programme and also build relationships with other service providers.

The Stepping Stones Project addresses a gap in service provision for homeless people in Barnet. The project will operate on Sunday and Bank Holidays to complement a week-day service run by Homeless Action in Barnet at the same location. Homeless people will be provided with meals and supported to access services in areas such as health, personal hygiene and drug and alcohol rehabilitation. Volunteers will receive training to help broaden their experience and develop their skills.

column2: Day trip, equipment, training and volunteer expenses
column3: A project to organise a recreational trip to Blackpool for members of this group, which supports the homeless, refugees and asylum seekers in Birmingham.The grant will pay for trip to Blackpool, photo and video camera, volunteers expenses, volunteer training and stationary.

This organisation provides accomodation for single homeless people at 'Long Street'. Many of the people supported here have disabilities, including learning difficulties. The charity wishes to create a a games area, where residents can meet socially and have a a games of cards, pool or darts. The people who live here cannot go into a pub or club to access these activities, and this project will allow them to socialise and enjoy their free time.

column2: Provide employment guidance and training and counselling
column3: The project (ASCEND) will deliver employment guidance and training and a counselling service, and provide advice and practical support to homeless young people. The project will be for the benefit of residents of South Oxhey delivered from the ASCEND Centre.
column17: All Saints Centre for Employment and New Direction Limited

column3: The purpose of the group is to give homeless people a voice and to ensure the range and quality of services for homeless people is appropriate to their need.  An award would be used to provide a range of training for current members to improve their chances of gaining employment. Advice and Guidance NVQ Training x 2(£1521), Administration Training(£680), Travel expenses(£156), Forum Administrator(£2400)

A project to develop their social media capacity to offer services for the homeless, those at risk of being homeless and rurally isolated people. This will provide an online facility to attract more income and support a wider client base in times of crisis.

The project will provide emergency and temporary accommodation to homeless young people aged 16-25 including those with mental health issues such as self-harm, substance misuse and offending. It will provide support with basic living skills, and advice and guidance, such as welfare and housing, and support to build resilience and emotional preparedness for independent living.

This group offers tailored support for people who are homeless or vulnerably housed in South Lakeland to help them move from crisis towards increased well-being and stability. The project provides three types of support: first meeting an urgent need for food, clothing and shelter, secondly tackling learning and skills development, and then increasing self-confidence and independence. The project aims to directly help 1,050 people who are identified as homeless or vulnerably housed in the area.

The organisation will use the funding to run art based workshops and activities for young people with an Autistic Spectrum disorder, homeless people, older people, and children with caring responsibilities. This will help beneficiaries to increase their confidence and self-esteem, learn life skills, and improve their wellbeing.
The project will design a website and information leaflets to raise awareness of homelessness and the help and services that are available.

A project to improve the quality of life, financial wellbeing and financial resilience of rurally isolated vulnerable people living on low incomes. The project will include drop-in surgeries, appointment based services, and home visits for those most hard to reach. It will offer advice, information and support on issues around money, debt, welfare benefits, housing and homelessness, fuel poverty and budgeting.

This project will provide a resettlement service to British citizens returning to England following imprisonment overseas, addressing issues of potential homelessness, destitution, poor physical and mental health and isolation. In addition to housing support, the project will identify benefit entitlements and help to access education, work and training along with referrals to external employment agencies.

column2: UTC Community Drama Group - helping the homeless in Torbay
column3: This group will use the funding to deliver drama themed activities for people who are homeless or recovering from addictions. The arts will be used as a vehicle to engage local people in positive social activities and become more active members of their local community.

The organisation will use the funding to provide group sessions, workshops and one to one support for young people who have experienced homelessness, and training for staff working on the project to improve their support services and promote understanding of the project and access to the young people. This will provide support and intervention activities to help improve the mental health and wellbeing of the young people, and capacity building to help ensure the future sustainability of the project.
The charity supports homeless people with the emphasis on long term engagement. The funding will support two core roles vital for direct support and development of the charity.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: This organisation aims to break the cycle of homelessness and reduce social exclusion.  The award will fund an extension of the current training services  for young vulnerable people by enabling the group to buy new computers,  software and other IT equipment and a subscription to "learnthings", an online resource for young people.

column2: equipment for tenants and buddying scheme
column3: A welcome bundle pack will help new tenants who have been homeless settle into their new accommodation.

A drop-in centre's services for disadvantaged people such as homeless and unemployed people, drug and alcohol addicts and long-term unemployed people will be expanded. The project will establish the needs of vulnerable people and then build for them individual support plans aimed at helping them achieve sustainable accommodation and employment. Primary services provided will include basic items such as food and clothing through to information, advice, training and support.
column75: St. Peter and the Waterfront Ward

column2: Healthier Communities - from Street to Home
column3: A healthy living centre will deliver onsite health treatment and support to over 1,400 homeless people. Services will include short-term health intervention and awareness-raising programmes; specialist care for dealing with issues including mental health and substance misuse; and primary services like showers, laundry, food and clothing. The centre acts as the first point of contact for the street population and rough sleepers across West London.
column26: City and County of the City of London
column73: City and County of the City of London

column3: This project is to develop a homelessness education programme for youth workers, housing officers etc. to be delivered by young people who have experienced homelessness.
column17: SINGLE HOMELESS ACTION INITIATIVE IN DURHAM LIMITED

column3: The project will continue the organisation's resettlement work with former homeless people. It starts with providing support around basic accommodation needs while the other element of the programme helps those more settled to go back into education or to find employment.

NCH Street Level will raise the self- confidence and social skills of young people who have experienced homelessness. The project will work with 50 young people per year, providing them with leisure cards which will give them access to all of Dundee City Council's Leisure facilities. The grant will pay for 50 leisure passes each year and will also fund the provision of outdoor activities to 24 young people each year.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: The Underground HLC improve the health and well being of socially excluded homeless young people between the age of 16-25.  The project will develop a new range of training and volunteering opportunities within the new cafe-style environment to be created.  Group work activities, drop-in sessions, one to one support, awareness raising within the target client group will also be delivered. The grant will fund a full-time Youth Development Manager, a full-time Youth Development Worker and training costs.

The project will be used to provide an interpreting service to give clients better access to advice and support.  The project will also provide a programme of activities and events for children and families during school holidays.

This group provides creative workshops for young people, exploring a wide range of social and environmental issues. They use music, drama movement, visual art and video to work with these topics and create performances to express ideas. They will purchase a laptop and digital camcorder to edit their movies and musical creations as well as create a touring show around schools on the issues of climate change, an opera project for homeless people and a performance project in a special needs school.

Centrepoint, a national charity that provides services for homeless young people, runs a number of projects across the North East including County Durham.  The project in Easington is being run in conjunction with the District Council and will train 20 young people who have experienced homelessness to be peer educators.  These young people will work with other young people at risk of homelessness. The 1 year Big Lottery Fund grant will pay for a new full time worker.

This project seeks to further expand a pilot project (funded by Lloyds TSB Foundation for the past 12 months) to develop three thematic networks for:  Homelessness - a targeted network focusing on voluntary organisations providing supported housing services; Health and Social Care - a targetted network focussing on organisations that provide services to vulnerable people and disadvantaged communities; and Access - a general network looking at issues of access to services.

column2: to create long term changes for disadvantaged youth in sefton and liverpool
column3: The project will provide a long-term personal development programme in Sefton and the City of Liverpool for young people aged 13 to 25 , who are suffering from a wide range of disadvantages that include failing to engage with mainstream education, a history of offending and homelessness. The programme will help raise their self-esteem, motivation and confidence and enable them to progress towards achieving their full potential.

This organisation will take a team of 50 volunteers out on one Sunday each month to carry out community work. There will be four groups - environmental, DIY, Sunday roast and Mobile Skate Park. The project will provide volunteers with access to new activities, training and skill development and the beneficiaries of the work have been identified through a similar project that was organised throughout Merseyside to support those most in need e.g homeless and disabled people.

The continuation of an outreach project in the rural areas of the Epping Forest District. It will provide advice and information securing full benefit entitlement for clients, assisting in securing housing for homeless people and managing client debt.

column2: Expanding the Impact of the Kitezh Community for Orphans model on Therapeut
column3: In Russia, social and economic changes have led to over one million children living in orphanages and on the streets where many of them are exposed to cruelty, neglect and abuse. State orphanages are often not able to deal with the children's special needs with many becoming homeless and unable to find work in later life, and falling victim to crime or prostitution.

Maidstone Christian Care provides practical support to local homeless and vulnerable people.  With help from a Lottery award it will employ a driver to collect and distribute left over food from local retailers and manufacturers as part of a new food bank project.  The food will then be then given free of charge to individuals or families who need additional support.

column2: An Integrated Learning and Employability Support Service
column3: This two year project will support individuals who have a background of homelessness, offending, and/or drug/alcohol misuse, plus multiple and complex needs. It will provide person-centred progressive guidance and personal development programmes and support services delivered in the community and in prison learning centres.  650 vulnerable people living in Edinburgh will directly benefit.

The project is to provide support services to young people who are homeless or who are at risk of becoming homeless - helping them to understand the reason why this has happened and enable them to take positive action to address the issues, turning their lives around in a positive and fulfilling way.

Step Up provides housing and support to vulnerable single homeless 16-25 year olds, it is also active in raising the profile of youth homelessness and increasing housing options for young people in East London. This grant will help fund Club500, a social inclusion and homelessness prevention project which supports 12-22 year olds.

column2: Healthier eating and physical activity project
column3: This organisation aims to alleviate homelessness in Reading through the provision of affordable accommodation and support. Based on the feedback and success of ad hoc work with clients the charity will run a project to promote healthier eating and physical activity. An Awards for All grant will pay for venue hire, equipment, training, fitness and progress tests and entrance fees to facilitate a range of activities.
This project will provide a range of support services to homeless people in Bath, particularly those selling the Big Issue magazine.
This is a project to employ a full-time worker for an organisation which provides advice and support to homeless people in central Manchester. The grant will pay for costs of the administrator.

Trinity Centre Winchester provides practical and emotional support for people who are homeless or have a substance misuse or mental health problem.  With a Lottery award it will be able to run a new six month women only pilot project.  The aim is to provide advice and information on housing and welfare issues as well as opportunities to take part in workshops on basic skills, cookery and recreational activities.  Free childcare will be available as well as access to legal and medical services.

column2: Club500- a social inclusion and homelessness prevention project for young p
column3: The proposal for this three-year grant is to initiate a social inclusion programme called Club 500, working with vulnerable 12-22 year olds at risk of disengaging. The project will target (but not work exclusively with) young black males, providing peer mentoring, family mediation and short-term emergency accommodation (The Crash Pad).
column34: YPF and Reaching Out - Grants to Orgs

column3: The project will develop a holistic package of activities and support for young people who are vulnerable or at risk of homelessness. Targeting young people aged 11 to 19 living in and around Tower Hamlets, the project's aim is to ensure that young people develop better skills for life, enabling them to succeed in education or training, improve their relationships and either remain in their family home or leave home in a more planned way.
column34: YPF and Reaching Out - Grants to Orgs

column3: This project is to offer a support centre with a variety of services, including support, counselling, care and advice. The centre will be available to people of all faiths and in particular to people who have been marginalised due to mental health problems, drug or alcohol use, homelessness and racism.

Homeless and at-risk young people in Mansfield access a range of help including advice and information, training, group work, mediation and an outreach service. The project's opening hours will expand beyond 11am and 3pm on weekdays to include evenings and weekends, while a wider programme of group work activities and social education programmes will be developed to address issues such as sexual health, drugs, parenting, basic life skills, communication, budgeting and independent living.

column2: Streetwise Opera in the North East
column3: This project will offer workshops leading to the performance of a new opera Whirlwind at The Sage Theatre where professional singers, homeless and ex-homeless people will perform alongside each other directed by one of the worlds leading opera directors.

column2: Access All Areas -Uncovering the Viking history of York
column3: This group advances the education of the public in archaeology and history. The project is to run a series of new workshops as part of the Jorvik Viking Festival including poetry, drama, music and history particularly aimed at people with special educational needs, under 5's, homeless people and people who have retired.
column17: York Archaeological Trust For Excavation and Research Limited

column3: Over the three years the project will engage a minimum of 276 young people from the South East of Glasgow in a range of sports, exercise and outdoor activity to include mountain biking, abseiling, canoeing. Work will primarily focus on BME communities, young people with disabilities and young people with a history of addiction, unemployment and homelessness. A minimum of 144 young people will also gain a sports related qualification.
column17: Glasgow South East Regeneration Agency Ltd

column3: Shekinah Mission runs a drop-in centre for people in Plymouth who are homeless, addicted or marginalized. The group will purchase laptop computers to be used primarily by their Creative Writing group, however they will also offer structured IT training, as well as opportunities for clients to drop-in and use computers for job searches etc.
column75: St. Peter and the Waterfront Ward

column3: This group provides emergency accommodation for young people who find themselves in a crisis or homeless. This is a project to encourage the young people residing at the centre to adopt a clean, hygienic lifestyle by teaching them laundry skills. The grant will fund new laundry equipment.

Charity which offers training and support for the homeless looks to develop an in-house training programme delivered by their own trainers.  This will address the very specific training needs of their client group.
The project will supprt and train volunteers involved in refurbishing derelict housing for occupation by homeless refugees and their families.

Upper Room (St Saviour With St Mary) was established in December 1990, the Upper Room is a community project, the group provide evening meals and services for homeless and society men and women five days  a week. The group also train 45, 14-16 yr-olds from four secondary schools. The award will fund a pilot African Drumming project.

This project aims to improve the health and wellbeing whilst increasing the educational and training prospects of 300 homeless individuals living in the Lanarkshire and Renfrewshire area. It will continue and develop the work of the Service Development Team increasing levels of support for homeless people by delivering greater levels of input in relation to health, accommodation and literacy and numeracy tutoring which in turn will increase employment and training opportunities.

This project is a continuation and development of a previous grant which addresses the social exclusion of alcohol dependent individuals within the homeless community.  Many of these disadvantaged clients have multiple needs and the project tackles an individual's hierarchy  of need through a redevelopment of the Harold Tomlins Homeless Resource Centre with a specially trained team to manage the Wet Centre.

column2: Project aimed at tackling homelessness and exclusion.
column3: This project will allow the Mansfield Young People's Centre MYPC (recently renamed Sherwood Street Day Centre SSDC) to maintain and develop their range of services. The Day Centre targets services to homeless or vulnerably-housed people over 16, including counselling, sexual health, life skills and resettlement support. It has also developed broader services, like breakfast for rough sleepers and training services.

The project will establish and run a 12 bed, 24 hour supported accommodation scheme for homeless people with alcohol and substance misuse issues. This will give these people an opportunity to control their substance use, access move-on or independent accommodation and become involved in their local community.

Genesis Trust support the disadvantaged in Bath through a range of services: soup run, drop-in for homeless people, life skills project and work placements. This request will develop and implement a system for monitoring the difference their work makes.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column2: Grant to Wintercomfort for the Homeless
column3: The charity supports homeless people.  Its Overstream Clean service will provide meaningful work experience and skills training to people who have experienced homelessness.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: To fund targeted casework support for people who are homeless or are at risk of homelessness.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column2: Grant to Gypsies and Travellers Wales
column3: To fund a Tenancy Support Officer to support Gypsy and Traveller families in Cardiff and the surrounding area when they are threatened with loss of their home, are in unsuitable accommodation, are homeless or at real risk of becoming homeless.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: Towards the salary of the CEO, to employ two young apprentices to provide administrative support and towards the core costs of the organisation that supports homeless young people in Barrow in Furness, Cumbria.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: The grant will support this homeless charity in Northamptonshire to implements a monitoring database and develop a communication strategy and materials.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: Towards the cost of employing a Chief Officer and towards rental costs for this charity that supports people who are homeless in South Lakeland.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: Z2K is seeking funding towards the salary of a homelessness empowerment officer to support its NextDoor private rented sector access scheme, supporting people who are homeless or at high risk of homelessness to secure and sustain suitable accommodation.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column2: Grant to Lancaster & District Homeless Action Service Ltd
column3: supports homeless and vulnerably housed people to find accommodation and learn the life skills essential for independent living and provide help and support to engage with the job market.
column17: Lancaster & District Homeless Action Service Ltd
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: the salary of the Young Person's Worker
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: The group provides support and rehabilitation for homeless people within Northern Ireland.  The project will increase and improve the fitness and health of residents of the Simon Community, through organised classes.
The group will set up an office to serve as a permanent point of contact for homeless people and ensure that there is support for individuals when it is most urgently required.

This project will work with homeless young people in Fife to help them increase their chances of finding sustainable employment. It will help young people to overcome these difficulties by providing assistance to develop their soft skills, such as time keeping and communication,  as well as helping to develop their job search skills and gain experience of using computers. The money will pay the salary cost of a new part-time Employability worker.

A project by this sustainability promotion group in Malvern to devise and perform a new piece of public theatre for members of the public to perform and watch. Themes of homelessness and mental health will be focused on within the play. The grant will pay for professionals (director, writer etc), materials, lighting, and rehearsal space.
This new group provides activities and support for people within a homeless hostel in Leicester. The project is to provide days out for members to visit places of interest.
The aim of this new group is to conduct a trial for the provision of short-term temporary accommodation for homeless people within the local community.

Volunteers will deliver education and outreach work that will prevent young homeless people in Greenwich and Lewisham from entering the cycle of homelessness. Greater support will be provided to new and existing volunteers who provide emergency accommodation.

This group provides accommodation and support to the homeless. The project will run a series of weekly recording sessions for people from homeless and mental health projects. Each session will be an opportunity for individuals and groups to write and record their own music and to produce radio programmes.

Homeless people in Peterborough who often have a reduced capacity to care for themselves because of drug, alcohol or mental health issues will learn to better care for their wellbeing. Their health will improve through activities like learning about nutrition on a budget, cooking, improving safety in the home, exercise and take medical checks.

Children from homeless families who are living in temporary accommodation in Newham will be helped with their schoolwork. The scheme will set up homework clubs and mentoring schemes, help youngsters attend reading partnerships and advocate on their behalf so that they can be matched to suitable school placements with minimal delay.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: Wired Women aims to increase access and knowledge in new areas of arts development, including video making, digital imaging and making art that addresses social and environmental issues. They will run a series of video workshops for people who are homeless, vulnerable, disabled, those with HIV/AIDS and drug or alcohol addiction problems. Participants will learn to use video cameras and have hands on experience in telling their stories around homelessness.

This group works with young people who are homeless, have previously been homeless or who are at risk of becoming homeless and also works with young offenders. They want to start a Sports Development Programme to encourage people of all ages to  get involved with football, trampoline, netball and dance. This project will provide opportunity, develop new skills and confidence and promote healthy lifestyles.
As part of 'homeless week' the group will put on performances of their rock opera.

Cardboard Citizens is the UK's only professional theatre company working with homeless and ex-homeless people as creators, participants and audiences.  The funding will contribute towards the cost of creating and staging a new show called DUST which will combine the skills and experiences of participants and allow them to present their stories and demonstrate their skills to a mixed audience of theatre goers.

This charity provides hot, nutritious meals for homeless and marginally housed clients. The award will fund an outdoor hand- washing facility for clients to  clean themselves before meals and to fill water bottles.

Registered charity offer support to disadvantaged people experiencing difficulties with homelessness, unemployment and mental health problems. Award would enable them to run extra classes on a Sunday, for those unable to attend during the week,  in adult basic skills, helping clients to attain a recognised qualification.

This housing charity runs a drop-in centre for the homeless, isolated and those with mental health and substance abuse problems. This project will involve service users in a series of therapeutic textile art sessions, resulting in the production of a themed banner. Their work will be exhibited within a large local art event, then kept on permanent display within the drop-in centre. This will help build the confidence and self esteem of participants and their elderly volunteer helpers.

This group will organise a free outdoor one day festival to showcase hip hop talent and encourage new people to become involved. They will also hold a series of rap and creative writing workshops for homeless people who are over the age of fifty, following on from a successful pilot project.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove

column3: Emergency 'crash pad' accommodation and support will be provided to young people in Newham and nearby areas of East London who are homeless, or at risk of becoming homeless. Six bed spaces for young people aged 16-22 will be provided for stays of up to three weeks. Advice will be offered about housing, benefits, training and employment.

This registered charity will set up workshops in Torbay to train unemployed people, homeless people and those suffering with substance addictions. This will result in a qualification and improve people's quality of life.

column2: Several events to mark the 200th anniversary of the Great Fire of Chudleigh
column3: The group researches and records local history for members and the local community in order to develop awareness and preservation of local historical sites. The grant will be used to mark the 200th anniversary, in May 2007, of the Great Fire of Chudleigh that saw some 1200 people left homeless.

A project for start up costs for one year to support disabled homeless people through the application process for obtaining free travel warrants. The passes will enable the holders to actively participate in society as well as provide proof of disability for those with non obvious forms of disability, such as mental illness. The group will also campaign and raise awareness of their findings and associated issues and carry out further research.

A project providing life skills training for long-term homeless people will be expanded. The project provides one-to-one key working and group sessions addressing anger management, assertiveness and positive mental attitude. Links to other development projects within the organisation including literacy and numeracy learning, work and work placement opportunities and volunteering and mentoring will be provided.

The organisation provides accommodation, support and counselling for vulnerable homeless people, with the aim of helping them to live independently. The project is to provide bicycles which will provide transport in areas where public transport is minimal, promote healthy exercise and encourage people to participate in charity cycle rides. The award is for bicycles, accessories, helmets and high visibility jackets.

column2: Entreprise, Resource and Information Centre (ERIC) project in Mansfield.
column3: This project is to develop a new Enterprise, Resource and Information Centre on the Oak Tree Lane estate in Mansfield. Framework Housing Association, who provide emergency and temporary supported housing for single homeless people in Nottinghamshire, already have funding for the Centre itself which is attached to four blocks of flats that they manage on the Estate.

column2: The Portsmouth Outreach Referral Treatment Access Service (PORTAS)
column3: The project will provide an outreach service to drug users on the streets of Portsmouth. Many drug users are homeless or are at risk of becoming homeless because of their addiction. Acting as a link between a range of drug services, this project encourages the rehabilitation of its users by putting the onus on them to make contact. It uses a mentoring approach to enable beneficiaries to improve their physical and psychological health, and quality of life.

This group promotes the preservation and protection of the good health of homeless people and relieve the poverty of homeless people.  With a grant it will pay for a part time admin post.  This person will give advice and help to homeless people, in relation to benefits, healthcare and housing that is available to them. The money will be used to employ an administration worker.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This registered charity provides accommodation and support to homeless men in Bradford. They will use the award to install CCTV cameras for their building, improving security for residents. CCTV camera system

column2: Housing Support for young people and asylum seekers
column3: YMCA Cornwall based in Penzance will receive £109,562 to enable it to continue its work with asylum seekers and previously homeless young people to help them settle into the local community. The organisation will do this by providing secure accommodation, practical help, and guidance in seeking educational or employment opportunities. The three year grant will fund two staff posts, management costs and running expenses.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group from Inverurie provide support and advice to homeless families and individuals.  Grant will allow the group to provide a starter pack for up to 20 families who are about to be re-housed.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This organisation provides advice/guidance, accommodation and employment/training services to young people that have left home.  The project is to purchase multi-media equipment to deliver housing and homelessness education in local schools and outreach centres. This will involve recordings of young people sharing their experiences of homelessness, these recordings would later be played back to other groups.
column17: Links Housing Advice Support For Young People

column3: The group runs High Street South, a project providing accommodation and support to homeless people. An IT Suite will be created to help residents produce CVs, prepare applications and search for employment. The award is for computer system, telephone line installation, telephone standing charge, broadband connection and stationery.

The group provides a hostel  plus tenancy and housing support for 16-25 year old homeless people, and a facility for play for 0-18 year olds. The project is to set up a forum (Activ8) for young people to have their say in the running of the organisation. They will receive training  in communication and experience team building at residentials and trips. A dance project will also be arranged. The award is for residential/room hire, trips, minibus hire, Dance Tutor, staff costs and refreshments.

Charity  provides support and emergency accommodation for single homeless men and women aged 16 and above in Stevenage and the surrounding areas. Counselling is a core support and grant will enable group to erect additional facilities to improve and increase number of homeless people receiving this free service.

The application is for revenue costs for three staff: a skilled Young Peoples Action Leader, Officer and Administrator to deliver opportunities for young people from homeless families to engage and participate through art, music, drama, sport and other confidence building and social activities.The money is for the salaries of a Project Leader, Project Officer and Administrator and associated running costs.

column2: The Newcastle Multi-Lingual Housing Advice Project
column3: This innovative housing and homelessness advice service project will support the residents of Newcastle through the provision of advice, advocacy and referral of clients to appropriate agencies as needed. The project will also develop a Community Facilitator project, recruiting 50 volunteers to be trained in basic housing advice to share this information within their communities through advice sessions and informal networking; improving community relations and reducing isolation.

Young people at risk of homelessness are counselled to help them deal with emotional issues, boost their confidence and raise their prospects of attending school, training or finding work. The young people referred to the project either live at, or are applying to move into, the Harlow Foyer, and are not in jobs, education or training. Counselling aims to give them with a framework with which to address issues, while an anger management group will also to continue.

column3: This community group will use an award to make a film in collaboration with residents of supported housing for homeless people. This project will enable a very marginalised group to devise a screenplay, create a storyboard, act, direct and shoot a film.  This will be supported by "Candellafilms" who are an independent production company who have expertise in company film production.

An extended day service for homeless people in Bassetlaw will provide mentoring and guidance on social responsibility; understanding and considering emotions; and anger management. The help will cover housing, employment, education, counselling on financial issues, debt management and drug and alcohol problems. Support will be provided to reduce or prevent dependency, violence and theft.

This project will help those furthest removed from the labour market, living in Renfrewshire, to access and sustain employment, training and education opportunities.  It will work with 400 people (homeless people, ex-offenders, lone parents, disabled people, alcohol users, recovering drug users, workless households and those without qualifications), and 50 organisations. This project will set up a breakfast club for homeless adults in the local area. The scheme will run in a local church hall and provide support and advice three mornings a week, along with food provisions. Prisoners working towards their NVQ will assist in the kitchen.

This project is a continuation of a project based in Penzance that will work with young people who have experienced homelessness to help them develop their skills to enable them to live independently and sustain their tenancies. The resettlement officer will provide help and advice on issues such as welfare benefits, preparing to move to independent accommodation and employment or training opportunities.

This continuation and expansion project, operating for the Yeovil and South West region, provides overnight accommodation for homeless people, food-making facilities and shower and toilet facilities. Beneficiaries also receive clean clothing and emotional support. The project aims to recruit a project manager and more volunteers to meet the increasing demand for the service. The project will also develop new policies and procedures relating to health and safety and to provide enhanced services.

The award will be used to develop a Street Games Sports Festival for homeless people across Greater Manchester. The event will provide an opportunity for homeless people to take part in over ten sporting activities at Sportcity. It is hoped that the event will be a springboard for them to address their issues and access other mainstream services.

This project in Hinckley, Leicestershire, will enable the group to set up a 5-aside football team for the homeless young people.

People who are homeless or have faced a housing crisis will benefit from a range of activities to improve life skills, reduce social isolation and develop healthier lifestyles for long-term wellbeing. Activities to suit their initial and changing needs will include sports, training and education.

This project will work with 5 different groups from South Tyneside including homeless young people and various religious organisations. At a later date visits to other parts of the UK will help identify common themes and key changes.
Counselling and complementary therapy will continue for current and former hostel residents. Women will be helped to access support to sustain a tenancy and stop homelessness.
This charity provides food and daytime shelter for the homeless, unemployed and socially isolated. This award would enable the group to send new volunteers on training courses and cover CRB checks.

Nightstop UK is an umbrella organisation supporting 45 affiliated Nightstop schemes across the UK. The schemes provide safe emergency accommodation for homeless young people in the homes of approved volunteers until appropriate permanent housing is secured.

The grant will establish a project working with runaway children from the Borough of Merton and will include advice, support and mediation for young people and their parents/carers: Child and Family support and mediation work for children with emotional and behavioural problems and/or homelessness. Through this supporta nd mediation, young people will be able to retrun to education and/or access employment opportunities.

Charity supporting young homeless people look to extend their homeless prevention programme by working with young ex-homeless people to produce a DVD highlighting key issues, developing a peer mentoring scheme and set up young people's advisory groups.

The trust provides residential rehabilitation and drop-in services for homeless men with alcohol dependency. This award will fund a new art club for people with little or no skill in art. Materials (£2400), Tutor (£2364), Management Allocation (£180),

This charity supports young people in housing need. It provides emergency accommodation for young people aged 16-25. This award will enable the group to put on a performance highlighting homelessness issues. This will raise awareness to the community of issues that homeless people face and give an opportunity to the young people to engage themselves in the local community.

This group reduces homelessness and increases access to housing resources for excluded people with housing needs across London. The group will develop, communicate and implement marketing related recommendations as per a consultants review after an extensive organisational review and merger.

This project in Tower Hamlets and Hackney will enable the group to deliver a complete housing support programme to its homeless Black and ethnic minority clients from first contact through developing care plans to rehabilitation training and support.

OASIS's idea is to develop their Positive Active Lifestyles (PAL) project for people who are disadvantaged as a result of substance misuse, homelessness, unemployment, offending, mental health issues and social exclusion. A project to run group work activities at this purpose centre for homeless people in Hammersmith and Fulham. The activities will include a gardening club, model making club, fishing club, cookery workshops, art, music and dance workshops.

column2: Hot Meal Provision/ Improved Health Initiative
column3: Hot meals will be provided to homeless, vulnerable and socially excluded people. The project will work with support and advice facilities in the day centre.

The group provides a range of services for the homeless and those living in adverse housing situations. The project is to update and improve its intranet and website. This will provide a more comprehensive service for clients, providing them with the tools to make informed decisions. The work of the group will also be more efficient, allowing it to support more clients.

The group aims to meet the housing, training and social needs of young people.  The project is to provide a support worker to offer mentoring, guidance and encouragement to assist homeless young people in accessing education and training opportunities.

Homeless young people in Skelmersdale will receive lasting support to help them live independently in the community. Youngsters will develop life skills and will be encouraged to take part in education and employment. On-going support will help those who move to independent living. The grant will also help pay for a range of building work at the centre.

Young people in the south of Worcestershire who are at-risk of homelessness will be sheltered in emergency short-term accommodation. Volunteers will provide youngsters with an evening meal and a bedroom.

column2: FRESH Community Market Garden and Education Centre
column3: Supported learning opportunities in horticulture will be provided to people with mental health issues, the long-term unemployed and homeless in Nottingham. A rolling educational activities programme, accredited training in horticulture and open days will be held and chemical-free produce sold to the community at cheap prices.

column2: Grant to Holy Cross Centre Trust
column3: HCCT supports people with complex needs such as mental ill health, addiction and homelessness with day opportunities, information, practical and emotional support. It is seeking funding for its Discovery programme providing individualised support

column3: Funding for a Transition Project Worker will support homeless people in Rhyl to better integrate when they are re-housed.
column31: Lloyds Bank Foundation for England and Wales

column3: This group will expand a pilot project in more locations in England for victims of human trafficking. When a person who has experienced human trafficking is identified, they are given a 45 day period of rest and reflection in a safe house, after which they are vulnerable to re-trafficking and homelessness. This project will address this through building self-esteem, purpose and employability skills to facilitate reintegration and independence, by delivering workshops and work experience in a safe house.

Destiny Angels Welfare Reform Project is a food and clothing bank service, however what makes it unique are the support activities which will assist vulnerable groups at a time of welfare reform and the imminent introduction of Universal Credit. The project is seeking funding for the following programme that will be running within the time frame. 1. The Money Secret Programme - is aimed at single parents and others having difficulties with financial capability skills, confidence and resilience skills. The programme will be a weekly event that will also assist single parents in formulating their own constitution as they have expressed ideas that will provide a solution to those single parents in work. As you may already be aware, single parents in work find insurmountable obstacles in their paths. This programme will therefore not only train them in skills, but will produce future entrepreneurs who aim to solve a crisis problem. 2. Food Bank and Advice Project - is aimed at increasing an extra day or hours to the food and clothing bank. While clients receive this form of empowerment, they will also benefit from free counselling from our professional counsellors. In addition to that, they will also benefit from employability advice and welfare assistance. The organisation will be working in conjunction with other agencies to manage this.

The Ridge Cafe will offer training for 24 local people facing food poverty, to feed themselves and their families with nutritious/appetising food within limited budgets. This will involve 5x weekly sessions for 4 people (x8 groups over 30 weeks), with training in: • Nutrition • Budgeting • Cooking Groups with different needs (eg pregnant mothers, parents of babies/young families, those living in hostels, those caring for elderly) will receive support specific to those needs. People will have a chance to learn to cook appetising, nutritious meals, using free/low cost locally available food. We will bring together local food businesses (in addition to those already involved) and growing projects to provide free food, to supplement food bank resources. We will provide additional volunteering opportunities in our cafe and at community meals, to help combat social isolation/to create local/cross-generational connections, and to encourage dignity – it is not about handouts. We will tackle social isolation by extending provision of community meals, moving around local venues to encourage wider uptake. Participants will be encouraged to take a stake in running the programme, to ensure it offers what is needed/wanted locally, and to give it the best chance of enduring beyond the grant period. Peer training will be developed, improving social and work skills, improving self esteem/confidence. The current welfare cuts have left many local people struggling to feed themselves and their families on totally inadequate income. What we propose is a creative alternative support system, where people develop skills (including from each other) to get the most out of what is available locally, to help each other out and to gain satisfaction from focusing on their health and on contributing to local environmental benefit, rather than feeling overwhelmed by their powerlessness and having to rely on handouts.

Young homeless people are provided with emergency accommodation and support to find permanent housing. Referred to Nightstop for help, young people first move into temporary accommodation with a volunteer host and the service continues to support them to find a more permanent solution to their housing needs.

The range of activities comprises homeopathy, counselling, art work, gardening and environmental skills.
The grant will be used to develop the Headstart project which, if successful at stage two, would offer employability and life skills training for homeless people across Northern Ireland.
The project is to produce a short film looking at the issues of homelessness and living alone from a young persons perspective. The money is for travel costs, refreshments and facilitators fees.

This three year project will continue the core service of Baseline as a project of Churches Acting Together and restructure it by creating a Manager and a Volunteer Coordinator post. It will support young people who are homeless to enable them to obtain and keep their own acccommodation. Young people will be supported, using an intensive volunteer befriending or buddying system. The project also aims to help those young people by encouraging them into training etc.
A project by this Kingsbridge community group to recruit and train new volunteers and provide specialised training for existing mediators to help teenagers at risk of becoming homeless.

column2: Feasibility study for proposed social enterprise centre
column3: This group aim to build a new and purpose built social enterprise business centre in Dundee to house social enterprise and training activities for homeless and vulnerable adults, ex-prisoners, long-term unemployed, people with chaotic lifestyles and those with addiction issues.  The group wishes to commission a feasibility study to assess the project's potential, obtain architectural designs, secure planning permission and obtain accurate estimates of the project's costs.

column3: This group provide support and advice while offering accommodation to homeless people. laptop and equipment, projectors, camera, flipchart and equipment, training and travel.

Homeless people in Redbridge will turn their lives around through individually tailored support, including access to accommodation, training opportunities and tenancy support. Recurring homelessness will be prevented through support that will include access to benefits, health and community care services and assistance to establish and maintain social networks.
The project is to work with homeless people on a portfolio of photographic images in Victoria.

The group will extend their literacy and numeracy service to provide learning opportunities on a one-to-one and group basis in a variety of settings including at home. The project will directly benefit 150 adults in the Edinburgh area who have a history of mental health problems, addictions, homelessness or rough sleeping. The grant will fund the salary costs of one existing full-time Literacy Project Development worker and one new part-time Literacy worker, travel and training costs.

Help will include mediation, resettlement, sessions in independent life skills and education in basic skills such as maths and English.

The project supports a drop in centre and an outreach service for vulnerable women and girls. Staff provides advice and one to one support on topics such as homelessness, health concerns, loss of children to social services and violent partners.

The Club was established in October 1975 to provide food and donated clothing to people in need, every Sunday 4 volunteers work on a rota to provide teas, coffee, sandwiches, cakes, and clothing to the homeless, lonely, isolated or socially excluded and poor in Islington.  This grant will allow the group to continue operations.

column3: Open Door Fife' s idea is to carry out a feasibility study and develop a business plan for setting up a day centre for people who are experiencing homelessness in Dunfermline. column3: The Advice, Information, Support and Advocacy for Southampton's Young People project will help organisation to improve the quality and access to information and advice on welfare benefits and housing and homelessness to disadvantaged young people. The project will integrate its existing day centre and cafe and develop activities for homeless people to improve their skills and abilities. It will ensure that there is an integrated 'first stop', providing services and activities for people with a wide range of needs.

Support will be provided to enable clients to adapt to their new homes, learn basic life skills and develop positive relationships with their landlords.

column2: Bute Advice Centre - Development and Improvement of Service
column3: This project will work to increase the confidence and skills of socially disadvantaged people, who are older people, lone parents, sick, unemployed, homeless and disabled people. It will provide a service for people who need benefits information, housing advice and a debt counselling service. It will also provide financial awareness workshops for young people and will help housebound elderly and disabled people to review their income and entitlements.

Women in Supported Housing offer accommodation for homeless women who require support. The award is for a project is to hold a series of workshops giving residents the opportunity to learn about various different skills to allow them to build self confidence. These courses include communication, outdoor activities, ICT, presentation and organisational skills.

This project in Coventry, will support young homeless people (aged 16-25 years) in learning how to lead independent lives and to increase their chances of achieving their full potential. The beneficiaries are residents based in the organisation's accommodation, who are identified as lacking family support, confidence and self-esteem to engage in learning or employment, as they have often had negative experiences of school, and lack self-motivation because of their academic shortcomings.
A project to provide workshops and museum visits to enable homeless young people to celebrate the abolition of the transatlantic slave trade by this charity in Soho.

This group will use their grant to purchase a ride-on lawn mower, suspension trailer and assorted hand tools. These will enable them to continue to deliver a horticultural project for the homeless and ex-offenders in the local area.

column2: Young Peoples Peer Learning Project in Housing and Homelessness
column3: The project will recruit disadvantaged young people who have experienced homelessness, and support and train them to gain OCNs in peer education, groupwork and communication skills. These young people will develop new materials and presentations for students and school pupils.
column34: YPF and Reaching Out - Grants to Orgs

column2: Streetwise Opera Workshop Programme North East
column3: This project is to strengthen and expand the Streetwise Opera Workshop Programme into the North East region to help tackle homelessness. The project is targeted towards giving homeless and ex-homeless people opportunities to take part in regular music making and music theatre productions to build confidence and restore self-esteem. The organisation directly engages with these issues through a regular workshop programme and work placement scheme.

This project will raise self esteem, confidence and improve the education of children and young people who are homeless or in temporary accommodation and therefore unable to maintain their education. It will provide four Education Liaison Workers for fo local authority areas who will tailor homework and homecare support and coordinate services between the education and housing department for the children who are facing difficulty in attending school.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: A project by this charity in Clapham Junction to provide a piece of interactive street theatre to highlight issues around homelessness. For one week the audience will be put in the role of a homeless person to engender a better understanding of what it is like to be homeless. Volunteers will be recruited from the local community to take part in the project.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This citizens advice bureau has recently gained funding to employ a money advice worker, this grant would pay for a desk and computer for the worker to use. This would allow the group to reach even more people in need of advice such as people with debt problems and those facing homelessness.
The project will continue to support formerly homeless older people, who have moved from hostels to sheltered housing and have multiple and complex needs.

The project will help people on benefits or earning a low income to find private rented accommodation by providing pre and post tenancy support. A support worker will combat issues like inadequate housing and homelessness and help people deal with debt, mental health issues and drug and alcohol misuse.
A project for an educational programme of activities for the homeless based at the day centre and other venues.

This organisation supports young people who are homeless or live alone and will, with this award, hold monthly pre-tenancy training workshops with homeless people.  The project will fund workshops about  moving into a property, rights and responsibilities, budgeting, practical issues and health and well-being.

The funding will enable this training agency to enhance its current work with young people, the majority of who have slipped through the education system, have been in care or are homeless, by providing additional recreational activities.

This group provides lodgings for single homeless people by matching them with registered landlords. The project involves translating information literature into Polish, Portuguese, Turkish, Latvian and Lithuanian to better assist those whose first language is not English.

This group works to alleviate hardship and poverty for homeless people. They will use funding to cover the cost of increasing the hours worked by the support worker and volunteers to expand the service they provide.

Bradford young people at risk of homelessness will be better informed to deal with housing, finance, safety issues and agencies.
