School teachers and youth workers will be trained to provide information to youngsters aged between 16 and 25. Information will also be provided directly to young people.

Vulnerable young people will be steered away from homelessness by Redditch Nightstop. Mediation services will bridge gaps in families between parents and young people to resolve issues that lead to youngsters leaving home. Outreach help will include the Bromsgrove area under the expanded scheme.

This project, based in London, will enable the organisation to expand its hours of service for families living in temporary accommodation. Most families the project will work with suffer not only from inadequate, cramped housing conditions but also from the many associated problems poverty can bring. This project will offer them a chance to train for a better life safe in the knowledge that their children are being cared for in a safe and friendly atmosphere.

column2: Hales House Young Persons Homeless Hostel
column3: The project is to provide activities for homeless young people outside of the hostel environment. Activities will include quad biking, horse riding, rock climbing, archery and workshops covering topics such as sexual health and nutrition/healthy eating. The grant will pay for entrance, workshop and activitiy costs, refreshments, travel and equipment hire.

column2: Young People Reconnection and Engagement Programme
column3: The grant will be used to run an IT and life skills training programme to improve education, job opportunities and self-esteem of homeless young people aged 16-25 in the Simon Community's Belfast Foyer sheltered accommodation.  The project will create a drop-in centre at the Foyer and develop programmes to improve education, help them gain employment and support them to move to their own accommodation.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group will provide new homeless clients in and around the area with a supply of  basic, essential toiletries, cleaning products and kitchen applicances to help improve their self-worth. The grant is for toiletries, cleaning products and kitchen applicances.

column2: Support For Homeless Families and Children
column3: This project will continue to support disadvantaged and vulnerable homeless families and children living in overcrowded and unsuitable temporary accommodation in North and East London. They will be supported to access health and education services, skills training and employment opportunities so that they can move on to independent living.
column17: Finsbury Park Homeless Families Project Limited

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: Fresh Start (Edinburgh) will use the grant to commission a feasibility study exploring the possibility of vertically extending the existing premises, owned by the group in order that they can continue their work of distributing starter packs of donated household goods to the recently re-housed former homeless people from within the city of Edinburgh.

This project works with the children of homeless women. Prioritising the children's needs, the project offers appropriate, sensitive and responsive childcare service. Provisions includes mother and toddler sessions, creche and kids club sessions, as well as a wide variety of organised activities and trips. These often-traumatised children are also given the opportunity, through supported play, to overcome various issues, which can include actual or witnessing abuse or domestic violence.
column17: Bradford And West Yorkshire Methodist Housing Limited

column3: This voluntary led project based in Belfast was established to meet the needs of vulnerable homeless people will develop the Drop-in centre for migrant workers.
This project will provide short breaks for local homeless people to teach them skills such as healthy living, cooking and gardening with the aim of enabling them to live independently.
column26: City and County of the City of London
column73: City and County of the City of London

column3: A project by this homeless charity based on Southwark, London to train homeless people to deliver workshops to other homeless people in order to pass on the skills they have previously learned. Skills which they will learn on the course will include customer service skills, interpersonal skills and understanding health and safety guidelines.

Key To The Door work with the homeless and people in poverty to provide facilities, social welfare, recreation and leisure time. The group will use an award to run a summer programme consisting of health and fitness plus a photography session which will culminate in the work being displayed at Oldham Art Gallery.

This project will work with adults excluded through mental health problems, substance misuse, prison experience and homelessness.  They will learn to work together to complete activities such as gardening and clutter clearance for disadvantaged members of the community. An Independent Living Skills training programme, assertiveness programmes and work experience placements will help them move on with their lives. The grant will fund salaries, staff training and travel, minibus hire and IT equipment.

column2: Community Projects Carlisle - KEY Drop-in Advice Centre
column3: The project is a one stop shop for young people 16 and 25 years old, who experience homelessness as well as other housing or financial difficulties. They provide a range of services including the KEY drop-in advice centre that is open each weekday fafternoon primarily for those who experience difficulties with housing, finance, jobs and independent living. They offer a range of advice to young people including benefits advice, housing and welfare advice, housing & employment law, debt/money advice.

column2: Advice Services Coventry -  extending our reach
column3: This project has four elements which build upon a neighbourhood renewal fund project and will meet identified gaps in the delivery of advice in Coventry working with older people from BME communities and those at risk of becoming homeless. The project will also work partnership with the University of Warwick School of Law to train students to work with local community groups.

This project will expand the work of the organisation in addressing the needs of the homelessness and supported housing voluntary sector in Nottingham. This work will focus on capacity building both for individual organisations and for groups of organisations. The project will aim to improve service delivery and to improve the ability of organisations to bid for future funding.

column2: Zambia Urban Land and Livelihoods Programme
column3: The project in Zambia will help slum dwellers to gain legal title to land and develop sustainable communities. It will help groups and individuals to understand the legal processes involved, to negotiate with local authorities for new land and to plan cost-effective housing developments. In order to do this it is necessary to strengthen existing savings and credit schemes to foster increased livelihood activities, and also provide credit to groups for initial land development.

The group are well established in the area and provide support to the most vulnerable women in the community such as the homeless, those suffering domestic abuse and those involved in prostitution. They wish to re-locate to more spacious accommodation and have secured premises from Glasgow City Council with no charge for rent, rates or utilities.The grant will be used as part payment towards Architect's fees
A project to help homeless people in Dorchester find permanent accommodation and overcome any problems that contributed to their homelessness.

column2: Emmaus Hull - Start Up Project including Trustee Development
column3: This newly registered company alleviates poverty and hardship for homeless people. They will use funding to cover start-up costs and provide training for trustee development.

This group provides activities and support for homeless people in Manchester and Salford. An award will be used to run a health awards programme which will encourage homeless and formerly homeless people to try new sports and outdoor activities in order to improve their health. Participants will be awarded for attending activity sessions as an incentive for them to continue the activity independently.

column2: The Queen Nursing Institute Health and Homelessness
column3: Homeless people will have better access to health care through the creation of an outreach network of community nurses across England. Outreach will raise homeless people's awareness to services and their rights to equal access to help.

Young homeless people in Mansfield will be trained in retail services, learn job-search skills and gain work experience in a YMCA coffee shop under a scheme that will help them move towards employment.

The project will provide a new service in Gloucester City working with young people to raise their awareness about the service offered by Glofysh as well as the options and choices they may face if they are at risk of homelessness. It will employ two staff to work more proactively with young people to prevent homelessness.

column2: Flora and Fauna at The Foyer
column3: A2 Winchester Limited is a charitable housing association and a member of the A2 Housing Group, created to provide homes and support for those unable to meet their needs in the open housing market. At The Foyer in Salisbury, a residential project for 28 young people in danger of becoming homeless, the organisation will create a wildlife garden with the help of BTCV and a landscape designer.

column2: St. Barnabas Rd. Young People's Space
column3: This charity will use the award to create an outdoor space at a local hostel for young homeless people, where they can feel at ease and socialise.

This project will provide tailored packages of support to clients, many of whom will have a range of additional support needs including mental health issues, offending behaviour and homelessness. Support will include basic skills, careers guidance, counselling, personal development planning, work experience, vocational development, job seeking and post-employment support. This three year grant will fund staff costs, beneficiary costs, professional fees, running costs, evaluation costs and office equipment.
column17: East Lothian Council, Department of Education & Community Services

column3: This project provides homeless men and women in Brighton and Hove with the skills to become both work-ready and landlord-ready. Help will be provided to maximise opportunities to secure private rented accommodation and employment. Volunteers will  also contribute to the delivery of workshops and peer support and provide clients with a role model, as they will have previously had similar experiences of homelessness.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column2: Spruce Carpets: Delivering Better Outcomes for our Volunteers
column3: This project will develop a successful volunteer programme to focus on providing supported employment to individuals who have experienced substance abuse, often leading to homelessness.  The grant will fund salary costs of a volunteer support assistant, human resources manager and warehouse supervisor. It will also fund training costs and volunteer expenses.

This homelessness charity will use an award to produce a training guide giving advise on managing finances and avoiding becoming homeless during the current credit crunch. A sessional youth worker will also run additional sessions with young people aged 16 to 25 to equip them with skills to manage their money and to make the guide relevant.

The continuation of an outreach project in the rural areas of Epping Forest District. It will provide advice and information securing full benefit entitlement for clients, assisting in securing housing for homeless people and managing client debt.The work includes home visits as well as visits to homeless hostels, a psychiatric hospital and a hospice Salary costs for Outreach Coordinator / Mental Health Advisor (34 hrs), Admin Assistance (14 hrs), Supervision (5hrs), travel and general running expenses.
column17: Epping Forest District Citizens Advice Bureau

column2: Advice service for homeless people with complex needs
column3: The organisation's main area of work is the prevention of drug and alcohol abuse and providision of help to those suffering from such abuse and their families. The project will provide an advice service on housing and money to homeless and vulnerably housed people with the aims to meet the need of people who, because of their complex needs find it difficult to access mainstream advice services.

This project aims to meet the social, educational, health and emotional needs of children who form part of a family that is homeless or unsettled in Bristol. The project helps beneficiaries achieve their potential by providing, or ensuring they get the support they need at school, in the home and in their leisure time. Each child will have their individual support needs assessed, including mental and physical health, educational needs, cultural needs, reasons for homelessness and social exclusion issues.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This new group support activities and projects involving homeless people. The award will fund the creation and production of a music CD that celebrates and showcases the talents of the homeless community in Cambridge.

The Freedom Trust works with those affected by social exclusion, multiple deprivation, homelessness, substance misuse, mental health problems, learning difficulties and other life controlling issues. It offers a drop-in centre, soup kitchen, shower facilities, sign-posting services, harm reduction advice, housing advice and a social area with leisure activities. This project will increase the personal and educational opportunities available and places a strong emphasis on the development of life skills.

column2: A New Start for Homeless People
column3: This project, in Hampshire and West Berkshire, will help 630 homeless or vulnerably housed people with low level skills to improve their employability, develop social and vocational skills and lead successful lives. It will offer training including life skills development, ICT skills and creative art. The project provides a tailor made programme for each individual, informal learning, learning needs assessments, information and advice, regular progress reviews, personal support and improved self esteem.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group provide support towards independent living for young homeless people. The grant will be used to pay for a canoeing programme, a healthy eating programme, art materials, tuition costs, costs for visiting historical sites and cultural events.
This group will use funding to run a community theatre project, aiming to improve understanding of homelessness and involving the whole community.

A project by this drama group from Stroud to hire professional artists who will run workshops working with local disadvantaged and homeless young people to create music for a live performance.  The aim of the project is to give disadvantaged young people the chance to learn new skills.

This group will use funding to develop their "Walk Unknown" project, by holding a launch event to screen and highlight previous work on the project. They will then hold a number of  training workshops for homeless people, hold two shows of their work and evaluate the project.

This project will provide homeless families staying at this group's temporary housing facility in Waveney District Council, Suffolk, with the opportunity to overcome barriers to learning. The project will have three main themes: 'Family Cookery' Story Time' and 'Family Life Book'.

column2: Consultation of Service Users and Service Providers for Befriending Service
column3: Glasgow Rent Deposit and Support Scheme's idea is to establish a befriending and mentoring service for homeless people in Glasgow, making the transition from temporary accommodation to independent living. The grant will fund consultation with service users, service providers, preparation of a final report, a hospitality budget and participants' fees.
column17: Glasgow Rent Deposit and Support Scheme

column2: Drama and Performing Arts For The Homeless
column3: This organisation will undergo a programme of drama and performing arts sessions over a period of six months for homeless users in two Cornwall centres.

column2: The Earth Into Light Community Project
column3: This community group will use an award to run a series of workshops working with an experienced artist to design and make lanterns with the aim of bringing the community together. Once the workshops are complete the group will hold a lantern parade through the town centre which will be lead by the Mayor of St Helens, this project will involve children from 3 schools in the area and 30 young adults from a homeless hostel.
column17: The World Of Glass (St Helens) Limited

column2: The Basildon, Billericay and Wickford Advocacy Project for Children and YP
column3: Vulnerable young people in South Essex will be helped to access support and representation so they can express their views, resolve disputes and break down perceived barriers to statutory services. Youngsters who face homelessness or have a mental health disorder will be among those given a voice.

This is a peer support group for young people living independently addressing isolation and loneliness. It will help disadvantaged young people who have experienced homelessness to participate in sports and other activities which young people who are not disadvantaged take for granted.Through the peer education project it will raise other young people's awareness of the risks of homelessness and increase their understanding of the disadvantage homeless young people face.

This project is the expansion and development of a previous project which was funded by Urban 2. Its aim is to help homeless people, particularly young people, lead independent lives. The project will provide a range of training opportunities, including life skills, ICT training, job search training, parenting awareness and parenting skills. In addition, beneficiaries will be mentored to develop their confidence and self-esteem.

The project will enable a group of young people who are currently or at risk of becoming homeless to participate in social and leisure activities including outdoor pursuits, dance, art and music workshops. The money is for the costs of the activities.

This group currently support vulnerable members of the community such as the homeless, carers and those with physical and learning difficulties by providing a healthy living initiative in Port Glasgow and Greenock. They intend to extend this service by refurbishing and developing a property into a healthy living bistro. The grant will pay for a business consultant to put together a feasibility study and sketch proposals to establish if a healthy eating bistro is a viable and sustainable option.
A project by this Shepherds Bush Housing Association to organise a programme of arts activities and a public exhibition for homeless residents.

Food Matters offers support and advice to organisations and individuals working towards creating more sustainable and equitable local, national and global food systems. Workshops will be aimed at helping a range of vunerable people including homeless people, to understand how to improve their diet and how this can help manage mental and physical health.

The project will equip homeless and excluded young people with skills necessary for inclusion into the community. This will be achieved by 'dream planning' which allows young people to recognise their needs, ask for help and take ownership of their goals.The project will run weekly training sessions, involve young people in peer mentoring sessions and voluntary work, run weekly workshops on various topics and hold activities to link young people from the local community and local schools into the programme.

A project to design and develop new building components which will be made entirely from waste and used materials. A prototype building will be created using these components and other recycled materials to showcase what can be made from waste products and recycled components. The project will also involve homeless people who want to learn more about constuction who will work alongside master builders and other volunteers at the Eden Project.

column2: Impact Project- Advice and Advocacy Service
column3: The project, based in Conwy, will provide one-to-one advice and advocacy services allowing homeless people to take control of their lives and move towards sustaining independence. In addition, a buddy scheme will match beneficiaries with volunteers to encourage engagement in a range of social activities each week.

A project by this Hanley, Stoke-on-Trent based charity to allow homeless people to learn new skills, play a more active role in society and build stronger communities.  The aim is to purchase wireless broadband equipment to allow key workers to dedicate more time with their clients, who they assist to achieve economic well being, access learning and increase social capacity.  The beneficiaries will be able to access the technology to enhance their own skills in a step to change their lifestyle.

This project, active throughout Herefordshire, will aim to tackle the factors that trap people into poverty and stop them from reaching their potential. This will be achieved by assessing people's needs individually and recruiting volunteers to encourage them to take new opportunities by working with local support services to deliver training, recreation, education, and employment. The project aims to support beneficiaries' development and prepare them for employment.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This continuation of an existing project will deliver an accredited training and volunteering programme for people in Sheffield who would not usually have these opportunities. Beneficiaries will be homeless, at risk of homelessness or living in temporary housing. They will have little or no formal qualifications and typically lack confidence, motivation, be unemployed and lead a chaotic lifestyle. The project aims to help them develop independent living skills and move towards sustainable employment.

This project will engage homeless and formerly homeless people in music production within a social environment at the organisation's learning centre in Westminster. It aims to encourage life change, re-engagement with society and development of transferable skills to increase beneficiaries' motivation, confidence and self esteem in order to access future mainstream education, employment or training.

The charitable community group based in Leighton Buzzard, Bedfordshire, currently have an open house project one day a week, for homeless people to attend and receive advice and have a warm meal. They will use funding towards having a three-day a week open house increasing the support of homeless people in the area.

column2: Voices of experience: Factors in positive change for street drinkers
column3: Broadway Homelessness and Support will lead this project, based in England, in partnership with the University of Sheffield. It aims to explore and understand factors that bring about positive change for persistent street drinkers (PSDs). Interviews across three cities with former and current street drinkers will explore motivation, aspirations, belief in the possibility of change and the required conditions for change. It will benefit 5,500 persistent street drinkers.
column26: City and County of the City of London
column73: City and County of the City of London

column2: Critical Mass: using operational data to end homelessness
column3: This 3 year project will be led by Homeless Link in partnership with Centrepoint, Connection at St Martin's in the Fields, Depaul UK (Depaul Trust), Off the Streets and into Work, Julian House, Worthing Churches Homeless Projects, New Horizon Youth Centre and Thames Reach Housing Association Ltd. It will collate data on homeless people to measure the impact of support services as current homelessness research is constrained by lack of quality data about homeless people and the impact of services.

A project by Writers & Scholars Educational Trust to reduce exclusion and marginalisation felt by people in Islington who have experienced homelessness. Their poetry group will gain IT skills and join internet networks to share their creative work and life stories.

This project will set up a food bank. Beneficiaries will be mainly referred by organisations and professionals and provided with a voucher to access three days worth of dried food and recipes. It will also provide food for other organisations running soup kitchens and homeless outreach. Contacts will be made with schools and other organisations to promote the service and encourage food donations. Supermarkets will also be approached to act as food collection points.

This project works to help homeless people or people at risk of becoming homeless in Burnley secure or retain their homes and improve their lifestyles. The project will provide a package of intensive support in areas such as lifestyle, career and health issues. They will offer drop-in facilities, shared lunches, access to employment searches, training including basic IT skills and support group activities such as food and exercise sessions to help the service users overcome their difficulties.

This project gives homeless people in Manchester and Salford the opportunity to learn new skills, gain qualifications, increase their self esteem and confidence, improve their health, and to move on to take up employment, education, training or voluntary work in the community. It will help deal with homeless people's low levels of self confidence, and the multiple problems they face in relation to drugs, alcohol, and mental and physical health.

This project provides in-depth support to homeless people in Birmingham to develop life skills for living independently. The project will address a number of issues including low self esteem, low educational attainment, lack of training and employment opportunities, managing finances and presentation skills. The project will better prepare homeless people for taking the next step in gaining independent accommodation and re-integrating with the community.

This project aims to ensure homeless adults in Sheffield have opportunities to move away from long-term or repeat homelessness and its associated issues. The project is a day centre facility providing volunteering opportunities, and occupational, leisure and educational activities to vulnerable adults to increase self-esteem, skills, interests and life opportunities, ultimately helping them to build a more stable lifestyle.

This project aims to improve the health of women affected by prostitution in Coventry, who may have a history of domestic abuse, substance misuse and exploitation. It also aims to reduce the number of women working on the streets. Support will be given through an outreach and drop-in service, help at times of crisis such as homelessness, substance misuse relapse or health crisis, through a user support group teaching various life skills and through befriending.

This project in Kingston upon Thames finds suitable temporary accommodation for people sleeping rough or 'sofa surfers'. The hostel placement service will run a daily drop-in service that will offer direct intervention including providing new housing opportunities for those living in hostels by making referrals to accommodation providers. It will also help with placing clients into Kingston Churches Action on Homelessness's own temporary accommodation and will offer support and advice.

This is a project by a community organisation in Esher, Surrey. The group will use the funding to modernise and improve their office equipment. This will improve the overall sustainability and quality of the service in order to meet the needs of homeless people.

This is a project by a charity in Stockport. The group will use the funding to provide art workshops for homeless and disadvantaged adults. This will enable the group to address their negative barriers to learning and they will also produce original artwork for an exhibition aimed at raising awareness of living on the streets and homelessness which will tour Manchester.

column2: Harbour Place Health Well-Being and Worklessness Project
column3: This project offers homeless and vulnerable people in North East Lincolnshire access to facilities including showers, nutritional meals and laundry services. More involved services include advice and advocacy on issues such as education, employment and health, with signposting and referral systems to voluntary and statutory services. Beneficiaries will have access to computer services to help them access employment and educational opportunities and offered opportunities to volunteer.

City Gate Community Projects manage the Brighton and Hove Fareshare scheme, redistributing high quality surplus fresh food from wholesalers and retailers to day centres and night shelters for homeless people. An award will enable them to expand their current services by purchasing a refrigerator. They will also involve more volunteers, who are usually vulnerable people from the projects. Volunteers will be given training in manual handling and food hygiene, which could lead to employment.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove

column2: Southbase - Stop Social Isolation in Southend
column3: Southbase is a drop in service for vulnerable people who have been made homeless in Southend. The organisation will use an award to provide new resources for the drop in centre, such as computers, and college training sessions. The aim of the project is to reduce social isolation and provide new skills for its users.

This community group based in Loughborough will use an award to provide IT facilities for the homeless and vulnerable young people that they work with. The project will enable them to build up important skills and help those trying to re-enter education. The project will also improve confidence and access to jobs.

A project by this charity based in Islington, London to arrange a series of workshops to allow ten social enterprises who train and employ homeless people to share best practice in training, human resources and employment processes. A guide will be produced following consultations that will be made available to organisations across the UK. The project improves the vocational opportunities for homeless people.

This charity based in Greenwich to provide food and counselling services for homeless people. They will also distribute toiletries, non prescription medicines and hygiene items in order to improve their quality of life. The project will give opportunities for homeless people to volunteer and develop their skills, reduce their isolation and social exclusion and will also help them with any addictions and any mental health issues in order to get them off the streets.

The group, which provides housing and accommodation for disadvantaged people in Northern Ireland, will use the grant to refurbish the flats and common room of the supported accommodation project in Clooney Terrace for young homeless people.

The grant will be used to fund the Community Learning for Independent Living project which will work to tackle the issues affecting the organisation's homeless residents including depression, drug and alcohol addiction, and lack of education. The organisation will continue to offer a programme of counselling and education that will help the men deal with their emotions and build for the future.

This group plan to provide opportunities for outdoor activities such as visits and hill walking. They will also provide Halloween and Christmas parties. This grant will fund transport costs, entrance fees, food, youth hostel accommodation, outdoor activities, volunteers expenses, toiletries, waterproofs, walking boots and party costs.

column2: Rehabilitation provisions and services for vulnerable adults
column3: A project by this Birmingham based group to offer support, housing provisions and outdoor activities to vulnerable, homeless adults in the community. The project aims to break the cycle of homelessness, anti-social behaviour and reoffending.

column2: Promoting the services and skills of vulnerable people
column3: This group will use funding to produce, distribute and promote a catalogue promoting the various services offered by the agencies who are members of SAVE, which help to develop the skills and employability of the homeless and other vulnerable people.
column17: Sheffield Agencies for the Vulnerable and Excluded (SAVE)

column3: Cambridge Cyrenians provide a range of accommodation and support services for homeless people. An experienced ceramicist will run workshops where handmade ceramic tiles will be made by residents. Participants will develop a range of skills through producing, firing and marketing the tiles.

This is to develop an online project currently run by Konnect9 Worldwide in Leicestershire. The project aims to match surplus items to disadvantaged and hard to reach people across England. These items are donated by companies and include clothing, toiletries, toys and educational materials and computer equipment. It will target children and families, isolated groups including homeless people and vulnerable groups such as people fleeing violence. It also means fewer items being sent to landfill.

The funding will continue and expand this service for homeless people in Oxfordshire. The project will address issues that have resulted in participants becoming homeless and provide them with the skills to sustain their own accommodation in the future. This service will tackle issues that contribute to homelessness including lack of motivation, poor concentration, and lack of confidence, poor social skills, and the inability to meet commitments or to establish a routine.

This is a project by a community organisation in Staines. This group will use the funding to modernise the infrastructure of their IT and Management systems in order to sustain their charity which helps homeless people to access private accommodation.

Orignally built in 1841, St Peter's Crypt in Hackney is used as a cold-weather night shelter for homeless people, community cafe and by groups promoting creativity and wellbeing. The project aims to combat isolation, promote integration, friendship and mutual support by expanding the services offered at St Peter's Crypt. The centre will be updated and made more accessible for wider community usage.
column17: The PCC of the Ecclesiastical Parish of St. Peter, De Beauvoir Town

column3: A project to create outreach activities in hostels, temporary accommodation and homeless support settings, offering community based accredited training, peer mentoring and work placements.The scheme will provide a range of drama based techniques to address problems faced by homeless people, while group activities will help to develop inter-personal skills and relationships.

This project aims to prevent long-term homelessness, social exclusion, poor health or exploitation of young people and support them to find long-term, secure, sustainable housing. The project will provide accommodation following assessment of the YP's needs. This temporary accommodation will be with trained volunteers in their homes. Funding will allow an additional 15 volunteer households to be recruited and trained. All beneficiaries will receive regular support and access to an out of hours worker.

This project will support homeless people in Glasgow who have just received a tenancy or will be getting a tenancy in the near future.  The project will be led by Glasgow Homelessness Network in partnership with Anniesland College, North Glasgow Housing Association and Glasgow Regeneration Agency. The beneficiaries will be affected by deep social exclusion. The four-year grant will be used for staff salaries, travel expenses, beneficiary expenses and sessional tutors.

Funded through Support and Connect this project will alleviate material poverty and financial hardship for vulnerable individuals and families who are making the transition from homelessness to permanent tenancies. It will collect and redistribute furniture and household goods to vulnerable households across Glasgow. The project will also signpost clients to support services operated by other organisations and agencies such as a local foodbank and social welfare agencies.

This Christian group will run a series of projects. The first project is to visit elderly people and to run clubs and activities that include gentle exercise. The second project is to build skills of both homeless people and ex-drug users, by providing training which will help them to build skills and self esteem. Additionally the group will support young parents by providing parenting skills training and counselling.
This project will enable homeless people to redevelop a disused allotment area within Haringey and restore it to public use.

column2: Healthy Transitions - framework for disadvantaged young people aged 16-25
column3: The aim of this three-year nationwide initiative is to improve the well-being of over 8,500 young homeless people, aged 16 to 25 housed by 120 organisations (or foyers) across England. Seven projects will be split across three years and delivered at 40 foyers per year. Healthy eating projects will be run in year one, physical activity projects will be run in year two and mental well-being projects will be run in the third and final year.

column2: 'We are the same but different' Art Exhibition
column3: This group upholds Christ's teaching in marriage, faith, the life of the church and promotes stable family life. The project is for an award to hold exhibitions of art, photography, collage and embroidery submitted by the community, including disabled people, Asian groups, homeless people and members of the group.
column17: Diocese of Manchester, Church of England.

column3: NERS acts to improve the everyday life conditions of refugees, and to promote social inclusion by facilitating their integration. The proposed project will tackle the extreme problems experienced by asylum seekers who are given a positive decision to stay in the UK. They get 28 days notice prior to eviction from their accommodation in which time they have to apply for a NI number and then apply for benefits. As both application procedures take weeks to complete, these people are very often left homeless.
column17: The North of England Refugee Service Limited

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: Hostel Feelings works with hostel users, homeless and socially excluded people. Funding will see the costs of venue hire, workshops, art materials and entertainment. Funding will also pay for equipment hire, photography equipment and film production.

This project provides young people in Kent who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless with support to help them speak in confidence to a trained mediator and receive impartial advice. The project will also provide support to families, family mediation sessions, ongoing support and sign posting to other agencies where appropriate. It also includes a preventative element, helping young people thinking of running away to either stay with their family or leave in a planned way, with family support.

This is a new project to convert the first floor of Serena Hall day centre in Slough into a learning facility and to continue and extend training provision. The centre is currently open six days per week offering vulnerable homeless people a place to go which provides advice and support as well as signposting them to other relevant organisations.The project will offer a four-stage programme.

The project will provide training to equip homeless young people or those vulnerably housed with independent living skills. The project will achieve this by providing a programme that tackles cooking on a budget, parenting and sexual health, keeping and maintaining a home, interview and work based skills, financial responsibility and information technology.
This homelessness group would use a grant to pilot a range of nationally-recognised environmental health courses, free of charge, to their volunteers and clients.

column2: CC87 Youth Project - Making Campus Better
column3: This youth-led project will enable young homeless people to participate in activities to increase skills and confidence. The provision of learning and personal development opportunities will develop skills and increase confidence and ambition and reduce isolation by bringing young homeless people together. There will be a number of activities linked to what young people want to do such as outward bound trips and group work.

This school in Haslingfield will use the award to create an outdoor learning area for pupils. They will redevelop the school garden area to be used during school time and for extra curricular activities. The school will also establish a gardening club where students will grow their own fruit and vegetables in order to encourage healthy eating. The vegetables will also be shared around the local community through care homes and homeless shelters.

column2: Action on Homelessness - Burton upon Trent
column3: A project by this group based in Burton upon Trent, Staffordshire to furnish a house to be used by people who were formerly homeless. The facility will provide temporary housing and support until permanent accomodation is secured. The project will provide a stable home environment for vulnerable people, enhancing chances in life and allowing those who are most in need to reintegrate within the local community.

This project will establish a new development and support initiative for homeless people in Essex. The initiative comprises of a number of key aspects including; advice and advocacy; health development; training and development; volunteer opportunities and facilitation of surgeries. The project enables homeless people to gain new skills and opportunities that will assist them in their life pathway and lead to financial and personal independence, healthier lives and reintegration into the community.
column75: Little Parndon and Hare Street Ward

column3: This project, based in Reading supports people with disabilities in the Borough of Reading into work, and promotes the commercial viability of local employers taking on disadvantaged people and people with disabilities. The project will be expanded  to include the Thames Valley area and to include socially excluded, marginalised and disadvantaged people such as the homeless, lone parents, carers, over 50s and young people leaving the care system.

This project based in Edinburgh will reduce the feelings of stress, the risk of homelessness as well as increase confidence and the communication skills of young people aged 14 to 15 years who are at risk of becoming homeless. The project working with SACRO will provide support services to young people and their families to help prevent them from becoming homeless. This 3-year grant will fund salaries, mediator services, administration, IT support, staff expenses and costs of developing the VDS standard.

column2: Have You a Story to Tell?
column3: This organisation caters for the homeless and those in temporary accommodation. They will use an award to run a series of drama and life skills workshops, providing disadvantaged people with an opportunity to develop their communication, social and team work skills and help them to become more active within the community.

This is a project by a charity in Leeds. The group will use funding to run physical activities for socially excluded people who have experienced homelessness. This will encourage them to participate in healthy activities, which they would not usually attend.

column2: Mendip YMCA  - Routes One Stop Shop
column3: This project based in Somerset offers advice and guidance to young people who are currently experiencing unsettled circumstances. The project provides a direct access drop-in centre during normal working hours plus one evening per week and every Saturday. It enables young people to access advice, information and support on a wide range of issues that include homelessness, crisis intervention, education and signposting to other agencies.

This group will use funding to offer a number of activities for young people who are in poverty, homeless, young offenders, addicts or NEET. The activities offered will be courses in topics such as budgeting, basic IT skills, CV writing, general health and fitness and gardening. This will help to improve young peoples' employment prospects and give them the opportunity to learn new skills.

column2: St Stephen's Film Club for the Homeless and the Elderly
column3: This is a project by a parish council in Hammersmith and Fulham. They will use funding to start up a film club for homeless and older people in the area. The project will encourage participation and provide the opportunity to meet similar people and gain access to support networks and skills development.
This is a project by a charity in Burton upon Trent, Staffordshire. The group will use the funding to re-equip a new homeless centre with bedroom and communal furniture and equipment.
column17: Burton Upon Trent and District YMCA

column3: This project will enable the organisation to complete the refurbish two kitchens and seven bathrooms in their two hostels for homeless people. Women who use the facility will be offered training in papering and plastering skills,  also gaining a sense of achievement from seeing the results of their efforts.

This is a project by a community organisation in Brent. The group will use the funding to research and develop a support package to provide advice and guidance about housing for young people who are homeless. This will increase the group's capacity to enable beneficiaries to access information and also gain additional support around unemployment issues.

column2: Partnership Development Worker - Community Project, Bradford
column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Bradford. The organisation will use the funding to pay for a part time Partnership Development Worker to identify and develop partners to provide services for vulnerable people. The will bring organisations together at the charities community centre in collaboration to help the most vulnerable members of the community including those who are homeless and isolated and this will also strengthen the volunteer sector.
This is a project led by Shelter, a charity and registered company based in London, serving the development of the Multiple and Complex Needs partnership in the Manchester target area.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: The project will support young parents aged between 14 - 25 living in Gwynedd with the problems and issues that they face. It will assist at least 100 young families with issues such as finance, child development, child care, training, qualifications and accreditations, cooking and keeping a tenancy. Sessions, training and support will be offered in various locations across rural areas, making it easier for young parents to attend.

This is a project by a voluntary organisation in Hastings, East Sussex. The organisation will use the funding to provide independent living skills and training in the operation and management of voluntary committees to 20 residents who were previously homeless and/or have complex mental health issues. This will increase their confidence and enhance their capacity to take on active roles and leadership in this organisation and other VCS groups.
This community organisation in Loughborough, Leicestershire will use the funding to establish a social enterprise trading arm to deliver service and training for homeless young people who are NEET.

This is a project by a voluntary group in Sheffield. The group will use the funding to pay set up costs and build capacity by extending their opening hours, in order to supply food and beverages and support to homeless people. This will provide homeless people with support and advice relating to health, benefits, and employment and provide hot food and drinks, which will improve their physical and mental well being and give them better chances in life.
column75: South Elmsall and South Kirkby Ward

column2: Well-being and housing sustainability in the private rented sector
column3: This England-wide project by Shelter, in partnership with Crisis, will provide an evidence base for future policy and practice by examining what personal and social factors affect people's ability to sustain tenancies in the private rented sector (PRS). It is increasingly being used as a homeless prevention route with little knowledge as to whether it is a sustainable option for different vulnerable groups. The project will also ascertain what services are necessary to support sustainability in the PRS.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This group provides supportive accommodation to young single homeless people and help them to turn their lives around. They will use funding to extend their already popular Internet access project, by providing a larger Internet facility and purchasing additional computers. This will accommodate more users and enable young people to access social networking sites and learn IT skills which in turn will increase confidence.

A project in East Ham to target local homeless people and offer them lunch and and refuge while offering the opportunity to partake in an empowerment programme which will give them skills in kitchen hygiene, IT skills and customer servicce skills.

column2: Health and Education For the Vulnerable (HEV)
column3: This charity will use an award to provide healthy living courses, exercise classes and IT skills training for vulnerable people who are homeless/potentially homeless. The project will improve the confidence, self esteem and health of beneficiaries through a variety of activities and will improve their chances in life.

The project will expand on the services already provided by St George's House Charity (SGHC) in Wolverhampton. They will support homeless people to gain practical life skills, such as decorating, literacy, budgeting and basic social skills, along with offering a range of advice. The project will provide the users with a profiled holistic care package that will be implemented in partnership with appropriate services. Beneficiaries will also receive access to an IT suite.

This charity provides support and emergency accommodation for single homeless adults in the Stevenage area.  The project will involve increasing homeless client interactivity in a training programme which will focus on tenancy management and money management training. This will enable clients to have a knowledge of tenancy and will teach skills on how to successfully maintain a secure and settled lifestyle.

A project by this group in Leyton to set up a food supply and volunteering programme for homeless people. Participants will also be given help with CV writing in order to help them gain employment. The project will help build the group's infrastructure and ability to provide food for homeless people, and will provide skills and experience to help them towards employment.
column17: Fountain of Peace Ministries of the Cherubim and Seraphim Church

column3: This group will purchase computer equipment to help homeless and unemployed people to become computer literate and improve their employment prospects. The grant will pay for computers, computer software, data projector, printer, security camera, DVDs, books and training courses.

This charity will use the award to offer a programme of confidence building, educational trips and activities to young homeless people living in accommodation provided by the group. Through access to positive activities participants will develop their social and communication skills, broaden their horizons and be motivated to change their lives.

This existing project seeks to prevent youth homelessness and mitigate the impact of homelessness amongst young people. The grant will enable this service to become more tailored in order to target the service more specifically. A variety of activities and services will be provided as part of the project, including the continuation and expansion of a scheme providing food and toiletry parcels to homeless young people.

column2: Advice Services Consortium Burnley and Pendle (ASC Burnley and Pendle)
column3: Burnley and Pendle Citizens Advice Bureau (BPCAB) will lead a partnership of four organisations with specific capacity to reach those most in need of advice including older people, homeless and those with complex needs. Services will be integrated at four local 'hubs', three new community based outreach surgeries will be established in areas of high deprivation and a peer advocacy and empowerment programme will be implemented.

This is a continuation and expansion of a project delivered by Bedfordshire Housing Link Limited (BHLL) to provide homeless vulnerable people living in Bedfordshire with employment support services to enable them to make positive changes in their lives.

This is a project by a charity in Camden. The group will use the funding to hold a series of events for homeless people and people living with mental ill health. This will provide the beneficiaries with an opportunity to be heard and help change people's perceptions.

This project will support 300 young people age 16 to 25 in the Cowal Peninsula and the Isle of Bute who are leaving care, homeless or in threat of homelessness. It will build on previous piloted activities to deliver a holistic package of services including an employment programme and an activities programme to support young people in securing and sustaining their own tenancies and improving employability and training opportunities.

This project in Exeter will use the funding to expand their work with vulnerable people to help them improve their quality of life and live more independently.The primary beneficiaries of the project will be people who have been homeless or vulnerably housed, people experiencing mental health issues or drug or alcohol dependency or who have learning or other disabilities.

column2: Emergency Accommodation (crash pad) and Chill Out, Learning Room
column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Lancashire.The organisation will use funding to create an emergency accommodation and chill out room for vulnerable young people who are homeless and for those currently resident at the centre.This will enable them to be safe, supported and have access to signposting and educational activities.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Hastings, East Sussex. The organisation will use the funding to provide an arts exhibition of the lives of people with issues such as mental ill health, homelessness, poor physical health and substance misuse through displaying photographs of themselves and creating a book of their life stories, which will include an opening ceremony. This will improve integration into the community for beneficiaries.

This is a project by a charity in Tower Hamlets. The group will use the funding to deliver a project for homeless people to raise awareness on drug and alcohol misuse and mental health. This will enable the group to promote healthier and more active people as a result of alerting the beneficiaries of how their daily life styles impact on their overall health.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Chester, Cheshire. The organisation will use the funding to design and develop a horticultural project. This will enable the organisation to improve the gardens and recreational areas at two housing units that are supported by the Charity as well as teaching practical skills to homeless people.

The four-year grant will be used to extend and enhance existing services for individuals who have alcohol related problems and who are homeless or who are at risk of becoming homeless. The project will work across three Health Trust areas (Southern, Belfast and Western), primarily within Armagh, Belfast, Derry/Londonderry, Enniskillen and Omagh. The services will vary in each area depending upon the needs of beneficiaries and services that are already available.
This homelessness charity would use a grant to develop self confidence and back-to-work skills through art activities.

This group will commission local, professional community artists to run a twelve week series of workshops covering drama, visual art, photography and computer imagery. This will enable regular service users to participate in the Eastbourne Cultural Community Festival and encourage more acceptance of homeless and distressed people and increase the prospects of employment.
column17: Oasis Christian Outreach Drop In Centre

column3: The Solas Psychotherapeutic/clinical psychology service will provide peripatetic psychotherapeutic support to homeless men and women in Newport, Monmouthshire and Torfaen, who have serious mental health problems. This will enable them to identify, acknowledge and be able to act upon the deep rooted psychological reasons which lie behind the difficulties they face. The service will  help people to move on successfully in the long term both practically and psychologically.

column2: Housing Education Service Volunteer Excellence Programme
column3: This project will increase the confidence and self-esteem of 405 young people who have experienced homeless and/or have been looked after and accommodated, helping them move into volunteering, training, education or employment. The five-year project will work with vulnerable young people across the Central Belt. The project will also provide aftercare support to the young people who make the transition to other work or training outcomes. This five-year grant will partially fund salaries and project costs
A project by this Erith community group to provide one-to-one housing benefit advice for young people and refugees to prevent street homelessness in the Bexley borough.

Stockport Metropolitan Borough Council's play portfolio will deliver five projects that will provide additional opportunities in play provision. The projects will benefit 3,444 children over three years from play deprived areas in the borough of Stockport, from homeless and displaced backgrounds and children with disabilities.

The project to be delivered by Centrepoint will involve the installation of an innovative computer system, e-Wise at Bruce House, which is a base for homeless people. The system will be installed in each of the forty-nine rooms and enable the residents to have access to the internet, complete their studies, interact with friends and search and apply for jobs. The project will also create a communal area where training sessions and social activities can take place.

This project works to support communities, schools, families and individuals in South Warwickshire to manage and resolve conflict, enabling them to make workable solutions in difficult situations. The expansion of the project will involve extending the parent/child mediation service to prevent homelessness situations arising in families and will include offering courses related to understanding and responding appropriately to teenage behaviour.

This project will help young people leaving care, young parents, homeless people, people coming out of hospital, those in severe debt and unemployed people through the provision of pro-active specialised tenancy support and debt advice. The grant will fund one new part time Money Advice Worker and two new full time Tenancy Support Workers, as well as training, travel, uniforms and IT equipment.

This project, based in Salisbury is to continue and expand upon the work of the organisation to provide accommodation to homeless people. This project will provide support to help clients address and resolve these issues. Their overall aim is to support homeless people to move into permanent accommodation, whilst reducing the repeat episodes of homelessness by helping them to develop the skills and coping mechanisms to re-integrate them into the community.
column17: Salisbury Trust For The Homeless Ltd

column3: This expansion of an existing project will develop the group's social enterprise, a catering service, providing young people aged 15-25 with supported work experience opportunities. The purchase of a delivery vehicle and adapted bicycle will enable the service to extend its services, raising awareness of the organisation locally to develop a network of opportunities for further volunteering. Beneficiaries will also be offered life skills sessions, reducing the likelihood of repeated homelessness.
column17: BYHP (Supporting Young People In Housing Need)

column2: SHARE IT! Participatory activities during Cockermouth Midsummer Festival
column3: This voluntary group in Cockermouth are working to establish a new midsummer festival to help the town's recovery from the devastating floods of November 2009. They will use an award to fund participatory activities, such as art, film animation workshops and music performance, which bring the community together. This will increase community cohesion after many people were left homeless, and attract tourism back to the town after many businesses were ruined.

column2: Out Of The Dark Into The Light
column3: A project by this charity based in Coventry, West Midlands, who specialise in counselling, childrens' services and training, to cover the travel and childcare costs of hard to reach, economically disadvantaged and vulnerable individuals who do not normally access their services.  These include people experiencing social exclusion, people living with mental health issues and homeless individuals.

This existing project based in Tower Hamlets, London aims to tackle the feelings of isolation felt by homeless people by providing informal learning opportunities in a variety of areas. It will address the problems experienced by them when trying to re-integrate into the community and re-build their lives by providing them with a range of skills and socialising opportunities.

column2: Training Room at Penny Wade House, a Hostel for the Homeless
column3: A project in Richmond-upon-Thames to improve the service offered bya hostel and training centre by fitting a new training room with equipment to help homeless people to re-integrate into society. The training room will be used to help people gain skills for use in employment and education and to help people to gain the confidence and self-esteem essential to give them better chances in life, and will also improve the infrastructure of the group and their ability to help more people.

column2: Progression Pathways at Crisis Skylight Oxford
column3: This project in Oxford will provide sustainable personal, educational, vocational and employment progression opportunities for single homeless people. A key part will be to promote personal progression by helping people overcome barriers such as lack of confidence and self esteem, mental health issues, and inadequate housing, enabling them to move forward with their lives and break the cycle of homelessness. The project will offer creative and vocational workshops.

This is a project by a community group in Redbridge. The group will use funding to provide initial health care assessments for homeless people. This will provide health care support services for people who have difficulties accessing health care.
column17: Healthy Living, Healthy Lives Community Interest Company

column3: This is a project by a theatre group in East Sussex. The group will use the funding to hold a series of interactive workshops for people with drug and alcohol dependency and homelessness. This will provide a new activity that would not normally be available to them.

column2: RECESSION 2: The Wallich Bridgend Solutions Centre -Extra Capacity Worker
column3: The project is to expand the current service offered by the solutions service through the provision of additional outreach work with vulnerably housed or homeless people in the county of Bridgend. The grant, over two years, will pay for the salary and associated costs of a part time solutions worker, recrutiment costs, expenses, training, marketing, central administration costs, management costs and running costs.

This is a project by a voluntary group in Woodford Green, Essex. The group will use funding to set up a hub for resettled homeless people. This will provide social contact, life skills, coaching and training in PAT testing, to improve job prospects.

This project aims to address the barriers preventing homeless people from becoming work ready and live healthy independent lives. The project gives service users more formal, CV relevant and vocational training and work placements. This will be achieved through delivering and accessing training to address skill-based issues and providing access to dentistry, clothing, hairdressing and similar services to address personal barriers.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column2: The Pop-up Talent Shop: 'Mastering the Laws of Employability Gravity'
column3: The aim of the project is to take career-based training to disadvantaged young people in areas including estates, homeless centres, street corners and supermarkets. It will support them to overcome the barriers to employability and help unleash their talent and potential. Young people and businesses will deliver career-based skills training and mentoring from initial tasters to long-term skills training and work placements, making this a youth-owned enterprise.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Keighley. The organisation will use the funding to provide an additional level of support to homeless people and will include offering interactive advice sessions and the development of a hub where service users can access computers and the internet to access vital services including benefits, job searches and to complete on line training courses. This will enable homeless people to access improved advice, support and training.

This group are looking at partnerships with non-arts organisations such as health, housing, community planning, homelessness, child welfare and community safety to help to address gaps in the provision of services with emphasis on areas where traditional approaches are not getting through. The group will be working with people in Glasgow, North Lanarkshire and South Lanarkshire. The grant will be used to fund consultant research support and workshops.

This group will use funding to upgrade its shower facilities for the use of homeless people. The facility provides the opportunity for people to maintain their dignity through being able to wash, but also offers an opportunity for them to interact with others in a social environment.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group will take a number of service users on an outward bound course in order to build confidence and increase skills. The award will fund instructor costs, lunch expenses and travel costs.

The grant will be used to run the Foyle Haven Safe From Harm project which will provide premises and support services for street drinkers and the homeless in a bid to improve their safety and well-being. The project will provide a safe place for drinkers to be, rather than on the streets, as well as laundry, shower and sleeping facilities.  It would also deliver programmes such as personal hygiene, anger management, healthy eating including nutrition and chronic alcohol abuse.

The award will fund a study aimed at identifying how systems, policies and procedures across seven Citizens Advice Bureau can be merged in order to improve the frequency and quality of advice services across North Yorkshire. Clients are faced with problems stemming from unemployment, debt, homelessness and isolation. A more efficient service will provide the advice and support they need to take control of their problems, resolve immediate crises and create long term solutions that will improve their lives.
column17: Citizens Advice North Yorkshire and York

column3: Nightstop Teesside provides emergency accommodation for vulnerable young people. They will expand their services into Hartlepool using volunteers to break the cycle of homelessness and assist young people to move into more stable, longer term accommodation.

This charity based in Cambridge provide support and advice services for people who are homeless or at risk of being homeless. The project involves homeless people working with a local artist to create three memorial sculptures in memory of the increased number of deaths in the community. Participants will take part in workshops gaining experience of working with others on a meaningful project to raise their self esteem. The sculptures will be installed in three appropriate areas in Cambridge.

This project will maintain existing provision and will expand services back to their previous levels. Currently a 'skeleton' service is provided due to funding issues. The project will help homeless people to meet their immediate need for shelter. In addition, it helps the beneficiaries to work through and address those elements of their life that contribute to, or result from their homelessness.
column17: St Richard Of Chichester Christian CareAssociation Ltd

column2: Making The Most of Our City
column3: York A-Team provide those who are homeless or in vulnerable housing with education and activity programmes, mainly on the causes and effects of homelessness. The project is called "Making The Most of Our City" and participants will be sign-posted from other local groups who support homeless people.

The Basement project is based in Bromsgrove and offers services to homeless young people. Expansion will allow the current drop-in centre to be open for longer hours with practical services being offered to those in need, including a kitchen, shower, washing machine, food parcels and good start packages (which typically include toiletries, towels and essential clothing items).

This project continues to support 16-25 year olds who are homeless or are threatened with homelessness in Exeter and East Devon with the aim to get them back with their families or into long-term safe accommodation. The project aims to identify and address issues relating to education, health and employment and provides emergency accommodation, support groups and advice on housing issues and offers training on homelessness to organisations working with young people.
A project to set up an office for this new charity offering accommodation and work for homeless people in Rugby, Warwickshire.
A project to train new staff and provide basic household items for this charity which helps homeless lone parents in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire.
column17: The Stoke On Trent And District Gingerbread Centre Limited

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group assist homeless young people in Fife by offering advice, information and support accommodation. The grant will pay for laptops, volunteer expenses, publicity material, training events and sessional staff.

This project will support homeless families and families vulnerably housed and facing homeslessness. The aim is to help them resettle and sustain their tenancies, whilst providing complementary support and sign-posting to specialist agencies to deal with associated issues, including drug/alcohol abuse, domestic violence, anti-social behaviour and lack of parenting skills.

This is an application to maintain an existing project in Leyland. It offers support to homeless or vulnerably housed people aged 16-25 who are at a critical point in their lives. The project will offer general support through a drop in, where the young people can have something to eat, use the centre's laundry or washing facilities and collect their mail. The young people are offered training which will help them to meet their responsibilities as a tenant, and will help them to remain in their housing.

column2: A Way Out - At Risk Women and Youth OUTreach
column3: This continuation of an existing project aims to reduce substance misuse and improve mental, emotional and physical well-being in women and young people in Stockton-on-Tees. It will target those who are hard to reach such as homeless, people in pockets of deprivation and children excluded from school. It will provide a link to existing formal services such as counselling and rehabilitation.

This is a project to install and furnish a log cabin in the hostel grounds. This will provide an area for the group to deliver activities for homeless people which will improve their confidence and skills. Funding incls Log cabin, labour hire and materials, and CCTV installation and full cost recovery.
The group will renovate the church providing a multi-purpose area for sports and recreational activities benefitting the homeless and vulnerable men and women who access the services.

The group are a Health and Social Care Trust based in Craigavon Area Hospital. The project will create an accredited life skills programme for young people who are either homeless or require support to maintain permanent accomodation.
column17: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

column3: This is a project by a charity in Brent. The group will use the funding to run outreach work to support migrant workers who are unable to speak English to seek training and employment opportunities.

Funded through Support and Connect this organisation aims to provide a free money management advice service to individuals who are homeless and have complex needs such as significant mental health difficulties, drug/alcohol addictions or physical disabilities. The project will also address housing needs, benefit maximisation, budgeting and strengthening links to other organisations such as credit unions within Ayrshire.

Funded through Support and Connect this group will increase its capacity to support homeless people who are offered a tenancy but lack sufficient funds to purchase the small household items required to set up and maintain a home. The organisation will work in partnership with a range of organisations which refer clients including housing associations and Women's Aid.

Funded through Support and Connect this group will provide starter packs and household goods to people moving out of homelessness and into their own tenancies. It will also offer financial awareness classes offering budgeting advice, as well as cookery classes incorporating nutritional advice and access to an allotment garden which will be created as part of the project.

An expansion of the current service by Shelter Housing Aid and Research (Leicester) (SHARP) which aims to reduce the number of individuals and families becoming homeless, by providing the support and advice they require. It will reduce the economic and social isolation caused by deprivation, lack of opportunities and support networks, poor education and family pressures.

The aim of this continuation and expansion project is to help homeless people and those at risk of homelessness, aged 18 and above in the Harlow, Essex area, to improve their physical and mental health by accessing suitable long term accommodation, training and development to improve their life skills, so that once they have a home they are able to keep it.
column75: Little Parndon and Hare Street Ward

column3: This expansion of an existing project will provide life and skills training for homeless people in Southend and Westcliff, enabling them to live independently within the community. In addition to the current shelter and meals for rough sleepers, the organisation aim to break down isolation and build beneficiaries' self-confidence by terminating the cycle of homelessness. Services will include life skills training such as budgeting and cooking and a volunteer training programme.

Chelmsford CHESS run a day centre for the homeless and provide short and long-term accommodation for people with housing and other issues. The project will enable the group to provide a number of interactive discussion groups where participants can explore the issues surrounding their homelessness and other contributing factors. These discussions will provide the group with more detailed information which will lead to the provision of more focussed services and advice to meet the specific needs of clients.

column2: Tenancy Starter Kits and Identity Building Project.
column3: This housing charity will use a grant to provide tenancy packs, allowing homeless people to set up a home of their own through the provision of basic household items. The project will also help them obtain documents enabling them to access amenities such as bank accounts.

This organisation assists community groups and individuals with arts-related projects, providing advice, guidance and project management. They will use an award to work with the West Lancashire Crisis Centre to deliver a project for young homeless people. The young people will create a piece a mosaic for the communal garden at the centre, working with professional artists to develop the artwork.

column2: Homelessness amongst East European migrants in Wales
column3: Since 2004, increasing numbers of East European migrant workers and their families have become eligible for statutory homelessness and housing support. However, there is limited understanding of homeless experiences amongst this population group and the extent to which services are being accessed. Shelter Cymru seeks to investigate homelessness amongst East European migrants and their families in Wales.

column2: Emmaus Burnley - Office set up (including Trustee & Volunteer development)
column3: This charity will use funding to equip and furnish an office for the group to operate from. The group are aiming to provide residential and recreational accommodation for homeless people together with a cafe, workshop and 'drop-in'.
This project will conduct research and create a DVD to allow people of all ages to better understand and educate on the issue of homelessness.

column2: Bury Lodge Day Centre for Homeless People
column3: This project in Hemel Hempstead provides a day centre for homeless people. The centre will go from opening only three afternoons weekly to opening five days a week, providing activities such as training, building relationships, one-to-one resettlement work, individual action plans and activities improving health, self-esteem and social skills. It also provides basic needs such as daytime shelter, hot meals, drinks, essential clothing, showers, laundry facilities, food parcels and sleeping bags.

This group trains volunteers to provide a listening ear, practical help and support to people on the streets and in bars throughout Friday and Saturday nights.
