The project will train additional volunteers to further support the scheme and aid development of the project. Local residents will have the opportunity to build relationships with Street Pastor volunteers, who can offer caring assistance, aid for homeless people, and signpost community members to beneficial services.

This community group works with young people in Oxfordshire aged 16 to 25, who are either homeless or in danger of becoming homeless. They will use an award to run a series of activities and workshops where young people will get the chance to grow fresh food and learn about the benefits of healthy eating.
column17: BYHP (Supporting Young People In Housing Need)

column3: This training and support company for homeless and troubled individuals will use an award to pilot a project that will deliver a series of ten Drink Aware presentations to schoolchildren. The sessions will be presented by homeless people who will aslo use the training received as part of their re-intergration in to society.

The association, based in Greenock, will pilot Fab Pad, a tenancy sustainment programme for its tenants who are at risk of homelessness. Participants will attend weekly interior design workshops to design and decorate their homes, providing them with new skills, stability and a comfortable home that they can be proud of and settle in. This grant will fund venue hire, staff costs for individual consultations, group work session costs for 31 weeks and programme materials.

This is a project by a charity in north Dorset. They will use funding to provide young people not in education, employment or training with transferable skills through vocational courses. This will enable beneficiaries who are homeless, or at risk of being homeless, to increase their employment opportunities.

This is a project by a community group in Nottingham. The group will use funding to purchase new recreational and educational equipment for their youth facility for young people who are homeless or live in hostels. This will allow the group to provide an increased range of recreational and social activities to young people from disadvantaged backgrounds.

column2: City of sunderland YMCA Foyer Volunteer Project
column3: This voluntary organisation in Sunderland will use funding to organise a volunteer project where members of the local community will work with users of the organisations services. This will support volunteer experience and help homeless people.
column17: The City of Sunderland Young Mens Christian Association

column3: This is a project by a voluntary group in Sheffield. The group will use the funding to provide and record interview sessions for a project which will help homeless young people who don't have older role models in their lives. They will be able to meet and begin positive relationships with older people which will encourage and support both generations to work together to benefit their local community.

This is a project by a company and charity in Blackpool. The group will use funding to provide art and media workshops, benefiting disadvantaged and homeless young people. This will help build the self esteem and aspirations of participants.

Young Devon 'Dreamcatchers' projects will benefit young people leaving care across Devon. It will provide mentoring and befriending through intensive one to one sessions and a peer-led befriending scheme. It will also offer a guidance service, counselling, advocacy and information, welfare rights, homelessness prevention, and health and careers advice. It will also include careers guidance through vocational mentors and work placements.

This project will provide support to improve the lives of sexually abused children and their families to negate the long-term consequences of abuse which often involves eating disorders, homelessness, drug addiction or prostitution. The project will provide training, counselling and support for children and their family, couples counselling for parents in extreme stress, massage sessions for parents and children to help re-establish bonds, therapeutic support groups and child-centred play therapy sessions.

This community organisation in Merseyside will use funding to set up an allotment. This will enable the group to give homeless people the opportunity to gain qualifications in horticulture and increase opportunities of employment and encourage social engagement.

This project will upgrade the kitchen facilities of its Day Centre by purchasing a variety of modern, fit for purpose kitchen equipment. The project will benefit staff, volunteers and homeless people, by providing a safer and more hygienic environment in which to prepare food. The grant will be used to buy a variety of large commercial kitchen equipment.

This group provides advice and support to people who are homeless in the Kent area. They will use funding to set up a resource centre. The centre will provide information, advice, training and volunteering opportunities.

This support group will use funding to conduct a Gap Analysis project. This will enable the group to establish the needs of local homeless people and highlight gaps in service provision that need to be urgently addressed. This project will also involve local community organisations, including the police, mental health services and district councils.

GISDA Cyfyngedig will work with their members to create an educational performance which will travel around schools and colleges in Gwynedd providing advice and support to young people on a range of issues. This project meets the Awards for All aim of supporting community activity. The grant for £4,998 will fund sessional worker, transport costs, venue hire and childcare.

This is a project by a community organisation in Hammersmith and Fulham. The group will use funding to run an anti-bullying campaign and support service for homeless people who often face bullying on a daily basis. This will provide beneficiaries with a place to turn to for advice, support and a reporting system to help identify perpetrators.

This is a project by a community organisation in Truro, Cornwall. The group will use the funding to celebrate their 25th Anniversary working with homeless people across the county by producing a documentary film and book to record past events and holding a launch event. This will raise awareness of the charity's work for homeless people and enable clients to share their feelings.

This charity based in Liverpool will use funding to provide opportunities to learn about horticulture and healthy eating and to socialise, for the benefit of homeless people in the area. This will provide accessible training opportunities for homeless people and enable them to gain stronger social networks and practical life skills.

This project will support adults that are either homeless or at risk of becoming homeless. The project will run drop sessions which offers hot meals, shower, clothes washing and drying. It will also run a skills cafe that provides training in basic skills and life skills, including numeracy, IT, healthy eating, hygiene, a mentoring and befriending service and housing advice. The project will also establish two social enterprises in partnership with a local eco-business and a local organic gardening project.

column2: Cedar House - young women escaping homelessness
column3: Cedar Housing Nottingham (CHN) continue its provision of support to homeless young women in South Nottinghamshire. Offering supported accommodation and one-to-one support, the group receives referrals from a range of agencies such as local housing departments, youth offending teams and Connexions.

This is a project by a registered charity in Hemel Hempstead. The group will use the funding to provide two structured activity weekends for 20 people striving to break the cycle of homelessness. This will enable the participants to be challenged, build up trust of others and improve communication and the ability to work together effectively.

column2: Mediation for young people at risk of homelessness
column3: This is a project by a voluntary organisation in Kent.  The organisation will use the funding to provide mediation to families where the children are at risk of leaving the household and becoming homeless.

The "Switched On" project is a new project that will deliver a range of personal development programmes and basic skills training through informal learning programmes/ courses and one to one/ group support sessions. The target beneficiaries are BME communities, people who are homeless, travellers or newly arrived. The courses will be delivered in three deprived inner city wards of Cardiff and from two wards in Newport.

This expansion and continuation of an existing project will provide an independent housing advice and support service to people 16 years and above in Corby. The project aims to tackle disadvantage, homelessness, discrimination, illegal eviction, mental ill health and domestic abuse for private and social tenants facing significant housing related problems.

column2: Central Manchester Women's Aid Outreach Project
column3: This project is working to reduce the number of women who may become homeless as a result of domestic violence in Manchester. It provides women with alternatives to going into emergency accommodation by offering confidential, sensitive and non-judgemental support, advice and information services for women. This will include advocating on women's behalf, giving advice on how to obtain relevant legal orders and signposting with additional support.

column2: Training and Employment Opportunties for the Long Term Unemployed.
column3: Alloa Community Enterprises Ltd's idea is to expand their current recycling project to provide training and employment opportunities for Clackmannanshire's most marginalised individuals, many of which have additional support needs. In addition, beneficiaries on low incomes, or individuals making the transition from homelessness into accommodation, will be supplied with high quality items of furniture which they will be able to shop for themselves. The grant will fund consultancy fees.

This group runs community concerts and music workshops. They will run a music project with homeless adults and those using local Mind drop in centres. Participants will attend a performance of music from different cultures, followed by a 6 week programme to include museum tours, discussion groups and creative writing workshops on the theme of different cultures. The project will culminate in a filmed final performance to be shown at a local museum, and feature on their website.
A project by this photography group from Victoria to work with homeless people to teach them how to use cameras, set the cameras up as well set up lights and tripods.

This group will recruit the skills of a social franchising expert, along with legal advice to enable them to establish a delivery network across Scotland for the successful 'Fab Pad' model. They want to adapt 'Fab Pad' to become a social franchise model and therefore have a much wider impact on homelessness in Scotland. The grant will fund travel costs, legal advice, social franchise expert fees, research fees and two pilot events.

column2: Safer Sexual Health Choices for Homeless Young People
column3: This project will provide sexual health information and guidance to young homeless people. The project will be based in the offices of Centrepoint and deliver a sexual health module on the Independent Living Skills qualification.  Young homeless people have a significantly higher chance of contracting a sexually transmitted infection, are less likely to access care through statutory services and are not sufficiently educated in sexual health. The project will address these needs through direct training.

column2: Foyle Haven Safe from Harm Project
column3: The grant will be used to develop the Foyle Haven Safe From Harm project, which if successful at stage two, would provide premises and support services for street drinkers and the homeless in a bid to improve their safety and well-being.The project would provide a safe place for drinkers to be, rather than on the streets, as well as laundry, shower and sleeping facilities. It would deliver programmes such as personal hygiene, anger management, healthy eating including nutrition and chronic alcohol abuse.

column2: Challenging Definitions - Bridging the Gap to Employment
column3: This project will support and encourage homeless people in Reading back into education, training or employment. The project will employ an education, training and employment co-ordinator to develop and implement a targeted programme of activities for each beneficiary. The individual pathway plan will start with basic skills such as literacy and numeracy, progressing to CV writing to help identify job suitability and key competences, followed by job search skills including interview skills.

Lamont Farm is a city-farm in Erskine that cares for sick and homeless animals, and provides young people with the opportunity to learn about the health, welfare and care of a variety of creatures. The group intend to run Animal Care Workshops for children aged 8-16. They grant will fund sessional workers, education materials, marketing, publicity and room hire.

column2: The Role of Housing Support Services in Building Positive Social Networks
column3: The Rock Trust will lead this project, based in Scotland, and partner with Strathclyde University. The research will look at the role of housing support services in enabling individuals who haveexperienced or are at risk of homelessness to build positive social networks. It aims tohelp prevent homelessness, reduce isolation, increase personal independence from supportservices and increase community and family relationships.

This project based in Derby delivers both direct legal advice services and strategic development, including campaigning on housing policy and practice issues and establishing new legal precedents to protect vulnerable people.It will provide specialist and targeted legal advice services and representation in housing, debt and welfare benefits for people ineligible for legal aid and vulnerable to being homeless.

The project is to engage homeless people from Swansea and Bridgend in activities that increase their independence, self esteem and engagement within the community and raise their confidence and skills with the aim of enabling them to enter into learning and possible employment.

column2: RECESSION - Shelter Cymru's Community Email Advice Service
column3: The project will offer a bilingual email advice service on housing, homelessness and housing-related debt matters and will accompany a new web-based bilingual advice information resource that was launched in October 2009. The service will particularly target homeowners in mortgage arrears and those who may experience greater difficulty in accessing face-to-face advice due to their hours of employment.

This new project, based in Worksop, aims to develop a central resource to provide essential furnishings, household goods, food parcels and clothing to homeless people in the community who live outside of mainstream society. It will also provide training and volunteering opportunities.

This project is an expansion and continuation of the Breadline Centre. The Breadline Centre is a resource centre for homeless people in Penzance. Refurbishment of the kitchen in the Breadline Centre will enable Saint Petroc's Society Limited to expand the services on offer to include training and work experience, and improve the café services offered.

This new project based in Brighton will set up an intensive training and employment project to give homeless and insecurely housed men and women the confidence, skills and training they need to help them to secure paid employment and achieve independent living.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column3: This group will use funding to put on an arts project involving making two large processional sculptures of Saint George and the Dragon. This will build a stronger community through engaging with homeless people, diverting them from anti-social behaviour and reducing feelings of exclusion.

This is a new project that aims to give support to households in Westminster who are potentially threatened with homelessness as a result of the Housing Benefits (HB) changes. The project will provide advice and information services to those affected by the HB changes to secure sustainable tenancies either locally or elsewhere, source appropriate school places for those with school aged children having to move schools.
The project is to provide care, support and move-on accommodation for homeless families and address their needs through education and life skills to become independent.

This organisation will use an award to make better facilities and resources available for young homeless service user groups. It will deliver both formal and informal workshops for young people between the ages of 16 and 25 to help them to realise their skills and abilities and increase access to other services and social networking.

This group will work in partnership with a range of agencies and employers to engage homeless people, deliver  training towards various occupations and provide ongoing support. With the aim of supporting homeless people  into sustainable employment or education. It will directly benefit 336 individuals and 20 organisations. This three year award will fund salary costs, tutors fees, beneficiary costs and project running costs.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: The organisation will carry out a feasibility study on the building it runs, which offers homeless young people in Glenrothes and the surrounding areas temporary accommodation. The group want to undertake major refurbishment work on its accommodation facilities and also build a new three-storey building on adjacent ground. A feasibility study will enable the organisation to assess how to proceed with this refurbishment and building work. The grant will be used to pay for a feasibility study.

This organisation will use an award to start up a window cleaning social business which will employ homeless people in the local area. The project will provide new opportunities for homeless people which will improve their long term employment prospects and their prospects of gaining permanent accommodation.

A project to provide advice, information and support to young people in crisis in the Goole area. Their needs will range from being homeless, threatened with homelessness, drug misuse, self-harming issues, social isolation, family/relationship breakdowns and domestic violence.

This charity provides emergency housing and support for young homeless people. They will use an award to provide training and basic financial advice to homeless people in order to help them make the transition into employment, further education or independent living.

This project, based in Liverpool, will improve independence for homeless people. The project provides learning, training and education to people to enable, empower and equip them through their journey from rough sleeping to re-entry to mainstream community living, education or employment.The project will provide training in life skills (including budgeting and food preparation), working effectively with people experiencing homelessness, harm reduction, boundaries, anger management and holistic therapies.

This pilot project will develop the self esteem, confidence and life skills of homeless people with a substance misuse addiction. The project will provide intensive support from project workers and peer support workers to the target groups a third of whom are under 25. The skills provided will include budgeting, financial planning, cooking on a budget, tenancy maintenance and addiction management. The grant will be used to pay for salaries, beneficiary costs, external evaluation and overheads.

This project will improve the confidence, knowledge, social networks, behaviours and life skills of young people aged 14 to 25 years who are leaving local authority care or are experiencing homelessness. The project will work closely with key agencies to provide a one-to-one support, outreach and advisory service to vulnerable young people. This grant will fund salaries, recruitment costs, professional fees, rent, rates, staff training, marketing, two smart cars, three laptops and associated running costs.

This is a project by a community organisation in Camden. The group will use the funding to run a music and video production project involving homeless and vulnerable people. This will provide an opportunity for the benficiaires to learn new skills and also improve self confidence and social skills.

The project aims to ensure older people facing homelessness are enabled to remain in their homes or are assisted into alternative, sustainable homes. The project will deliver social welfare (housing, debt and welfare benefits) advice, advocacy and support service to people over 50 at risk of homelessness or experiencing poor housing conditions and/or poverty. The service will offer support and practical assistance and also focus on underlying factors that may leave an older person vulnerable to repeat risk.

This project will provide advice and support to help lift young people out of homelessness in Warwickshire through helping them stay in education, access training and volunteering opportunities, access employment and participate positively to local community life. The project will provide weekly advice drop in sessions as well as workshops on shopping/living on a budget, tenancy agreements, practical responsibilities of living independently. A young people's peer support group will be set up.

This is a continuation and expansion of an existing project providing day services to marginalised, homeless and extremely isolated people in Ipswich. The centre provides a vital and potentially lifesaving service to Suffolk's most vulnerable adults. It is open every day and meets the immediate basic needs of clients including washing facilities and other practical support. The grant will provide funding for a range of staff posts.

This is a project by a community organisation in Salisbury, Wiltshire. The group will use the funding to purchase office furniture and IT equipment for their recently built community building. This will enable the group to provide community based training and support to people who often find it very difficult to access these types of activities due to being homeless, living with disabilities or being financially disadvantaged.

column2: Homelessness Project and Delivery of Sub-Regional Regeneration Strategy
column3: This is a project by a community group in Swindon. The group will use the funding to secure premises and purchase IT equipment for their employment and accommodation support and advice service.This will enable the group to more effectively support the needs of their beneficiaries, helping them to secure long term accommodation and access signposting regarding employment and training.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group in Alloa wish to establish a community centre which will provide a range of activities, primarily focussed on serving those who are homeless, disadvantaged or marginalised within the community.  The grant will enable the group to pay for professional support and legal requirements to take their project to construction phase.

column2: Wirral Churches Arc Drop In Project
column3: This charity based in the Wirral will use funding to purchase bikes and gardening tools for use by homeless people who use their drop-in centre. This will enable the group to expand their programme of positive activities and opportunities to aid the personal development of beneficiaries.
This church in Newcastle will use funding to improve the facilities in their parish meeting room. This will enable them to provide a drop-in centre for homeless and vulnerable local people.

This group in Liverpool will use funding to develop a programme offering training courses to service users. This will give homeless people the opportunity to gain qualifications in order to assist them with entering work and living independently.

This is a project by a community organisation in Coventry. The group will use the funding to provide a series of creative writing sessions for social excluded people (homeless people, those with mental health issues and refugees and migrants). This will feed into the beneficiaries general life skills such as co-operating with others whilst also improving their literacy skills. The beneficiaries will also be assisted to access other services that can help them with other issues.

column2: I.T for education, employment, and independent living
column3: This is a project by a charity in Nottingham. The group will use the funding to enhance the services currently available to their homeless clients and expand their reach to the community by providing access to computers and I.T. facilities. This will enable the beneficiaries to develop their I.T. literacy skills and access a range of information and advice to improve their future education and employment opportunities.

Build Brighter Futures will renovate a hostel for homeless people in Ealing, improving it for residents. The renovation will be used as a vehicle for young homeless people and those at risk of homelessness, to undertake accredited training in construction skills and receive mentoring during the renovation, so that they can potentially develop a career in the industry.

The Caffi Ni/Our Cafe project will open an informal cafe where homeless charity GISDA can provide young people with work experience, new skills, confidence and the motivation to lead successful independent lives. The cafe will be equipped to create light lunch and refreshments and younger people will receive accreditations for cooking skills, starting their own business, health and safety and food and hygiene. Outside agencies will visit the site and there will be open microphone sessions and bands.

The project will create a new centre in St Matthews Church Swansea to help 220 sex workers be better informed, safer, healthier and have exit routes from prostitution. It will work with 150 people with mental health issues and homelessness or substance misuse issues to increase confidence, reduce stress and live more safely. It will renovate the centre and connect it to the Cyrenians Community Centre. It will also provide funding for a Project Co-ordinator and support workers.

The group will deliver a support programme for people affected by issues including homelessness, unemployment and drug dependency, working in partnership with mainstream agencies to include social services, homelessness section of the local authority and Calderdale college. This will enable beneficiaries to access advice and information relevant to issues concerning them, with the aim of providing those living in severe poverty with the knowledge and confidence to come out of the poverty trap.

column2: CYP Advice, Information and Support Drop In
column3: The aim of this continuation and development project is to provide a drop in service for YP aged 11 to 25 in the Castle Point area of Canvey Island who need support with a range of issues including homelessness, unemployment, addiction, mental health problems and debt.

This is a new project based in Luton delivered by Luton Community Housing Limited (LCH) which aims to improve the mental health and access to mental health services for young homeless people by providing accessible Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) intervention. It will also seek to address problems such as substance abuse, anti social behaviour and self-damaging attitudes.

This project, based in Barnstable, North Devon, aims to improve quality of life for disengaged and vulnerable adults by providing accessible needs-led support allowing them to become better integrated into the general community. Homeless beneficiaries will be given one to one targeted support leading to individually tailored action and support plans. These will be used to contact external agencies and providers of appropriate safe and secure housing.

The continuation and expansion of a project by Broxtowe Youth Homelessness to prevent and mitigate the impact of youth homelessness in specific areas of Nottinghamshire and Derbyshire. 30 young homeless people will play a key role in leading on and delivering interactive workshops to year 10/11 students in local secondary schools in the five boroughs where they currently work.

This project will increase the rates of tenancy sustainment among recently rehoused homeless people through the provision of life skills, social networks and employability training, advice and information. The project will help 700 rehoused homeless people. The project will support previously homeless people to maintain their tenancy by focusing on improving employability skills and reducing social isolation as a long term solution to homelessness. This five year grant will fund staff salaries.
A project to set up a writing group for homeless and formerly homeless people throughout London to meet regularly and discuss each others' work as well as attending playwright sessions.

This project will allow Off The Street and Into Work (OSW) to develop an England wide regional network to provide infrastructure support to organisations working in the homeless sector. OSW will target regional infrastructure groups and local/regional employment, training and homelessness organisations. This project will give the VCSOs the planning and business skills to increase their sustainability.

This project will support Framework's management to induct and train volunteers and liaise with local partners and Nottingham CVS. The project will provide 176 volunteering opportunities each year for people who are homeless, disadvantaged, or have mental health issues in Nottinghamshire promoting the development of life skills, social networks and improved employability. Volunteering will involve gardening, decorating, food preparation, service support working, and befriending.

This project will be funded for two years to help 282 young people gain the skills and confidence to allow them to become more involved in the decision making processes which affect their lives. This project will allow young people to organise and deliver workshops, design their own information resources, develop their own campaigns and organise a conference to share and inform other young homeless people how to get their voices heard. The money will pay for the project salary costs..

This project helps people who are homeless and living in supported accomodation, or at risk of becoming homeless to get into education and employment in Bedfordshire. It offers courses in basic literacy, numeracy and IT skills, and advice on how to improve presentation and communication skills; build up personal confidence and motivation; develop interview skills; CV Writing; job searching, voluntary work or work based training programmes.

The project will enable a group of young people who are currently or at risk of becoming homeless to participate in social and leisure activities. The money is for citizenship workshops, travel costs, entrance fees and cost of activities.

The Nightstop programmes provide safe emergency accommodation for homeless young people aged 16 to 25, in the homes of approved volunteers. The project will develop 5 new schemes; provide advice & information to schemes; develop specific areas of support to schemes; enable schemes to deliver a broader range of services; provide training to schemes; a scheme mentoring project; involve young people & develop the sustainability of Depaul Nightstop UK.

This group will use an award to offer a range of activities to young homeless people. Activities will include fitness sessions, food and nutrition sessions as well as others to encourage young people into education, employment and training.

This project will see three Cornish reuse centres combining efforts to reduce the amount to waste going into landfills. It will also benefit homeless individuals, allowing them to move into permanent accommodation. Volunteers will service, test, clean and repair old furniture and appliances so that they can be delivered to low income or recently homeless individuals to assist them in restarting or rebuilding their livelihoods.

Pembrokeshire Association of Voluntary Organisations (PAVS) will manage a diverse portfolio of 8 projects, over five years. Projects will work with geographical communities and communities of interest to explore innovative ways of engaging citizens in the process of designing and delivering local services. Target groups include carers, older people, people with learning disabilities, younger homeless people and those with sensory impairment.

column2: Who Are the Real Homeless People?
column3: This organisation will hold a programme for residents of their three supported accommodation services in Edinburgh where they will produce a short film focusing on their experiences of homelessness and how they became homeless.

This group will improve service-user participation in its activities by creating a comprehensive participation strategy, providing young people who are homeless with the opportunity to become more actively involved in developing its service.

This new five year project will improve the mental health of people from BME groups in crisis in Leeds. Many of the beneficiaries are at a crisis point due to homelessness, poverty or domestic violence. The project will reduce isolation, and provide those people with better access to community based mental health services. The project will also report a reduction in self harm and suicide attempts and reduce the level of people from BME backgrounds using other crisis and emergency services.

This  is a project by a new voluntary organisation in Washington. They will use the funding to provide start up costs including room hire, office equipment, volunteer and travel expenses. This will enable the organisation to deliver emergency food parcels, provide advice and support to disadvantaged members of the community including the homeless, those on low incomes and people waiting for benefits.

column2: Vision and Voices - For a Healthier, Happier Lifestyle
column3: Solas Cymru Ltd in Newport will provide a wide range of activities to engage and encourage people who have issues including homelessness, substance misuse, alcoholism and poor mental health. The project meets the Awards for All aim of 'extending access and participation'. This grant for £4,218 will fund 3 digital SLR cameras, memory cards, lighting kit, background kit, carry case, Photoshop software, games equipment, OCN materials, cost of outings and other materials.

column2: Chester le Street YMCA Volunteer Project
column3: The organisation will establish a programme of employability, healthy eating and independent living sessions delivered by community volunteers to homeless people aged 16-35 in Chester-le-Street, to include CV writing, interview skills, nutrition, cooking on a budget, money management and housekeeping skills. This will encourage local people to engage and work with the young people to promote healthy living, develop their life and employability skills and encourage reduced isolation and independent living.
column17: The City of Sunderland Young Mens Christian Association

column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Reading. The organisation will use the funding to purchase a transit van to enable them to maintain their leased properties for homeless people. This will replace their current unreliable van so that they can run an efficient service to their tenants.

This is a project by a community organisation in Plymouth, Bournemouth. The group will use the funding to deliver a basic cooking course and provide nutritional knowledge for homeless and vulnerable adults. This will enable the beneficiaries to gain life skills to support their health and wellbeing and learn to live independently.
column75: St. Peter and the Waterfront Ward

column3: This is an expansion of a project by The Bubble Theatre Company Limited (London Bubble) that aims to offer significant, lasting and material difference to the life-chances and choices of young people aged 16 to 21 years from Southwark who are NEET or at risk of being NEET. The young people targeted face a number of barriers to conventional routes to employment such as lack of confidence, social networks or communication skills and homelessness, poverty or family breakdown.

column2: The Cook & Eat Healthy Food project
column3: A project in Croydon to encourage young people in sheltered housing, families and homeless people to lead healthier lifestyles.  They will run weekly healthy cooking sessions and a weekend breakfast and lunch club, providing nutritional meals, whilst engaging people to learn how to cook healthy food.

Working with young ex-offenders, homeless people, older people and school children with behavioural difficulties, to create and install mosaics in the Waterloo area, enhancing railway tunnels, walkways and community buildings. Workshops would take place to discuss and select themes and imagery that reflect the lives and ideas of local people.

column2: Emmaus Burnley - Building a Community of Support, Involvement and Opportuni
column3: This project will provide residential support for up to 36 homeless people living in East Lancashire at any one time.Residents will live and work as a community sharing tasks and problems. Additionally, six self contained 'move on' flats will also be available so that the transition from living as part of the community to living fully independently can be managed gradually. The project aims to support homeless people in independent living with opportunities to access training and employment.

A project by this Stroud charity to increase the number of local groups running creative events at the community hall by the provision of lighting and sound system and new folding chairs. This will help the integration of young disadvantaged and homeless people who will use the new facilites to present their performances and exhibitions.

This group provides supported accommodation for homeless young mothers, fostering and adoption services. They will use an award to create an outdoor play area that is appropriate for children aged 0-3 and young mothers. This project will allow homeless young mothers an area to interact and play with their children.

This is a project by a charity in Willenhall. The group will use the funding to employ a sessional worker to enable the group to extend it's services. This will enable the group to provide more services to disadvantaged and homeless people such as reading courses and life skills classes.

This project works with male prisoners at Nottingham Prison and ex-prisoners in Nottinghamshire  to help reduce their risk of homelessness and risk of repeat offending. An offender support officer will provide one to one support to prisoners leading up to their release, providing information and advice on housing, and agreeing personal plans that will help prisoners to set goals and track progress towards them. After release continuing tenancy support is provided.

This project in Sheffield works towards breaking the cycle of homelessness by making a transformational change in people's lives, helping them move from dependency to self-reliance and return to independent living. The project is based in a former cutlery factory in central Sheffield, which has been refurbished to create a live-in community for homeless men and women. The community offers support, training and meaningful work in an on-site social enterprise.

This project provides an accessible health outreach service in Brighton to help homeless and vulnerably housed people to improve their health and access to health services.  A team of staff and volunteers, including nurses and podiatrists, provide: drop in health clinics where beneficiaries can access nursing services, such as wound care, advice and treatment for skin disorders, drug and alcohol advice,  and monitoring of ongoing chronic conditions such as diabetes.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove

column3: This is a project by a voluntary organisation in Merseyside. The group will use the funding to develop a community garden and allotment. This will provide training and recreational activities for homeless people in the area. The award includes funding for sessional staff, garden tools, materials and publicity.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in St Helens. The group will use the funding to develop a choir to engage people affected by homelessness, as well as delivering craft and photography sessions for people suffering from mental health issues. This will improve the emotional well-being of participants, reduce stress levels and contribute to positive mental health.
art360 Hereford Limited in Bromyard, Herefordshire, will provide art workshops for young homeless people,culminating in a public exhibition of the work.

This is a project by a charity in Exeter. The group will use the funding to provide a resource pack to landlords in order to attract them to the group's Smartmove programme, a deposit guarantee scheme to allow people on low incomes to access privately rented accommodation. This will increase access to accommodation for people who are homeless or on low income.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Colchester. The organisation will use the funding to deliver cookery sessions and themed evenings focused on preparing food and taking part in educational activities such as world cuisine and job skills. This will give people who are preparing for independence following homelessness opportunities to learn cookery skills and take part in discussions and advice to help them find employment.

This is a continuation and expansion of a mediation service which aims to reduce youth homelessness in Burton on Trent. The project works with health, social, voluntary and community agencies who refer young people who have reached crisis point. Sessions involving family members and the young person will help to resolve conflict situations so the young person can return or stay at home, move in with other family or friends, plan a move to alternative accommodation, or be supported in living independently.
column17: Burton Upon Trent and District YMCA

column3: Medrwn Mon will deliver a portfolio of 10 projects over 4 years to encourage older people, young people, people with disabilities, homeless people, disadvantaged and under-represented groups and communities to develop skills and confidence to enable them to engage with service providers and participate in the planning and delivery of services in Ynys Mon. The development grant of £25,000 over 8 months will pay for the salary of a Portfolio Development Officer, to develop the stage two application.
column73: Sir Ynys Mon - Isle of Anglesey

column2: Education, Training, Employment for Homeless People
column3: The expansion of an existing project will allow Lauchpad Reading to improve their current basic skills training package delivered to homeless people living in Launchpad's supported accommodation. The group will develop an increased focus on clients who need intensive basic skills, literacy and numeracy support as well as delivering much of the training in-house. The work will be a combination of one-to-one courses, lessons and larger group work sessions.

The aim of this new project led by Shelter is to provide specialist advice to those with the greatest need, build resillience and quality within the advice sector and develop new methods to expand advice services.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column2: 'Inspiring People': Celebrating homeless street paper vendors
column3: The foundation will use the grant to hold the first ever Vendor Week in Glasgow in February 2013 to celebrate street paper vendors across Scotland.

This existing project aims to support people needing housing who have mental health and substance misuse problems to access appropriate services and accommodation. After an assessment, participants are offered a minimum 12-week support programme to link them to appropriate services and provide education around substance misuse. Advice and support will be given regarding housing options and advocacy between mental health services, housing departments and service users with high needs will be provided.

This is a new project by Providence Row to improve the lives of homeless people in the target London areas through personal development, training, volunteering and community action. PR aims to tackle the root causes of homelessness, not just immediate needs, with its role being to enable a transition by this very excluded group into mainstream employment, activities and community based support.

This project will provide an outreach, support and advice service for over 50s in Edinburgh who are homeless, or in inappropriate accommodation and at risk of becoming homeless. Working in partnership with other agencies, the project will arrange accommodation in crisis situations, provide advice, and signpost beneficiaries to other support services. This three-year grant will fund the salaries of two full-time project workers, project overheads, and two PCs.

column2: Safety and Security for Vulnerable Families
column3: A project by this charity based in Stoke-on-Trent to replace and improve their CCTV system. The group provides supported accomodation for homeless lone parent families, many of whom have experienced domestic violence. The project will allow the group to provide a more safe and secure environment to protect the vulnerable families that they support.
column17: The Stoke On Trent And District Gingerbread Centre Limited

column3: This new project based in Stoke will work with people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness, ex-offenders and victims of domestic violence, and offer an outreach programme of support services with an emphasis on healthier lifestyles and changing behaviours in an informal learning environment. Activities, including cookery sessions, money management and crafts, will provide vulnerable beneficiaries with the skills to live independently, and work towards informal learning opportunities.

This charity offer homeless young people support, guidance and opportunities to gain skills to achieve sustained independence. The group will use an award to run a 10 week boxing training course which will help young homeless people to tackle issues such as healthy eating, fitness, isolation and budgeting. The course will also give participants the chance to earn Network Open College progression awards which improve life skills and increase opportunities sustained independent living.

A project by this Westminster charity to provide two positive parenting groups for refugee and homeless families run by an educational charity. Parents will learn in activities and group discussions, behavioural difficulties, child development and discipline, associated stress, healthy living, information and coping strategies, while promoting positive relationships.

This charity will use an award to set up a film group for users who are homeless or have been homeless. The project aims to make short films about the beneficiaries involved concerning their current situation, how they came to be homeless and how they have overcome these problems. The films will be made into a DVD and shown to a wider audience.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This company seeks to carry out a pilot project to build the confidence and self-esteem of people experiencing homelessness. This will be done through the provision of regular physical activity which will lead to individuals being more able to cope with transitions in their lives and to permanent housing. The grant will be used fund health training, physical activities, sports activities, training, transport, equipment, monitoring expenses, evaluation expenses and forum expenses.

This new project will recruit and train 60 volunteers aged 16 to 25 to run a project team and motivate their younger peers get positively involved in their community. YP will plan social events, anti-bullying and crime reduction initiatives as well as local, national and global campaigning and action on issues such as the environment, knife crime, homelessness, and understanding cultural differences. There are also plans to organise some large events such as a music festival.
column17: Tees Valley Young Men's Christian Association

column3: The Benjamin Foundation provides a diverse range of services and opportunities for children, young people and the homeless in Norfolk. They will use an award to develop an outdoor learning area for their Kidzone project which targets children between the ages of four and eleven. The project will improve the opportunities for children to play outside and create a gardening area to allow children to learn about healthy eating whilst growing their own fruit and vegetables.

This project will support people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness and who need to find an alternative to local authority or housing association accommodation. It will help 800 households to find, set up and maintain tenancies in the private rental sector. It will achieve this by providing landord liaison to increase people's opportunities of finding a suitable home. This five-year grant will partially fund salaries, volunteer expenses, staff training and office equipment.

This group offers shelter, food and clothing for those needing resettlement in the community. They will refurbish the outdated kitchen facilities at the Fyffe Centre, a direct access hostel for homeless adults. The new facilities will enable them to provide interactive cookery sessions and also provide guidance on nutrition, hygiene and budgeting.

The aim of the project is to continue and develop the provision of temporary emergency accommodation and supported lodgings in volunteer's homes, and advice and support, for homeless young people aged 25 and below in Teesside.

column2: Gloucestershire Peer Education and Support Project
column3: This project will prevent homelessness amongst young people in Gloucestershire by providing support and advice to those who are at immediate risk of becoming homeless. Formerly homeless young people aged between 18 and 25 are trained as peer educators, delivering education sessions to young people in secondary schools, colleges, youth clubs, pupil referral units and youth offending teams.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This continuation of an existing project will support vulnerable communities in Liverpool. Beneficiaries, suffering from a range of disadvantages such as poverty, isolation, poor health, social exclusion, language barriers, homelessness and unemployment will be able to access a varied range of support options from the Gateway Centre. Provision will include access to training in general work skills, education and employment as well as information and advocacy on financial, physical and mental health issues.

column2: Bridge View Information and Advice Centre
column3: This project will build on work at the Bridge View Information and Advice Centre. The centre provides support for the whole community but particularly for people who are homeless, have mental health issues or drug / alcohol addictions. The centre will increase their range of services, introduce sessions on cookery and budgeting skills, develop the personal development programme and a 'pathways to employment' project to provide assistance with interview techniques, CV writing and volunteering placements.

The project will improve communication and develop the skills and confidence of vulnerable young people through the provision of an alternative educational programme which will equip the young people with necessary skills to live independently. The project will also provide a mediation service which will improve family relationships and contribute to a reduction in homelessness.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group provides pre-school education for children aged between two and five. The nursery building also hosts Greater Govan Mobile crèche which caters for children from homeless and vulnerable families across Glasgow. This grant for will fund the supply and installation of a delta fitness trail.
The organisation, which represents a number of organisations who work with homeless people throughout Northern Ireland, will use the grant to offer courses and training for other organisations.

This is a project by a homeless people's accommodation provider in Essex. The group will use funding to refurbish its chapel kitchen area. This will provide a suitable venue for other community groups and conform with current Health and Safety regulations.
column17: King Edward The Sixth and The Reverend Joseph Prime Almshouse Charity

column3: The aim of this continuing project is to improve the health of homeless and vulnerable adults in Southampton by overcoming the financial and social barriers preventing them from participating in sports. Providing access to sports such as football, golf and kickboxing, it aims to reduce drug and alcohol use and other destructive behaviours while improving confidence through motivating activities in a supportive setting. Participants can also undertake volunteering opportunities and accredited qualifications.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Cambridge.  The organisation will use the funding to construct a pedal powered mobile display unit involving homeless beneficiaries and volunteers in its design and construction. This will provide a video booth, interactive display and reading/conversation area to help raise the awareness, causes and impact of homelessness to the community to help break down barriers and encourage understanding.
The group provides homelessness related services in Northern Ireland. The grant will be used to purchase equipment for a resource room enabling the project to deliver programmes for young parents.

This project will work with homeless or potentially homeless young people, aged 16 to 25, who may have experienced family breakdown, abuse, unemployment and substance misuse. Due to their experiences the young people often suffer from poor mental health and low self-esteem. The project will help the young people to find safe, affordable accommodation, and get involved in volunteering, training and employment opportunities.
column17: Doncaster Housing for Young People Ltd

column3: This is a project by a charity in Stoke on Trent, Staffordshire. The group will use the funding to develop a multimedia web-based communications platform, to optimise support for vulnerable adults who are homeless. This will enable the group to better meet the communication preferences of the beneficiaries, most of whom are under forty.
column17: The Stoke On Trent And District Gingerbread Centre Limited

column3: This is a project by a company limited by guarantee in Manchester.  The organisation will use the funding to deliver 12 afternoon and evening workshops focussed on improving literacy and IT skills, confidence building, and awareness of support services to women who are homeless or experiencing drug / alcohol dependency.  This will enhance the self esteem and confidence of the participants to address their problems constructively.

Young people who are homeless or facing homelessness in Southampton will receive support to explore their options.Services will include an accessible youth drop-in centre to deliver advice and resources including laundry, shower, housing advice, mediation with family or friends and partnerships with housing providers and statutory services.

column2: Emotional Intelligence and Personal Development Project
column3: The community company are based in Reading and work with homeless people in that area. The project will provide training for volunteers enabling them to provide a better service to users. Workshops will also be held for users on understanding emotional and behavioural difficulties.

This project supports homeless adults in Preston to improve their circumstances, life chances and health. It provides the first point of contact and first steps to help beneficiaries move from chaotic lifestyles into a more stable way of living. The project is run from a community café in Preston town centre, where a range of activities can be accessed including art workshops, IT training, volunteering opportunities, job seeking advice and social activities. Sports and exercise activities are also provided.

This project will give homeless young people and adults in hostel accommodation help in developing personal skills, forming connections with the community and moving towards creating an independent lifestyle. It will provide support for beneficiaries to go from benefit dependence to employment. During this transition, job placements will take place within a variety of BYMCA departments, including HOPE FM community radio station.

The project will allow the organisation to expand its current project collecting and distributing emergency food aid, so that it operates throughout Cardiff. The organisation will collect tinned and dried food items from members of the public, charities, churches and schools and then distribute them to project beneficiaries. Project beneficiaries will be individuals and families who have suffered a crisis such as changes or delays in benefits, debt and homelessness.

This project aims to meet a gap in the housing provision in Cheltenham for those who have drug and alcohol issues, a high proportion of whom are likely to be current or past offenders. This group is frequently difficult to house because of the complexity of their needs, which creates a cycle of offending and homelessness. Securing suitable accommodation is essential to the success of the efforts to breaks these patterns and to allow other issues to be addressed effectively.

This project will consolidate and formalise a volunteering scheme entitled the Volunteer Improvement Programme (VIP) at the Northampton Hope Centre. VIP will provide the opportunity for homeless people and those affected by housing issues, drugs, alcohol, poor mental health and long term unemployment to improve their wellbeing and employability; working to break the cycle of homelessness, unemployment and deprivation. It will do this by providing structured voluntary work opportunities and training.

This project provides immediate and sustainable support to the homeless. The project will provide housing and accommodation, support around life skills, financial management, mental health support, employment and training advice, family reconciliation and alcohol and substance misuse advice. Provision also includes a weekly soup kitchen, two drop in sessions each week where beneficiaries can access information, advice and guidance and twice weekly house visits.

This is a project by a voluntary group in Abingdon. The group will use the funding to provide mentoring support for young people. This will be a pilot project for young people needing basic skills but also facing other challenges of homelessness, mental health or drug and alcohol problems to gain personal development for future employment or further education.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group deliver a range of housing support services in order to support individuals at risk of homelessness to sustain their tenancies and to live independently. The group wish to establish a furniture recycling service which will provide a source of affordable quality furniture, as well as volunteering opportunities and training for local people. The grant will pay for the costs of a consultant to undertake a feasibility study and produce a business plan.

This project operates a day centre providing a care location for drug and alcohol users, the homeless and individuals experiencing mental health issues. The drop-in service includes basic onsite health treatment from a nurse, medical advice (including sexual health and harm reduction training), acupuncture, housing and benefits advice and support, a laundry service, provision of clothes, companionship and a comfortable place to spend time away from the streets.

This group will use funding to develop a website in order to promote their family and pre-emptive homelessness services. It will also provide facility for clients to book and schedule appointments at the centre. This will increase awareness and capacity of the group to reduce homelessness in the local community.
The Tower Hamlets community group will use funding to organise a series of workshops that will record the personal history of homeless people from a range of backgrounds.

RUSH House works with homeless young people, between the ages of 16 and 25 to help improve their chances of obtaining work, training and skills development. It will provide flexible, bespoke training to improve literacy and numeracy skills of homeless young people and issue based educational opportunities that help them to develop better coping strategies and skills within the wider community.

The aim of this new project is to empower and enable people whose lives have been affected by homelessness to overcome the barriers between them and education, training and employment through activities, opportunities, workshops and peer support. It also aims to help people to maintain sustainable housing, which is key to moving on with their lives, and also improve their literacy and numeracy skills and overall confidence. DENS will run regular surgeries and workshops to enhance skills such as budgeting.

This is a project by a charity and company limited by guarantee based in Aylesbury working in Slough, Buckinghamshire. The organisation will use the funding to deliver individual counselling and life skills training to groups of young people who are homeless and living temporarily in the YMCA, and vulnerable young people. This will enhance their resilience and develop their communication skills, confidence and self-esteem.

column2: Camden and Islington - CN Development Funding
column3: This is a project by Single Homeless Project (SHP), a charity and registered company based in London, serving the development of the Multiple and Complex Needs partnership in the Camden & Islington target area.

This new project aims to coordinate every aspect of a homeless person's journey from being street homeless to accessing settled accommodation. The two main categories of street homeless people in Lancaster, those new to rough sleeping and long term homeless people, will be supported appropriately in finding and keeping settled accommodation.
column17: Lancaster And District Homeless Action Service Limited

column3: The portfolio will deliver 9 projects over 4 years to encourage older people, young people, people with disabilities, homeless people, disadvantaged and under represented groups and communities to develop skills and confidence to enable them to engage with service providers and participate in the planning and delivery of services in Ynys Mon.
column73: Sir Ynys Mon - Isle of Anglesey

column2: Foodbank, befriending and signposting services for Rossendale
column3: This is a project by a voluntary organisation in Rossendale. The organisation will use the funding to provide volunteer training, remote IT access and food storage facilities and create a website and publicity towards providing a foodbank service. This will provide a much needed service and information on service providers for people struggling to feed themselves including people in ill health, homeless and on low incomes.

This is a project by a community organisation in Lewisham. The group will use the funding to run creative motivational workshops for young women who are homeless or living in sheltered accommodation. This will provide an opportunity for beneficiaries trying to integrate back into society to raise self esteem and improve life skills to seek training or employment.

This is a project by a charity in West Bromwich, West Midlands. The group will use the funding to deliver employability and life skills training sessions that will focus upon the needs of migrant homeless people at risk of engaging in antisocial behaviour. This will equip the beneficiaries taking part with skills that will enhance opportunities for gaining employment and improve their chances in life.

A new project for young homeless people in Swadlincote, South Derbyshire to develop the skills, knowledge and experience to live an independent life and make a positive transition into adulthood. Trident has 32 short-term accommodation units and provides tenancy support for people residing in them. In addition, they will now be able to provide comprehensive wellbeing support to challenge the disaffection and disengagement from mainstream society that many young homeless people experience.

column2: Journey on - Arts and Cultural Programme
column3: The trust will run a year long programme of arts, crafts and cultural sessions/activities. The programme will be aimed at local people who are suffering from issues such as mental health problems, homelessness, drug addiction, alcoholism and long term unemployment.

A project by this Birmingham group for user led research on services accessed by people including the homeless, substance misusers and people with poor mental health. Having merged within the last two years, the organisation wishes to review its services.

This is a continuation and expansion of an existing project in Coventry city centre by Abacus Counselling Services Ltd (Abacus) that aims to provide a counselling service to support the disadvantaged within the local community. This project targets unemployed individuals (reinforcing personal skills), ex-offenders (to re-integrate back into society), school pupils with problems such as disruptive behaviour and absenteeism (usually caused by a breakdown of the family unit) and the homeless.

This is a continuation of an existing project by Home-Start Tameside and Oldham (HSTO) to provide support to families across Tameside who have at least one child under the age of five and are experiencing stress such as through post natal depression, multiple births, disability and debt. In Tameside, there has been a dramatic increase in families affected by substantial debt, who are struggling to provide basics such as heating and food and without support would face eviction and homelessness.

column2: Wyre Forest Nightstop and Mediation Scheme
column3: This is the expansion of an existing project to help young homeless people in the Wyre Forest District. Housing advice, a mediation service, short term accommodation with a trained volunteer host and a drop-in centre will be available. Courses will be delivered at the drop-in centre to help teach young people to look after themselves, including cooking healthy meals, budgeting, CV writing and how to apply for a job. Volunteers will be trained as family mediators to help people return to the family home.
column17: Wyre Forest Nightstop And Mediation Scheme

column2: Move on through learning with BENS
column3: This is a project by a voluntary and community organisation in Braintree, Essex. The organisation will use the funding to expand their capacity to be able to deliver educational and training courses to people at their homeless shelter.

column2: Healthy Eating; Healthy Mind and Body
column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Bradford. The organisation will use funding to run healthy eating on a budget, food preparation and exercise sessions for homeless male adults recovering from substance misuse. This will enable beneficiaries to prepare and cook a healthy meal on a low income and encourage them to participate in physical activity, with the aim of improving their BMI and promoting wellbeing.
column17: St Anthonys Project for Homeless Addicts

column3: This is a continuation and expansion of a project which helps pregnant women from disadvantaged backgrounds to improve their lives and give their babies the best possible start in life. Many of the young women supported by the project find themselves homeless because they are fleeing domestic violence or as a result of a relationship breakdown within the family. The project offers one-to-one and group training in basic life skills including kitchen skills, parenting, health and budgeting.

column2: SPAN Scotland - Supporting Prisoners; Advice Network Scotland
column3: This project will aim to prevent homelessness amongst ex offenders and their families in Aberdeen, Perth and Inverness.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This is a project by a community organisation in Swadlincote, Derbyshire. The group will use the funding to create an IT area with new computers and furniture for young people who are or at risk of becoming homeless. This will improve the facilities to be able to provide IT skills development for beneficiaries.

This project aims to support children and young people to attain their legal rights and deal with issues. Subjects dealt with include homelessness, advocacy, preparation to leave care and broken contact with social workers. Support is provided by specialist advisors manning the National Children's Advocacy Helpline. It can resolve issues, offer advice and information during a call. The project will expand by introducing new techniques to better monitor long-term impact of the support provided.

This group in Bradford will develop an IT suite in one of their offices for 'move on' tenants to use. This will provide PC and internet access to men who have been homeless and enable them to apply for jobs and education opportunities.

This group will develop and run a horticultural project for young homeless people in Stornoway and the surrounding areas. The project will enable the beneficiaries to learn about gardening and growing organic food. They will be able to use the skills they aquire on the project to obtain future employment. The grant will fund the renovation of the workshop into a service horticultural area, administrative costs and supervisory support.

This project provides day support for homeless people in Waltham Forest. The HOPE project will offer a complete resettlement programme with the long-term aim of improving health, emotional well-being and confidence. It also aims to break the cycle of homelessness by supporting beneficiaries to find a permanent home. A multi-agency approach will address varied needs.The programme will be based at the Fountain Daycentre drop-in and will be delivered over three hours, five days a week.
column17: Fountain of Peace Ministries of the Cherubim and Seraphim Church

column2: Specialist Housing Advisor at HMP Camphill Prison
column3: This project based at HMP Camphill on the Isle of Wight, provides specialist housing advice to offenders with the aim of resolving housing problems, preventing homelessness and improving their overall health and welfare, while reducing re-offending. A specialist housing advisor will assist beneficiaries by resolving existing concerns relating to housing and accommodation. This will involve offering practical assistance with debt management, rent/mortgage arrears and eviction and repossession notices.
column17: Isle of Wight Law Centre Limited

column3: This is a project by a registered charity in St Albans. The group will use the funding to provide basic IT training to older people and people from a local homeless shelter. This will provide people with an opportunity to learn new skills.

This project will expand a craft workshop for homeless and marginalised adults with mental health problems so that more woodwork and craft classes can be run. The organisation would like to fit out a space with two new peices of laser cutting equipment, decorate, and make into a bright effective workspace. Items such as clocks for local football teams, etched glass, external signs, pottery and woodwork are made, helping people with learning disabilities learn skills.

column2: Emmaus Bolton - Purchase And Refurbishment of 'The Cottages'
column3: This project in Bolton will purchase and refurbish a building, the 'Cottages', and associated land for conversion into a halfway house/move-on accommodation to expand a furniture recycling social enterprise. The project is designed to provide a stable base and home environment for homeless people in order for them to take stock of their lives and be supported in finding employment in the wider community and move towards independent living.

This project in Worthing provides crisis intervention and advice, signposting to appropriate services, temporary accommodation and eventually permanent housing to adults experiencing or at risk of homelessness. Up to 30 people a day currently access the services. Other services include food, laundry and shower facilities, health services (needle exchange, sexual health and primary health) and specialist advice through four workers providing signposting services.

column2: Sail Project (supporting adults for independent life)
column3: The organisation, which provides accommodation, care and support for homeless people in the Mid-Ulster and South Tyrone area, will use the grant to buy equipment for their new premises and support the work of the Supporting Adults in Independent Living project.
column17: Mid Ulster & South Tyrone Association For The Single Homeless

column3: This is a project by a community organisation in Hackney. The group will use funding to offer IT training and internet services to unemployed and homeless people in the local area. This will offer beneficiaries a chance to interact with other people in similar situations and receive IT training to help them find employment.
column17: Open Doors Baptist Church Community Projects Limited

column3: The charity for homeless and vulnerable people will use the grant to fit out their premises with tables, chairs, electronics and storage space.

column2: Migrant Assistance Project - Drop in Centre
column3: The group, which works  with homeless people in Belfast, will use the grant to provide outreach, drop in, and on-call services. The project will also allow the organisation to expand its drop-in service's opening hours.
This project received development funding for a project that would provide counselling and support to people with a combination of mental health, substance misuse, homelessness and offending issues.

This project across the five London authorities of Greenwich, Bexley, Bromley, Southwark and Lewisham addresses the root causes and warning signs that lead to youth homelessness, with the aim of reducing the number of homeless young people. Peer educators will be used to educate and further inform what it is actually like to be homeless and in temporary accommodation. The educators will also advise on school sessions and training.

column2: Save the Family - Cotton Hall Farm
column3: This charity in Chester will use funding to produce a information leaflet that will be sent to the wider regional community. This will provide information on the new homeless shelter that the group are opening in 2011 and attract new volunteers to help with the rapid expansion of the group.

column2: Nottingham Homeless DVD Magazine - Pilot Project
column3: This is a project by a community group in Nottingham. The group will use funding to bring together homeless people to produce a series of short community films. This will improve their work and life skills to improve their chances of finding future employment.

This project will provide information, advice, advocacy, support and representation for young people throughout Gateshead - empowering them to tackle their problems and make informed choices. Issues tackled by caseworkers and small group sessions will include debt, homelessness, sexual health, domestic abuse and mental health. Direct advice and/or signposting to other services will be provided as appropriate.

This project uses food as a catalyst to help people who are homeless to move on with their lives. The project aims to inspire people in transition and propel them to better health, improved confidence and a career pathway. Activities will work with homeless people in hostels across London, using a participative 'cook school' model to help develop social skills such as communication and team working, as well as learning about healthy eating and low-cost cooking for independence.

column2: Isolation to Integration - Strengthening the Core
column3: This project in West Hampstead supports marginalised women through the provision of crisis intervention, education and healthy living activities. The daily drop in and crisis intervention service supports beneficiaries with issues including domestic violence, sexual abuse, rape, homelessness, harassment by neighbours and issues relating to mental and physical health. Beneficiaries can access information and advice by telephone or visit WHWC to obtain advice, advocacy or support.

This is a project by a charity in Hammersmith and Fulham. The group will use funding to equip a newly opened hostel for homeless people. This will build capacity for the group and enable the group to deliver new activities.

Norwich City Council will use a grant of £311,000 to work with homeless people and those in supported housing in the Greater Norwich area to help them into employment, education and training, as well as into accommodation in the private rental sector.

The project will support people with multiple barriers helping them move into volunteering, training, education or employment. The project will engage with clients mainly from the north and west of Glasgow who have serious mental health problems and chaotic lifestyles (including drug misuse, alcohol misuse and homelessness). The grant will fund salaries, organisation overheads, beneficiary costs and external training.

The project will create a Wales-wide street football network for homeless and/ or socially excluded people. It will build on the existing Swansea league, expanding this to cover West Wales and will develop new leagues in the South East, Valleys, North East and North West areas. The project will establish a system where the participants in the leagues will receive support with the issues they face and will be referred onto other support services.

This is a project by a charity in Haringey. The group will use funding to purchase IT equipment, run volunteer and staff training and receive an evaluation of their support and advocacy services, for the benefit of homeless families. This will expand the group's capacity, improve the efficiency and security of their IT systems, and enable them to reach more beneficiaries by addressing their cultural and language needs.
