SIFA Fireside Limited will help improve the health and well-being of homeless and vulnerably housed people in Birmingham who experience low life expectancy and long term physical and mental health issues. This scheme will help them to become more physically active, eat healthily on a budget, and improve their mental health and well-being through skills training, complementary therapies, physical activities, self care training and peer health support.

This continuation and expansion of a project will see Chester Aid to the Homeless deliver its range of support, learning and volunteering opportunities to homeless people in West Cheshire. Many of the service users have complex needs including mental health, alcohol and drug issues and face a range of barriers to accessing training and development to improve their life skills and chances.

This is a continuation and expansion of an existing project that uses football as a means to engage with and provide learning and support to hard to reach people such as homeless and vulnerably housed people, offenders, ex-offenders, those with mental ill health and ethnic minorities. It also offers activities to improve physical health and bespoke training with the long term aim of giving beneficiaries new life skills and helping them to facilitate independent living.

The group will use the funding to hold evening drop in sessions for homeless people in the area. This will ensure that homeless people have somewhere to go to receive a hot meal and any help and support needed to encourage a change of lifestyle.

This is a project by a charity in Nottingham serving beneficiaries in Erewash, Derbyshire. The group will use the funding to develop a website, promotional video and new outside access point for their service, which helps support homeless men. This will enable the beneficiaries to access a range of information and advice to improve their future accommodation, education and employment opportunities.

This charity in Rochdale will use funding to provide a programme of activities for disadvantaged community members including people with disabilities, sufferers of abuse and those who are homeless. The project will involve cooking on a budget, meal planning, hygiene awareness and debt management sessions in addition to day trips to local places of interest and a National Trust conservation residential.

This group will establish the Wheels in Motion project in Edinburgh which will assist vulnerable homeless adults in accessing resources from the organisations partnership service The Bruntsfield Clothes Line project.

column2: Mount Zion House Energy Efficient Project
column3: This is a community hub which provides a venue for local groups & supported housing accommodation for young people who are homeless, a registered domiciliary care agency providing personal & practical support to individuals in their own homes, a free & impartial advice centre (LIAISE),office space for voluntary & community partners. The grant will be used to install heating/zone/weather compensated controls including heating zones. A new boiler will be fitted boilers including a new heating system.

column2: One - off Food Drive to collect and distribute food packages to those
column3: The charity in Barnet serving beneficiaries in Barnet and Manchester will use the funding to collect and distribute food for homeless people, single parents and low income families. This will provide food for the most at risk in the community, raising awareness of the issues the beneficiaries face, and encourage voluntary work.

The project will build on the current Agor Drysau project to provide support for vulnerable young people, particularly addressing homelessnessby establishing drop-in centres in Caernarfon, Blaenau Ffestiniog and Pwllheli. They will provide a range of support and training to enable young people to improve their life chances and employability or develop their own business ideas leading to self-employment. The grant, over 3 years, will pay for staff costs plus expenses and running costs.

This project is a continuation and expansion of the existing support for homeless people in Worthing by Worthing Churches Homeless Projects (WCHP). It aims to reduce homelessness by providing services to help people rebuild their lives via personal solutions and interventions, building confidence in the beneficiaries so that they can seek further support and take control of their lives Most of the project activities will take place at St Clares Day Centre.

column2: Equipping Burton YMCA's rough sleeper base
column3: This charity in Burton upon Trent, Staffordshire will use the funding to equip their new homeless centre with furniture, equipment and CCTV. This will provide an improved and safe facility for beneficiaries.
column17: Burton Upon Trent and District YMCA

column3: This project by a community organisation in Birmingham will use the funding to start up an additional soup kitchen for local disadvantaged people, some of whom are homeless or hostel residents. The funding will enable the project to provide volunteering opportunities and one-to-one advice to service users.

This is a project by a charity in St Austell, Cornwall. The group will use the funding to fit out a charity shop that will provide work experience for volunteers who until recently were homeless. This will provide the beneficiaries with work based training and development that will improve their life skills and chances of finding employment.

This is a project by an Industrial and Provident organisation in Hampshire. The organisation will use funding to run nutrition and health workshops along with physical activity sessions for young homeless members of the community, culminating in a showcase event for all participants of the workshops. This will allow them to gain an understanding of the need to eat healthily and stay active to make positive lifestyle decisions to reduce isolation and low self esteem.

column2: Horses Helping People - The Neigh Team
column3: The grant will enable Horses Helping People to develop the care farm to include horse driving and harness work, with a trail and vegetable garden. Local volunteers, homeless and veterans will create and tend to the garden, create the track and train the horses. The aim is to enable people to learn new skills and team-working, helping with progression to paid work. The tranquillity of the natural environment and horses provide a sense of calm and wellbeing for the disadvantaged children and adults who visit.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: This group will create a new office space to expand the service offered to clients within the Rothesay area who face various issues such as mental health problems and homelessness. The grant is for starter packs (pots, pans, duvets etc), computer equipment, office furniture and volunteer expenses.
column17: The United Church of Bute Pass It On Project

column3: This project will deliver a range of training and volunteering services to disadvantaged young people in Darlington, many of them homeless. A combination of on-site and outreach activities will be delivered, including employment support, counselling, basic skills assessments and training. The group will also offer volunteering placements with local community groups, work placements with local employers and a flexible programme of team activities against a backdrop of supported study and mentoring.
column17: Tees Valley Young Men's Christian Association

column3: This is a project by a community group in Poole, Dorset. The group will use the funding to establish a scheme to support homeless people who have recently secured long-term accommodation. This will help recently housed people adjust to their new lifestyles, reduce the chances of them losing their accommodation, and provide a range of support and training to enable service users to fully re-integrate within their local community.

This project will develop the Bury Adult Education Service which offers training and educational packages for adults who are hard to reach in Bury. Currently targeting people with homelessness issues, this project will expand to include drug and alcohol users, people with mental health problems and ex-offenders; people whose learning needs are greater than provided for with current provision. This project will be offering training and support.

column2: Fresh Start Borders Start Up Project
column3: This group provide Starter Packs (new or used household items) to help people who are previously homeless and are about to take up a new tenancy. The grant is for two direct heating units, additional shelving, tables and chairs, PC, software & printer, lockable cupboard & filing shelves, portable display banners and stands, publicity, website design and stationery costs, storage containers and starter pack items.

column2: Group Relapse Prevention Courses for WCHP service users
column3: This is a project by a registered charity in Worthing. They will use the funding to develop and deliver a relapse prevention programme for beneficiaries with alcohol and substance misuse difficulties. This will help these beneficiaries to remain stable and improve their overall health.

This group will use funding to purchase new IT facilities and furniture for their residential home for teenage girls who are homeless, many of whom are pregnant. This will allow the group to develop its capacity to provide support and access to training to improve literacy, social and life skills that will enable them to live independently and re-integrate in the wider community.

column2: Huggard Training, Development and Enterprise Suite
column3: The project will provide a training, development and enterprise suite as part of a new one stop shop homelessness complex providing homeless people with the skills and confidence to move towards independent and sustainable lifestyles.

This group will use funding to provide activities for homeless people including sporting activities and training to improve health and career prospects. This will involve a two-day event with participants signposted to education, training, healthy eating and alcohol and drugs awareness. This will improve employment prospects and healthy lifestyles for homeless people in Merseyside.

column2: Hostels Outreach and Support through Theatre (HOST
column3: Through a series of performances and workshops this project uses theatre to reach out to homeless adults living in London hostels and day centres. As well as developing self-esteem and confidence, creative and social skills, participants will be provided with information and referred to relevant services.

Project: A new project in Brent, London to help enable isolated disadvantaged people with mental health issues to  become more independent. The scheme will increased access to mainstream services including training opportunities and personal and vocational development programmes, and provide outreach support at local centres such as libraries, mental health centres, homeless groups and Addaction.

This is the continuation of an existing project to provide a free, impartial short-term mediation service to under-16s and their families, with the aim of conflict resolution and prevention of family breakdown and homelessness of young people. The project currently serves seven areas in Hertfordshire (North Herts, Stevenage, Welwyn Hatfield, East Herts, Broxbourne, St Albans and Hertsmere) and will be expanded to serve the whole county.

column2: My Time Family Trauma Centre - My Dad Project
column3: The continuation project by My Time C.I.C delivers an early offer of support to families in Central and East Birmingham. A team of family therapists and multi-lingual volunteers will be trained in family trauma intervention to address issues such as depression and anxiety but also extreme poverty, homelessness, debt, unemployment, family breakdown and social exclusion. Volunteer father ambassadors will be trained to provide peer support and undertake workshops on positive parenting.

This is a project by a registered charity in Oxford. It will use the funding to purchase essential furniture and equipment for their new renovated premises offered to homeless people in Oxford. This will improve a community homeless drop in service by purchasing kitchen appliances and furniture in order to expand their facilities to accommodate more people.
column17: Homeless People and the Oxford Churches (Gatehouse)

column3: This community group in Stoke-On-Trent will use funding to provide counselling and mentoring services to homeless people with a range of health issues. This will improve the physical, emotional and social wellbeing of beneficiaries who are often isolated from mainstream support services as they have no fixed abode.

The grant will be used to run 'Champions for Change'.  The 3-year project will engage with 450 young people from across NI, aged 16-18, who are Not in Employment, Education or Training (NEET), and experience issues such as poor self-worth, low educational attainment, substance abuse, homelessness, anti-social and criminal behaviour, and mental health problems. It will be delivered in partnership with the Bytes Project & run in 16 areas, experiencing high socio-economic deprivation.

column2: Budget, Buy and Build for the Future
column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Richmond. The group will use funding to furnish eight new apartments, where homeless people will be given a budget to furnish it with essentials, including a bed, fridge and cooker. This will provide suitable accommodation for further homeless young people, and equip them will new budgeting skills, with the guidance of YMCA staff.

This Hampshire organisation will establish a bicycle workshop that will be run by people who are affected by homelessness. This will provide a community resource for bicycle repair, enabling beneficiaries to learn repair and maintenance skills and provide transport for homeless people to attend interviews or training.

This existing project will expand services already being delivered by Hexham Community Partnership (HCP)  in Hexham East. The house is used by community organisations to provide a range of activities, information and advice services including a credit union, breast feeding peer supporters, support for the homeless, a local charity helping women in abusive relationships, Job Centre Plus and Health Care Professionals. The expansion will increase the opening hours to Monday to Friday operating 10am to 4pm.

column2: CLEAR (City Life Education & Action for Refugees)
column3: This existing project in Southampton will enable marginalised groups of refugees, asylum seekers, new migrants and their families to access services, participate in and contribute to UK society. Southampton is a dispersal centre for refugees and asylum seekers, communities which have a greater prevalence of homelessness, poor housing, unemployment, debt, physical and mental ill health and racial abuse. The project offers ESOL courses, a weekly drop-in employment advice service and IT courses.

column2: The Pop-up Talent Shop: 'Mastering the Laws of Employability Gravity'
column3: The aim of the project is to take career-based training to disadvantaged young people in areas including estates, homeless centres, street corners and supermarkets. It will support them to overcome the barriers to employability and help unleash their talent and potential. Young people and businesses will deliver career-based skills training and mentoring from initial tasters to long-term skills training and work placements, making this a youth-owned enterprise.

column2: Job creation for ex-offenders in Bristol and the UK
column3: Bristol Together was established to create jobs & skills training for ex-offenders, homeless people and long-term unemployed people by purchasing, repairing & letting properties.  A £1million bond, raised with the support of Triodos bank, will fund the purchase and refurbishment of six properties, creating 40 construction jobs for ex-offenders in Bristol, during this one year project. An external evaluation on the effectiveness of this bond will be published on the web and shared through events.
This group provide support and care services to people who are homeless. The grant will fund 15 starter packs, 6 laptops and outing costs.

This is a project by a community organisation in Hackney, working across London. The group will use the funding to deliver workshops in information technology and literacy skills for homeless people. This will enable beneficiaries to acquire skills that will keep them up to date with the latest technology and improve their chances in life.

column2: Turning round the telescope;a community development approach to well being.
column3: The project will work with communities in Splott (Cardiff) and West Rhyl to trial a community development approach to develop their ability to shape the community services provided to meet their needs. The aim of the project is to empower beneficiaries which will in turn improve their wellbeing and to influence change and progress. The project will be of benefit to homeless people and people in crisis in Rhyl and 50+ people of working age in Splott. The project will benefit 120 people and 30 organisations.
column17: Community Development Cymru - Datblygu Cymunedol Cymru

column3: The project will provide specialist accommodation and support for  homeless young people, aged 16 to 25 years who have complex needs. Digartref Ynys Mon will work in partnership with specialist agencies to provide a package of support to maximise each young person's ability to sustain independent living and 1:1 intensive support to overcome issues impacting on their lives. The grant over three years will pay for the purchase and refurbishment of a building and contribute towards the staff costs.
column73: Sir Ynys Mon - Isle of Anglesey

column3: This is a project by a voluntary organisation in Littleover, Derbyshire. The group will use the funding to install solar panels in its community hub and deliver activities that will focus upon the developing the knowledge of energy and billing options for people who are or at risk of becoming homeless. This will improve the environment and energy sustainability for the group's building and raise awareness of the issues that people in the community are facing.

column2: 'Learn to Progress' at Crisis Skylight Merseyside
column3: This is a development and expansion of existing learning provision for single homeless and vulnerably housed people in Merseyside which will improve their life chances by equipping them with skills and confidence to progress into education, training or employment.

This Slough project aims to help homeless people to improve their self-esteem, develop new skills and access information to secure paid employment, in addition to traditional drop-in support such as hot meals, shower facilities and clean clothes. The project will also expand on providing support for people obtaining work experience, volunteering and employment opportunities, with courses available in subjects ranging from basic numeracy, literacy and IT to construction skills and gardening.

The project will provide supported emergency and temporary accommodation to 16-25 year olds In Gloucestershire. This will reduce homelessness and rough sleeping for vulnerable young people, as well as further improving welfare a through programme of life skill development opportunities.

This Kent charity will involve local residents and volunteers in redeveloping a derelict garden at a supported accommodation facility for homeless people. This will transform an unused piece of land into a wildlife garden that can be used for relaxation and skills training. Native planting, wildflower seeds, lawn, pond, trees, shrubs, materials, edging materials, repair to brick outbuilding, gardening tools, gloves, boots, compost bin, path decking, gate, training and volunteering days, tool hire.

This is a project by a charity in Bromsgrove, Worcestershire. The group will use the funding to set up a volunteer programme for young people who have experienced homelessness to help them develop life skills and self confidence. The project will also strengthen the organisation's capacity by increasing the range of services it can offer to its beneficiaries.

This charity in Leicester will use funding to create two nature gardens, one in the garden of a hostel for homeless men and one in an allotment run by a local secondary school, both of which will be monitored by webcams.  This will improve two urban environments to attract urban birds and provide an opportunity for two groups to work together to learn about nature.

column2: There is no project name available for this record
column3: The project based in West Lothian aims to provide better accommodation facilities to young homeless people between 16 and 25. The group plans to develop a new hostel or refurbish the existing building. The grant will fund a feasibility study on a new build hostel and a feasibility study on the refurbishment/redevelopment of the existing building.
column75: East Livingston and East Calder Ward

column3: Crisis UK will continue helping homeless and vulnerably housed people in Birmingham to access further education and employment opportunities. The project will provide activities with a holistic approach to help people reach their full potential. These will include informal, creative based workshops in drama, creative writing and cooking, accredited courses in basic numeracy, literacy and IT, and soft skills such as time management, communication skills, group work and team working.

This is a project by a charity in Northfield, Birmingham. The group will use the funding to run nutrition and physical fitness sports sessions with mentoring and personal development coaching for young people who are homeless. This will enable beneficiaries to learn about healthy eating, sexual health, the benefits of exercise and anger management to help improve their overall physical and mental wellbeing.

This project will create a community for those who experience a cycle of drug use, offending, poor physical health, mental health issues, unemployment and homelessness. Supporting individuals to maintain tenancies, improve their coping abilities, increase their practical skills and encourage them to re-engage with society. The project will fund the refurbishment of the existing premises and a new-build extension.  It will also fund the employment of a caretaker.

The project will benefit young people aged 14 to 24 who have run away from home or are at risk of doing so, as well as their siblings and families. The project will be delivered in partnership with Relationship Scotland. They will also offer practical support for young homeless people helping them with long term tenancy sustainment. The grant will fund staffing costs, IT costs, an external evaluation, rent, heating, subscription fees, books, software, maintenance costs, audit costs and office furniture.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This is a project by a charity in Leicester. The group will use funding to install a secure bike stand at the accomodation for homeless people. This will improve the facilities at this location that provides refuge for a number of homeless people.

The project will create a cyber cafe, run by homeless young people, in a refurbished Merthyr Tydfil shop. It will provide them with work experience, skills, confidence and motivation. The project will improve relationships between young people and the community and will contribute to the regeneration of Merthyr Tydfil. By the end of the year it is anticipated that 30-50 young people will have gained new skills with 15-20 others moving on from the cafe to find further training, education or employment.

This group will organise Garden Workout exercise classes and taster sessions in yoga, tai-chi and pilates. The sessions will be delivered by a sessional worker over a 10-week period, twice per week. The project will benefit people with multiple issues including mental ill health and a history of homelessness..

column2: Emmaus South Wales - building the first Emmaus Community in Wales
column3: The project will create a sustainable community home for 22 homeless people in the Bridgend area, providing them with accommodation, training and full-time work in the organisations social enterprise business. Up to 120 beneficiaries over the three years will gain work and life skills, reducing the likelihood of becoming homeless again or re-offending. The grant, over a year, will be used towards the renovation costs of the building, providing en-suite rooms, kitchen, dining and other communal facilities.

This is a project by a charity in Worksop, Nottinghamshire. The group will use the funding to provide individuals who are or have recently been homeless with access to training, development and support needed to improve their life skills. This will help address the personal, social and economical challenges faced by the beneficiaries, which tend to hinder their life chances and lead to low self-esteem and poor self-confidence

This Brighton project will promote their service and recruit host families to expand provision from single night emergency accommodation for homeless young people to longer term, settled accommodation. This will increase its capacity to support young people and help them reintegrate back into mainstream society.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column3: This is a project by a community organisation in Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire. The group will use the funding to purchase computer and food preparation equipment and to deliver training including enterprise, project management and sales for young people who are homeless and NEET. This will provide training and skills for beneficiaries which will motivate them and enhance their employability prospects.

column2: Horn of Africa Health & Wellbeing Project
column3: This new project will provide a programme of outreach and onsite healthcare services for homeless and vulnerable people living in and around Hammersmith and Fulham. The project will launch a calendar of health-themed awareness-raising events and engagement activities relevant to the target audience, including sessions on TB, Hepatitis C and diabetes, among others. Up to five volunteers will be recruited each project year to provide peer support and advocacy, and will be trained in areas such as first aid.
column26: City and County of the City of London
column73: City and County of the City of London

column3: This project will support families to sustain their tenancies and manage their finances to prevent homelessness. A community link officer will visit targeted community groups who have established relationships with targeted families. Families will be offered advice through one-to-one sessions, financial training courses or surgeries. 16 volunteers will be trained to provide financial advice to their local communities. The project will also make a DVD demonstrating why financial control is so vital.

This project will address the homelessness, addiction, offending and employability issues of adults in West Dunbartonshire with the expansion of its existing community services. The project will also set up a residential recovery unit. The project will provide intensive support including therapeutic methodologies aready successfully employed in the community. The grant will fund salaries, sessional staff costs, accomodation, management costs, travel expenses, client expenses and partner delivery.

This is a project by a community group in Hammersmith and Fulham serving beneficiaries in Camden. The group will use the funding to provide support to access health resources, activities and training for homeless people. This will enable the beneficiaries to receive training to deliver to their peers to help lead to healthier lifestyles.

column2: Community Leadership Training and Empowerment Programme
column3: This is a project in Essex which will use funding to develop the skills and knowledge of its trustees and volunteers, including business planning and company and charity law, in services aiding the homeless. This will enable the group to fill the gaps in the skills and knowledge required to provide an effective service.

This project will see St Paul's Hostel Worcester continue its programme of support for homeless people. Access to education, training and employment opportunities will be provided alongside numeracy and literacy, creative writing, drama workshops and sports. There are opportunities to learn skills such as bricklaying, carpentry, husbandry and horticulture, while within the hostel's kitchen there is the chance of learning to prepare, plan and purchase food.

This project, which uses theatre to reach out to homeless people living in hostels and day care centres, will be expanded across London by the charity Cardboard Citizens (CC). The aim of the project is to move people away from homelessness through participation in a drama-focused journey. Beneficiaries will be encouraged to become actors and tour the play across over 40 hostels. Alongside the peer-led activities, one-to-one sessions will offer advice regarding education, training and employment.

The project provides debt and welfare rights advice to single homeless and vulnerably house people across Ipswich, offering various services such as face to face appointments, home visits and drop-in facilities. The group deals with around 450 cases per year and has seen an increase in the number of debts and size of the debts that people are struggling with. Today's funding will enable more people to see an adviser and reduce waiting times.

This is a project by a charity based in Bradford. The group will use funding to set up and equip a new IT suite and training room for the benefit of homeless people. This will create an accessible IT facility for homeless people and provide training and courses to increase people's skills and employment prospects.

An intervention programme by Kids Company to be replicated across the UK for deprived young people who are disengaged from society as a result of issues such as homelessness, exclusion from education, gang membership, dependence on substances or emotional difficulties. They will address issues acting as barriers to engagement; offer support that will enhance resilience, well-being and self esteem whilst offering practical life skills to enhance employability. It is part of the C4 series, Secret Millions.

This is the continuation and development of an existing project to provide emergency accommodation for homeless young people in South Worcestershire and to tackle the causes of homelessness amongst this group. Emergency accommodation will be provided in a volunteer host's home for up to eight weeks together with the chance to talk through their problems in a supportive environment. A mediation service will also be run to try and reunite young people with their families.

This is a project by a community group in Bedminster, Bristol. The group will use funding to deliver a series of weekly cooking sessions to people from two local homeless hostels. They will also offer related learning sessions, such as nutrition and budgeting. This will increase the life skills and opportunities of those who participate.
This Surrey charity will install a wireless network and new computers at a residential home for young people at risk of homelessness. This will enable residents to improve their learning.

Dinas Fechan Residents' Association will provide social activities for people living in a hostel for homeless people which will include walking, climbing, archery, fishing and bowling and outings to places including St Fagan's and Cardiff Bay. The project meets the Awards for All aim of 'extending access and participation'. This grant for £1,900 will fund transport for activities including bowling, walking, climbing, archery, kayaking, fishing, football, laser games, outings, entrance fees and refreshments.

column2: St Anne's Cobbled Court Yard & Landscape Project
column3: This community organisation in Highgate, Birmingham, will use the funding to purchase gardening equipment and patio furniture sets, enabling the group to provide new constructive and social activities for their members, who consist of young homeless men.

Over three years, the project will work with homeless people at risk of marginalisation and exclusion from society, in Cardiff and the Vale of Glamorgan. By developing the knowledge and life skills required for progression into learning and employment, the project aims to improve confidence, skills, independence, self-esteem, and community engagement. A full time Client Learning and Development Worker, part time Employment Link Worker and part time Client Learning and Development Manager will be employed.

Broadway Homelessness and Support will establish a new Private Rented Sector Social Investment Fund to meet the accommodation needs of people who are homeless. Within six months the fund aims to raise £10m capital to purchase a portfolio of up to 260 properties to house 150 to 600 homeless people, capable of sustaining a tenancy. The project also aims to build investor confidence, engaging 20 new investors; and to extend delivery capacity, by sharing their research with 10 organisations in the sector.
column26: City and County of the City of London
column73: City and County of the City of London

column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Peterborough. They will be using the funding to refurbish two houses in order to provide accommodation for homeless people.
column17: Hope into Action: East of England

column3: This is a project by a group in Kensington, London. The group will use funding to introduce Open Cinema at one of their hostels serving long-term homeless people with alcohol dependency issues. This will offer a different kind of opportunity to engage the men living at the hostel. The partnership with Open Cinema offers a package of education and training to develop the participants interests and aspirations. The activity will add structure to the day to enable them to abstain from alcohol.
column17: Look Ahead Housing and Care Ltd

column3: This is a project by a community group in Tower Hamlets. The group will use funding to provide recreational activities for homeless people. This will enable beneficiaries to gain life skills that will increase confidence and self-esteem, promote social interaction and help prepare them for independent living.

This is a project by a not-for-profit company in North Lincolnshire. The organisation will use funding to deliver life skills and anger management coaching to young homeless people, and train the group's committee members to give them the skills to deliver projects and assist with the running of the organisation. This will give participants the skills and confidence to start living independently, and for the group to deliver a high standard of service to the community.

This is a project by a charity in Ripley, Derbyshire. The group will use the funding to run a photography class for people who are homeless. This will enable the beneficiaries to identify personal barriers and resolve their issues, increase their skills and confidence and encourage them to pursue education and employment opportunities.

This is a project by a voluntary and community organisation in Essex. The organisation will use the funding to run a project for eight people from a background of homelessness and local volunteer mentors to create a community garden. This will provide support for the reintegration of homeless people back into mainstream living.

This group will run a pilot project aimed at providing practical support to people who are homeless, on low incomes, asylum seekers, refugees or substance misusers. The project will include the provision of food, advice, support, social activities and volunteering opportunities. The grant will fund sessional staff costs, transport, kitchen equipment,  stationary/postage, volunteer expenses, venue hire, cleaning materials and food costs

column2: Council for the Homeless NI Awards For All project
column3: The group represents organisations working with homeless people throughout Northern Ireland and provides direct services to the homeless. The grant will fund training for staff and volunteers.

This group aims to provide supported work experience to individuals who are removed from the job market due to personal barriers which include being in prison, substance misuse issues, homelessness and offending behaviour. The project will provide supported work experience within a warehouse environment to 300 beneficiaries over five years. The grant will fund staff costs, training costs, volunteer expenses, project overheads, volunteers uniforms and recruitment costs.

This is a continuation and minor expansion of an existing project by Crisis UK (Crisis) that aims to transform the lives of single homeless and vulnerably-housed people in Newcastle upon Tyne and Gateshead by equipping them with the information, skills, qualifications and confidence needed to progress into housing, education and employment. Beneficiaries are chiefly engaged through outreach to hostels for the homeless.

The 'Way 2 Go' project will extend on existing services for individuals who have alcohol related problems & who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless.  The project will work across the Armagh/Belfast/Derry/Enniskillen & Omagh area.  A Rapid Response Service will be available, where members of the public can call a telephone number if they find a person who is intoxicated & homeless/sleeping rough.  Arrangements will then be made for the person to be taken somewhere safe for the night.

column2: Feel at home with your finances
column3: The initiative aims to ensure new and young existing tenants are equipped with the information, financial skills, confidence and access to suitable products and services to manage financially. The project will be delivered through four strands of work, which will include distributing information packs; developing a flexible training 'passport' to specifically cater to the training needs of each tenant; offering additional personalised support for tenants identified as high risk and peer mentoring.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Darlington. The organisation will use the funding to pay for a sessional worker to deliver cycling mechanic skills, and then to run a cycling repair enterprise for homeless and ex offenders in the wider community. This will provide participants with a skill and experience in customer service and retail management to enable a smooth transition into employment.

This new project will enable homeless young people to influence the services available to them and to help other young people at risk of homelessness within the local community. The project will enable homeless people to speak out about issues and services that affect them, as well as giving them the opportunity to learn new skills, take part in training, work placements and traineeships.

This expansion of an existing project will provide furniture and home start-up kits to people in the local area. The current project is an informal furniture recycling service providing re-housed homeless people with donated furniture. The expansion will be a social enterprise that will recycle and restore furniture and white goods, run by people who are homeless, vulnerable, have mental health issues or misuse drugs and alcohol. A structured programme of training and volunteering will also be offered.
column17: St Richard Of Chichester Christian CareAssociation Ltd

column3: This organisation will create a garden at the Garry Place Homeless Service in Falkirk. The grant will be used to pay for monoblock, monoblock installation, wall art material, wooden table, seating, 2 bird baths, feeders, garden games, 4 large pots, 40 small pots, 8 trellises, shrubs, vegetable seeds, plants, rocks and compost for a rockery.

This charity prints and distributes a free magazine for homeless people in London and Edinburgh, and provides an online facility with details of homeless services and information. Funding will enable the group to develop their website, providing homeless people with a more effective and up-to-date online service to assist in their reintegration into society.

A project by this company to install IT equipment into a newly refurbished IT training suite which is used to help homeless people sort their lives and find permanent employment and accomodation. Support is also available to lone parents and ex-service personel.

This project aims to engage with young people and their local communities to prevent long-term youth homelessness by providing emergency accommodation on a one night at a time basis in the homes of trained volunteers. After each stay the young person's long-term housing needs are addressed. The project will expand its provision to offer a 'nightstop plus' service, where young people can stay with a host for up to three weeks, giving them more time to think about their future and options available to them.

This project will provide substance misuse assessment, treatment and intervention to vulnerable young people aged 14 to 25. The majority of the young people will also be homeless, care leavers, have mental health issues or be offending. The young person will initially develop relationships with the project worker and complete an assessment which will be used to develop a Plan for Change. The grant will fund two support workers, travel expenses, group work programme costs and project overheads.

column2: A pathway from homelessness to independence
column3: This is a continuation of an existing project by Emmaus Sheffield (ES) which aims to break the cycle of homelessness in Sheffield, by enabling the homeless to embark upon a sustainable coherent pathway which will make a transformational change in their lives. It will help them to move from dependency to self reliance and return them to independent living and work, in order to protect them from returning to homelessness.

column2: Fulfilling Lives: Multiple and Complex Needs Support Contract
column3: The contract between July and December will be used to provide project support, service user involvement work and inform and disseminate a policy briefing for the areas.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Blackpool. The organisation will use funding to gain Registered Social Landlord status. This will enable the group to provide more dry housing for people who have experienced homelessness or addiction, along with affording the group to obtain further capital funding for their housing project, with the aim of expanding their services.

column2: The Hidden Homeless - Positive Change Project
column3: This is a continuation of an existing project, based in West Yorkshire, which helps homeless/hidden homeless people overcome their mental/emotional barriers and make positive choices/changes by breaking out of the cycle of homelessness.

The project will establish Take Notice Citizens who will provide a voice for homeless people and set a standard for the delivery and evaluation of other statutory and voluntary services. Service providers and communities will listen to citizens' stories who have been adversely affected, with the aim of readjusting their perceptions of homeless people and how they deliver services in the future. The three year funding will pay for salaries, staff expenses, equipment and running costs.

This is a continuation and expansion project by Nightsafe Limited (NL) based at their day centre in Blackburn with Darwen in East Lancashire. It will provide day time services and night time accommodation to support vulnerable young people aged 16 to 24 that are either homeless or at risk of losing their home.

column2: Supporting young women in gaining skills and confidence to pursue empl
column3: This charity in South Shields will use the funding to support unemployed young women and will make referrals for specialist support on issues such as offending, substance misuse, homelessness and domestic abuse. The project aims to enable participants to gain skills and confidence to pursue employment.

This is a project by a charity and not for profit company based in Norfolk. The group will use funding to provide workshops including an allotment project, cooking classes and multimedia sessions, targeting homeless people.
column17: The Purfleet Trust Resettlement Project (King's  Lynn) Limited
column73: King's Lynn and West Norfolk District
column75: St. Margarets with St. Nicholas Ward

column3: The project aims to improve life skills, employability and access to services for people who have experienced homelessness in Glasgow. The project will provide activities to improve basic skills, literacy, numeracy, learning, careers guidance and supported volunteering. There will also be outreach tenancy sustainment courses and clients will be referred to partner agencies. The grant will fund salaries, training courses, overheads, course materials, staff training, travel, subsistence and office equipment.

This project will support homeless people, who have experienced domestic abuse, through the transition of moving into their own tenancy. The funding will enable the organisation to continue to take referrals from temporary accommodation services and support people to address multiple issues such as mental health, substance misuse, and offending, either directly or by supporting them to access external services. They will be supported to gain and maintain appropriate housing.

Funded through Support and Connect Scottish this organisation will see the expansion of their Arch Moving on Scheme (AMOS) supporting homeless men to make the transition into independent living through free or low cost furniture provision, starter packs and furniture vouchers. The project will also accept referrals for local people living in poverty and facing material hardship who require support.

column2: Sheffield Art Forge - Shalesmoor Community Arts Project
column3: This is a project by a company limited by guarantee in Sheffield. The organisation will use the funding to deliver a range of arts based activities to young adults, in particularly those who are homeless or living in shelters, and are dealing with depression or experiencing low self esteem or alcohol dependency. This will improve their health and well being by using art as a therapeutic medium.

This is a project by a charity in Tower Hamlets. The group will use the funding to overhaul the current group website and customer database which is proving restrictive, to enable more efficient monitoring, communication and a stronger online presence. This will ensure clearer and more regular communication of the groups services and events for homeless people, enable tracking of progression of members and more interactive demonstration of their impact.

This project, based in Aylesbury, seeks to reduce and prevent homelessness by providing disadvantaged and vulnerable people with advice, information and support to enable them to find accommodation, sustain a tenancy and improve their chances in life. The expansion element will allow increase the opening hours for its drop-in centre, develop and extend existing activities such as the job search club and will introduce more training opportunities to improve people's basic and vocational skills.

This is a project by a charity in Nuneaton, Warwickshire. The group will use the funding to work with a group of young people and create a documentary about homelessness and how it can affect young people. This will enable the young people to learn new skills and will create a film that highlights homelessness to the local community.

Swansea Young Single Homeless Project will create a Young Persons Zone where young homeless people can relax, learn new skills and attend a job club. This meets the Awards for All aim of increasing skills and creativity. This grant for £5,000 will fund six laptop computers, a printer, two sofas, six chairs and a projector.

column2: Inside Out - Building Self Esteem in Homeless People in Brighton & Hove
column3: This is a project by a company limited by guarantee in Brighton. The group will use the funding to run photography workshops on communication and digital skills for homeless people, aiming to improve social integration and wellbeing.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove

column3: This is a project by a voluntary organisation in Huddersfield. The organisation will use the funding to deliver workshops for young people who are at risk of becoming homeless, offering information in areas such as how to run a successful home, improved communication skills and debt management. This will equip young people with the necessary skills to live independently and avoid becoming homeless.

column2: Back 2 Work Partnership  Funding for 2 Key Roles
column3: This project will help both homeless and unemployed people overcome acute personal difficulties and improve their skills. They will also be encouraged to develop personal aspirations through one-to-one support. The project also aims to foster positive relationships between its homeless residents and the local community whilst developing skills and confidence to sustain the participant's journey to independence and employment.
column17: London Inter-Diocesan Council Of The Apostleship Of The Sea

column3: This is a project by an Industrial Provident in Surrey. The organisation will use the funding market and launch their new social lettings model which will enable the organisation to work with landlords to identify and provide accommodation for homeless people. This will help people who are homeless secure long term good quality housing.

column2: Child and Parent Accident Prevent Safety Project
column3: This is a project by a charity in Hammersmith and Fulham. The group will use the funding to offer advice and information to parents/carers who are homeless or under housing stress on how to keep children safe and how to deal with accidents.
column17: Shepherds Bush Families Project & Childrens Centre

column2: Food for the Footsteps drop-in centre 2014-2015
column3: This is a project by a registered charity in Guildford. The organisation will use funding to provide nutritious meals to homeless people every Sunday evening. This will enable beneficiaries to eat at weekends when other service providers do not operate and provide them with the opportunity to discuss problems and issues with other homeless people and volunteers.

This is a project by a company limited by guarantee in Sheffield. The organisation will use the funding to purchase materials and pay a product designer to design display fixtures out of recycled materials to be assembled and created by residents from a local homeless shelter. This will equip homeless people with practical skills to improve their chances of finding employment.
Not Available
column17: South Ayrshire Escape from Homelessness Limited

column2: DENS Day Centre for Homeless and Vulnerably Housed People
column3: This is a continuation and expansion of a BIG funded project by DENS Limited (DENS) which will provide a safe and supportive environment, through its Bury Lodge Day Centre in Dacorum, Hemel Hempstead, to provide homeless and vulnerably housed people access to support and information, and to improve their chances in life by enablement and empowerment through proactive intervention.

column2: Reducing Risk of Homelessness in Eastern European Women
column3: Reducing Risk of Homelessness in Eastern European Women

This is a project by a company limited by guarantee in Hull. The organisation will use funding to deliver basic ICT and sewing workshops, for homeless visitors of their hostel, to include CV writing, job search, sewing machine maintenance and the creation of soft furnishings. This will provide beneficiaries with new employability skills, with the aim of assisting them into further training, volunteering or paid employment.
Not Available

column2: Empowerment and Enterprise through Pottery Participation
column3: This continuation and expansion of an existing project for Manchester Ceramics Enterprise (MCE) will provide support to homeless people in Greater Manchester, aiming to reduce social isolation and improve confidence, self esteem, health and well being.  Through regular, structured and meaningful activities, which offer positive alternatives to negative influences, homeless people, or those in temporary accommodation will be able to address their problems and participate more in mainstream society.

A new project in London, which aims to provide disability services to disabled people who are homeless. It will provide access to free transport, sheltered jobs via Work Choice, and help with accessing disability benefits (DLA), and finding accommodation. The scheme will also raise awareness of issues around the homeless disabled. Revenue:

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Cambridge. The organisation will use the funding to set up IT, literacy and arts and crafts workshop with an exhibition for homeless and vulnerable people. This will enable marginalised community members to increase their IT and literacy skills which will improve their chances of finding employment and improve confidence, self esteem and mental health.

column2: Support and Development Services for Complex Needs programme BIG001-0348
column3: This contract provides support to the 15 lead partner organisations that applied for funding under the Complex Needs Programme. This includes providing independent critical friend challenge to the lead partners as visions are developed, reviewing proposals for identifying need, service user engagement, system change principals and a cross sector approach. Support will be provided through Homeless Link and authorised sub-contractors: MEAM (Making Every Adult Matter), Clinks, Drugscope and Mind.

This is a project by a charity in Cambridge. The organisation will use the funding to continue to run weekly music-making workshops for homeless, ex-homeless and vulnerably housed people in the area. This will enable the group to continue to provide sessions and deliver performances for the wider community.

column2: New Leaf Community Chaplaincy Support Pack
column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Aylesbury. The organisation will use the funding to develop and distribute a support pack to homeless ex-offenders upon release from prison with information about local services and support available to them. This will provide vulnverable ex-offenders with information to help them access local aid in order to improve self-esteem and provide support to help them integrate with society.

Taff Housing Association (THA) will support 190 young parents aged 16-25 in Cardiff and the Vale of Glamorgan (who are homeless or at risk of homelessness) to develop good parenting skills. Support will be on a 1-to-1 and group basis at community-based 'hubs' and 'hands-on' practical skills in the home. The project will be prevention focussed and work to pre-empt escalation of issues, helping those struggling with a range of transitions brought about by parenthood, to enable families to thrive in future.

This continuation project will improve the health of homeless people by providing nurse-led health clinics, including podiatry, at two drop-in centres in Hastings. Most homeless and vulnerably housed people do not have access to GP services due to complex appointment systems.The project will raise awareness awareness among GPs and PCTs of the barriers faced by homeless people, while providing beneficiaries with signposting and referrals to agencies for issues such as housing, and drug and alcohol misuse.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove

column2: Red Dog Outreach: Confidence Building Workshops
column3: This is a project by a charity in Stroud, Gloucestershire. The group will use the funding to deliver new creative confidence building workshops for vulnerable and disengaged young people who have been homeless and supportive leisure activities for young carers. This will develop the beneficiaries' transferrable communication skills through teamwork, working to deadlines and positive social experiences.

This project aims to give homeless men and women skills to become tenancy ready to enable them to successfully find and secure accommodation and move on from homelessness. Through a training course and peer support sessions, beneficiaries will develop a portfolio of qualities designed to meet the requirements of landlords. These include; understanding the responsibilities of being a tenant, security, reporting repairs and the upkeep of premises; demonstrating positive behaviour and the ability to pay rent.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column3: This expansion of an existing project will work with homeless people in supported accommodation in Brighton, Lewes and Portslade, supporting them to learn practical and transferable skills and become more independent in social and economic terms in preparation for when they leave the accommodation. Many beneficiaries will experience the anxiety and depression associated with social exclusion and living in unsettled accommodation, and the project will aim to bridge the gap into independent living.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove

column3: This project based in Liverpool meets the particular needs of women and children who have lived with domestic abuse and provides a purpose built refuge for 19 women and their children. Families who arrive at the centre are in effect homeless, lacking confidence and self-worth.

column2: Horizons Volunteer Training and Support Project
column3: A project by this Bristol group to reduce numbers of people returning to homelessness, by providing training, accreditation and support for volunteer mentors through Horizons, the Homeless Mentoring Project. Training for volunteers will include mental health and drugs and alcohol awareness.

This project in Merton will run informal workshops on disability to address the social exclusion of disabled homeless people. These workshops will be run by volunteers and will advocate Freedom Passes and focus on employment issues to encourage decision makers and employers to consider people with these issues as disabled instead of homeless.

This project in Bournemouth offers opportunities to people who are long-term unemployed and have experienced either; alcohol/substance misuse, mental health issues, homelessness and/or is an ex-offender. This will be through the provision of activities which will ensure they are better prepared and more able to access employment and volunteering opportunities.

The project will support the prevention of homelessness by addressing anti-social behaviour and social exclusion in Caerphilly and Rhondda Cynon Taff local authority areas. This will be achieved by providing support and guidance to identified households displaying anti-social behaviour and those households already excluded. Activities planned include training seminars, service user group meetings, newsletters, diversionary activities and floating support to households at risk of homelessness or exclusion.

A grant of £295,945 is going to Mary Seacole Housing Association to provide mentoring, practical support and training for homeless young people aged 16 to 30 years old. The project will help these young people to access accommodation and to develop life and employability skills to prepare them for independent living.

Action Homeless (Leicester) will provide training and work experience to homeless people living in hostel accommodation through Down Not Out. It will focus on producing a monthly community newsletter written and edited by the homeless volunteers with guidance and training from staff. The newsletter will focus on issues related to homelessness to raise awareness within the local area.

This project will build upon creative writing, poetry and art workshops delivered to vulnerable adults in east and west Sussex who have become socially excluded through issues such as homelessness, drug addiction, long term unemployment and depression. Beneficiaries will have exhibiting and publishing opportunities, as well as involvement in several high profile events including The Impact Art Fair - the UKs only art fair solely representing the work of marginalised and disabled artists.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Kent. The group will use funding to run a personal finance programme for homeless people in the local area. Existing staff will attend training to enable them to facilitate the workshops. This will equip beneficiaries with the skills they need to manage their own finances, avoid debt and achieve sustainable independence.

This continuing and expanding project will provide counselling and advice services to young people and support and signposting for families. The focus of the project will be providing long term effective interventions for individuals struggling to cope with everyday issues. Beneficiaries will receive advice, information and counselling addressing issues such as unemployment, homelessness, mental health problems, abuse, trauma, eating disorders, self-harm, poverty, low skills, and no qualifications.

This charity in Rochdale will use funding to provide legal advice sessions to young people, particularly those who are at risk of homelessness, and specialist training sessions to youth leaders and mentors. This will improve the young person's life chances by making them aware of their rights and responsibilities, and increase the knowledge and ability of people supporting them.

This project will promote the health, well-being, and employability of homeless and vulnerably housed adults in the Bradford area, supporting and encouraging them to seek education, training, volunteering and employment opportunities. The project is based at Horton Housing Training Centre (HHT), which is a purpose built community learning venue. The centre provides 32 hours a week of courses including literacy, numeracy, ESOL, IT, tenancy management, money management, self-development and food hygiene.

This is a project by a charity in Wigston, Leicestershire. The group will use the funding to deliver film making, photography and facilitation workshops for homeless people to communicate their stories. This will enable beneficiaries to develop their self confidence and aspirations and tackle misconceptions.

The organisation provides support and advances the education and personal development of people with learning disabilities, as well as offering 24 hour domiciliary care and housing support for homeless people.  The project will create opportunities for young homeless people and people with mild learning difficulties to get involved in gardening, foraging, food preparation and cooking.

This is a project by a charity in Derby, Derbyshire. The group will use the funding to purchase and install a kitchen to deliver vocational training sessions in cookery and healthy eating to young vulnerable people who have experienced homelessness, substance misuse and abuse. This will provide the beneficiaries with skills to improve independence, confidence and focus on development for future opportunities of employment.

column2: Specialist Advice Training for Day Centre Staff for Homeless People
column3: This charity in Chesterfield, Derbyshire, will use the funding to train staff in practical skills to support homeless people which will enable them to help more people.
column17: Pathways: Chesterfield Day Centre For The Homeless

column3: This County Durham organisation will run a workshop of new media and film skills to disadvantaged young people including those who are homeless, living in care and ex offenders to help them record their own work-based learning development on film which will be used to encourage young people in similar circumstances. The will increase their self-confidence social and digital media skills and improve their chances of finding employment, and raise other people's aspirations to find employment.

This unique project will continue to support and develop the capacity of the resettlement services provided by Prisoners Abroad (PA). Its aim is to enable Britons returning to the UK after imprisonment overseas to resettle into a crime-free life and avoid becoming homeless.

column2: Improving Employability Chances for Young People aged 16 plus in Glenrothes
column3: This group will run a Job Club within their homeless hostels for young people aged 16-25 years old. The Job Club will be attended by the 35 residents with the aim of helping them to create a personalised 'Individual Learning Plan'.

This is a project by a company limited by guarantee in Sheffield. The organisation will use funding to run a series of creative workshops, including artistic event production and digital arts, culminating in an exhibition of work, for young people living in homeless hostels. This will provide beneficiaries with therapeutic activities, with the aim of reducing social isolation and promoting wellbeing.

This is a project by a company limited by guarantee in Sheffield. The organisation will use the funding to deliver an intergenerational awareness project to older and younger people using digital media focusing on homelessness and loneliness. This will reduce isolation, build confidence and lead to a better understanding of generational issues.

This is a project by a registered charity in Cambridgeshire. The organisation will use funding to stage a series of community performances, featuring local teenagers, highlighting teenage homelessness. This will enable participants and the wider community to understand the issues faced by homeless teenagers, with the aim of altering the perceptions people have about the homeless.

This is a project led by Shelter, the National Campaign for Homeless People Limited a registered charity and a company limited by guarantee based in London serving the development of the Multiple and Complex Needs partnership in the Manchester target area.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This is a project by a charity in Lambeth. The group will use the funding to basic and life skills training sessions to people who are at risk of or have experienced homelessness. This will enable beneficiaries to develop skills in IT, cooking, communication, interpersonal techniques and increase confidence to improve quality of life and employment prospects.

The aim of this expansion project is to break down the cycle of poverty and combat the effects of the multiple deprivations within the community of Bassetlaw in Nottinghamshire. It provides targeted support that relieves homelessness, poverty and distress, whilst promoting and protecting health and wellbeing, confidence and skills of young people aged 16-25 and their families.

This is a project by a voluntary organisation in Liverpool.  The group will use the funding to provide a meal for homeless people once a week and set tackle homelessness. This will enable homeless people to come together have a meal and obtain assistance in obtaining accommodation.
Not Available
Not Available
Not Available

The continuation of a project run by Theatre Royal Plymouth since September 2010 to raise the aspirations and confidence of adults who have multiple and complex needs including homelessness, reoffending, substance misuse and mental illness. The project uses the arts as a means of engaging beneficiaries who have proven consistently difficult to reach, enabling them to develop as active citizens by improving their life skills, access to employment and social inclusion within the wider Plymouth community.

This is a project by a community organisation in Northampton. The group will use the funding to refurbish a rundown cafe and purchase a van to facilitate a catering project which will help homeless and disadvantaged people re-engage with society. This will develop skills for beneficiaries, and will improve a local building, turning it into a social enterprise training hub and facility for the community.

column2: ASDAN life skills/personal development for tenants
column3: This is a project by an exempt charity. The organisation will use the funding to develop an accredited course for vulnerable young people, victims of domestic violence and single homeless people. This will provide vulnerable homeless people with the life and employment skills to live independently and improve their chances in life.

This is a project by a community organisation in Stroud, Gloucestershire. The group will use the funding to create a communal garden area. This will enable the group to provide improved support to their beneficiaries as part of their food based training programme delivered to homeless people.
The group will run a one year pilot project providing tailor-made starter packs and additional support to people who have secured a new tenancy after a period of homelessness.

This project aims to help break the cycle of homelessness and remove barriers to employment for homeless young adults in Great Yarmouth, by providing them with the necessary life skills to live independently. It will bring services together into one accessible place. Young people will be able to access support in the areas of mental health, financial counselling and family mediation as well as education and work experience. Crisis and transitional accommodation will be provided when homelessness does occur.

This is a project by a charity in Birmingham. The group will use the funding for a residential self-esteem and personal development course for homeless young women. This will enable beneficiaries to improve their confidence, personal achievements and life skills to increase their future employment and training prospects.

This project by Housing For Women (HFW) will continue to meet the housing and support needs of mothers who would be homeless upon release from prison, so that they can be reunited with their children and reduce re-offending. Tailored support to both women and their children is designed to improve their life skills so they can successfully resettle in to the community.

The organisation provides support to those who are homeless across Northern Ireland.  The grant will be used to deliver  a range of social activities to vulnerable homeless clients who are living in temporary accomodation across.

column2: Horn African Youth Health Promotion Project
column3: This is a project by a community organisation in Hackney to provide drama, music and dance activities for young people who are isolated, homeless or with a history of mental ill health. This will improve their confidence and reduce isolation. venue hire, musical instrument hire, volunteer expenses, publicity, travel, composers' fee
column17: Adal Development and Leadership Foundation - ADALEAF

column2: Open Door - Housing Advice and Support Service (HASS)
column3: Thurrock Open Door provides specialist housing advice, welfare benefit and grant advice and advocacy for vulnerable adults and young people who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless. It aims to support clients who find general provision too complicated to navigate or for those who fall outside of the criteria for obtaining help. It provides immediate and flexible support, focusing on a preventative approach to stop issues escalating to the point of crises.

Shelter will expand its successful 3-year pilot programme which provides housing-related support to vulnerable families at risk of eviction or with a history of repeat homelessness to help them learn skills and behaviours needed to manage a tenancy successfully. It will aim to support children deemed to be homeless through the families own actions. This project will expand the service to cater for families in order to address the root causes of why certain families face eviction issues.is strategy.
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This is a project by an incorporated charity in Bradford. The organisation will use the funding to pay a sessional gardener who will deliver vegetable, herb and plant growing activities for members who are all homeless or ex-homeless. This will provide positive activities, teach members basic living skills and divert them from using drugs and alcohol.
column17: St Anthonys Project for Homeless Addicts

column3: This is a project by a registered charity in Kent. The organisation will use funding to develop further their services for homeless people, through training volunteers to deliver courses, including maths and English, along with expanding their current service of finding accommodation and employment for beneficiaries. This will enable volunteers to deliver a sustainable training programme for homeless people and extend their hours of service.

This is a project by a charity in Bridlington, East Yorkshire. The organisation will use the funding to improve their facilities and services including providing cooking classes, new tents, cooking and IT equipment. This will enable the organisation to advertise their services to more homeless people, providing them with meals on more days throughout the week, cooking skills and support.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Bolton, Manchester. The organisation will use funding to create a garden with a working allotment, flower garden and seating area within a hostel for homeless young people. This will give these young people new skills and develop strong working relationships through the design and working on the allotment site.

This continuation project aims to help transform the life chances of disadvantaged adults through supporting them into learning and skills training. It will work with adults who have issues like homelessness, substance misuse, longterm mental ill- health and offending.

The group will use the funding to deliver support and life skills training workshops for people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. This will enable the beneficiaries to access training and development opportunities to improve their life skills to support them in independent living.
Not Available

column2: Building Skills and Confidence Within Reading's Homeless Community
column3: Not Available
Not Available
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This project aims to break the cycle of homelessness by countering the negative stereotype and producing a monthly magazine, which will be sold to the public. This will enable homeless people to contribute to the cultural life of the wider community. Central to the philosophy is that the content of the magazine is planned, designed, written and created by homeless people. The magazine will be sold and distributed by people with experience of homelessness.

This is a new project that will prevent young people aged 16 to 21 years from being and remaining homeless. Project Front Door will provide housing units which are accompanied by an intensive support package that includes on and off site activities to help young people to learn how to manage their accommodation and live a much more positive lifestyle.

An intervention programme by Kids Company to be replicated across the UK for deprived young people who are disengaged from society as a result of issues such as homelessness, exclusion from education, gang membership, dependence on substances or emotional difficulties. They will address issues acting as barriers to engagement; offer support that will enhance resilience, well-being and self esteem whilst offering practical life skills to enhance employability. It is part of the C4 series, Secret Millions.

column2: Sheffield Vulnerable Peoples' Financial Confidence Programme
column3: The project will address the financial confidence and capability of first time social housing tenants including those living with mental health issues. It will exploit early-intervention referrals from homeless and choice-based lettings housing applicants in priority, discharge pathways from mental health services and from asylum housing providers in order to provide more intensive one to one support for these beneficiary groups.
column17: Sheffield Citizens Advice Bureaux Debt Support Unit

column3: This development of an existing service for Valley House in North West Coventry will extend the current support provision to deliver pre and post counselling support, drop-in sessions, on-line and telephone counselling and guidance, advice and information. This will coordinate in depth emotional and psychological support for those with deep-seated complex needs including multiples of isolation, mental ill health, drug/substance misuse, domestic violence, family breakdown or homelessness.

This is a project by a community organisation in Hounslow. The group will use the funding to support female ex-offenders to improve parenting skills. This will enable the lone parents to receive training and self sufficient skills to refrain thier children being placed in to care, fosterhomes or become homeless.

column2: Risking it All - An Arts Project for Homeless Young People
column3: This Chester organisation will use the funding to work with vulnerable and homeless young people to explore the issues of risk-taking behaviour and use their experiences to develop and deliver a theatre performance and DVD. This will provide beneficiaries with access to advice and support to help them overcome the consequences of risk-taking behaviour, voice their opinions and raise awareness of these issues within the local community to prevent other young people from making the same mistakes.

Gisda Cyfyngedig will open a new information centre in Caernarfon from which they will deliver support services to vulnerable young people aged 16-25. This project meets the Awards for All aims of supporting community activity and improving the quality of life. The grant for £5,000 will fund telephone costs and signage and will part fund rent, 2 ipads and a printer, furniture, heating costs and training.

column2: 'Moving on Up' - Taking our Business to the Next Level
column3: Us Un Ltd  in Flint will expand their social enterprise and provide training for additional homeless young people by establishing an OCN course in design and jewellery. The project meets the Awards for All Wales Programme aim of 'increasing skills and creativity'. This grant for £5,000 will fund facilitating delivery of OCN course, materials and printing costs.

This continuing and expanding Winchester-based project aims to provide practical and emotional support to people in Hampshire who are homeless or vulnerably housed.
