The drop-in day centre provides basic services including hot meals, clothing and washing facilities, as well as opportunities to make positive long-term changes through counselling, learning, and access to advice and support. The grant will allow extended opening hours to Saturdays and bank holidays and extended morning outreach services.

This is a project by a charity in Bromyard, Herefordshire. The group will use the funding to provide art workshops for young homeless people culminating in a public exhibition of the work.  This will enable beneficiaries to participate in activities that will help increase their confidence and self-esteem to help with future employment and education prospects and independent living.

column2: Support for training, events and volunteer activities at Arlington
column3: This is a project by a charity in Camden. The group will use the funding to deliver training courses and recreational activities for homeless people. This will provide beneficiaries with the necessary skills and support their transition away from homelessness.
column75: Camden Town with Primrose Hill Ward

column2: Acorn Fund Legacy Project - Supporting Communities through LocalPhila
column3: The Community Foundation for Northern Irelands Acorn Fund will use the funding to help build a legacy for the first UK City of Culture by providing grants for community arts and culture projects across County Derry/Londonderry. It will also help support projects for young people as well as people from marginalised groups such as the homeless and ethnic minorities. A three-year programme to support young people with learning disabilities who wish to pursue a career in the arts will also be developed.

column2: Street Medicine Service for homeless people & street workers in Bradfo
column3: The organisation will use the funding to assist with the purchase of a van which will act as a mobile clinic for homeless people and street workers in Bradford. This will enable the organisation to offer care, mental health support, drug, alcohol and other health advice to vulnerable and hard to reach members of the community.

The project is challenging stereotypes about people at risk of homelessness and experiencing homeless in Derry/Londonderry, Belfast and Dungannon. People who use Depauls services are contributing to a sound archive of personal stories to illustrate the complex diversity of what it means to experience homelessness in Northern Ireland today. A sound archive art installation will be produced and made available through online channels and outdoor audiovisual installations in public spaces.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Hampshire. The organisation will use the funding to deliver a variety of life skills workshops and physical activity sessions to homeless young people aged 16-25. This will encourage and support young people to develop their general living skills, promote independence, improve their health and teach them how to stay safe so they can move forward with their lives.

This is a project by a charity in Southwark. The group will use the funding to provide warm food, clothing, practical advice and information to homeless people. This will give the beneficiaries access to training opportunities and other agencies to enable them to change their lifestyle.

This is a project by a charity in Bournemouth, Dorset. The group will use the funding to deliver accredited programmes for local disadvantaged homeless young people who are not in employment, education or training and live in supported housing. This will allow the beneficiaries develop transferable skills to improve their employability, education and training opportunities and reduce the risk of them continuing to fall into workless and homelessness cycles.

The project will work with local artists to raise awareness of homelessness by creating a dramatic visual representation of its realities in Derry/Londonderry. CHNI and the artists will work with homeless groups and other voluntary and statutory organisations to produce one life-size cardboard figure for every person who has become homeless in the city over the last year. CHNI will hold an event in the Guildhall to display the art and where local organisations can showcase their services.

column2: ACTIVITY CENTRE - COOKERY AND ART TUTORS
column3: This is a project by a charity in Worcester, Worcestershire. The group will use the funding to deliver cookery and art courses for vulnerable adults who are homeless. This will help to build their self esteem, enabling them to realise their skills and talents with a view to moving on to higher aspirations.
Not Available
Not Available

This is a project by a charity and not for profit company in Bedford. The organisation will use the funding to deliver family counselling to young prisoners and their families prior to release from prison. This will enable them to rebuild family relationships, improve communication and coping skills, and reduce the chance of homelessness and re-offending.

This is a project by a community organisation in Bedworth, Warwickshire. The group will use the funding to provide support and life skills for homeless people. The project aims to integrate beneficiaries back into society, developing their practical skills and improving their self-confidence and aspirations.

The aim of this existing project is to continue to provide support to homeless asylum seekers and refugees, helping  them to access vital services, develops their social contact, self-esteem and practical skills to build their confidence so they can move on as independent members of the community.

The Cyrenians has received the funding to expand its project which helps people, mainly aged between 16 and 35, who are affected by homelessness, alcohol and substance abuse, and mental and physical health issues. The project offers support on a one to one basis, and improves lives with psychotherapeutic interventions, peer support, recovery support, volunteering and mentoring.

column2: Young and Homeless: Social Inclusion Initiatives in Fife
column3: The school will organise film making workshops for pupils aged 12-13 years to enable them to make two films of their own about young homeless people in Fife. This grant will fund the cost of six media education workshops, two half day shoots, two public presentations and transport costs.

The group will deliver a peer mentor training programme for young people predominantly in Glasgow, Edinburgh and Falkirk. The project will engage young people who have experiences of homelessness, drug/alcohol addiction and low level criminality. The grant will fund course materials, web design, publicity, activity sessions, sessional artist/facilitator fees, travel costs and venue hire.

column2: Margins Project - Helping the Homeless in Islington
column3: This is a project by a charity in Islington. The group will use funding to refurbish its new social enterprise cafe kitchen training facility at its drop in and advice service preparing meals for people who are homeless or marginalised. This will provide new cafe facilities at to improve its efficiency, cater for more people and provide better access to training for users and trainees.

This expansion of an existing project will provide support to homeless people with alcohol and substance addictions. The project aims to support service users to address barriers to work, securing long-term accommodation and employment in order to break the cycle of poor independence and subsequent return to using and to regain control of their lives.

column2: A Community Hub for Hastings Ward
column3: This is a project by a charity in Loughborough, Leicestershire. The group will use the funding to provide practical, technical and team building skills and refurbishment work at one of its site buildings for vulnerable homeless men faced with substance misuse. This will enable beneficiaries to develop skills and further their employment opportunities, reduce anti-social behaviour and provide a new amenity facility for homeless people.

The project will provide an enhanced level of support to vulnerable and disadvantaged young people experiencing homelessness. The project will provide a range development activities, access to accredited training, work placements and psychodynamic therapies. The young people will be resident in one of Cyrenian's two supported accommodation communities. This grant will fund salaries, group work costs, beneficiary costs, beneficiary training, staff expenses, staff training and recruitment costs.

This is a project by a charity based in Southwark, serving beneficiaries across London. This homeless charity will use the funding for the training of their volunteers in mental health awareness, safeguarding, listening skills and dealing with confrontation.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Bradford. The organisation will use the funding to setup a pilot project to provide an emergency shelter for homeless people with complex needs in the area, offering leisure activities, befriending services, advice and volunteering opportunities. This will expand the organisations capacity to be able to support a wider range of homeless people.

column2: Harbour Place Health, Wellbeing and Worklessness Project
column3: This is a continuation and expansion of an existing project by the Harbour Place Day Centre (HPDC) in North East Lincolnshire (NEL) to help the most vulnerable, chaotic and excluded individuals to improve their quality of life in respect to problems relating to homelessness. Homelessness is a perpetual cycle that is a result of many other social and economic factors, such as relationship breakdown, social isolation, poor skills, substance misuse and offending.

The grant will pay for Communities United Project to provide training and volunteer opportunities to young people and adults aged 16+ at risk of becoming homeless or unemployed or with poor educational qualifications. A programme of community sports and play leadership workshops will enable local residents to gain skills and knowledge and work towards accreditations, to help them provide community activities. The aim is to improve confidence, motivation and life skills of people living in high crime areas.

The project will deliver a support programme for people who are homeless and have multiple complex needs. This will be achieved by providing training and practical experience in organic horticulture and farming and reviving an organic farm in Kirk Langley, which will lead to basic qualifications and job search skills. Mentoring support from community volunteers will improve their life and communication skills.

column2: Skateboarding, urban dance and beat-boxing workshops
column3: This is a project by a charity in Hammersmith, serving beneficiaries in Birmingham. The group will use the funding to deliver skateboarding, urban dance and beat boxing skills workshops for young homeless people. By engaging them in positive activities, this will build the confidence of the beneficiaries, raise their aspirations and provide them with skills and experience which will help them to break the cycle of homelessness.

column2: Young Person Homeless Prevention through Volunteering
column3: Not Available

column2: Digital Inclusion Project for homeless and other disadvantaged people
column3: Not Available

column2: Renewal of kitchen in church hall
column3: This is a project by a charity in Devizes, Wiltshire. The group will use the funding to install more robust units and appliances for their community kitchen, regularly used to prepare meals for homeless and vulnerable people and community groups. This will improve the safety and efficiency of the facility so it can be continue to be used to meet the needs of a large number of beneficiaries. kitchen units, appliances, sinks, taps
column17: Parochial Church Council of Devizes St John and St Mary

column3: This is a project by a community organisation in Enfield. The group will use the funding to provide a comprehensive and valuable foot care service for elderly, disabled and homeless people. This will help the beneficiaries maintain their health, mobility and independence.

column2: Targeted Development for Men and Women
column3: This is a project by a voluntary organisation in Manchester. The organisation will use funding to provide staff with training in marketing, volunteer management and fundraising, and deliver pottery workshops and activities to homeless people. This will enable the group to deliver more efficient services and provide vulnerable people with opportunities to develop creative skills, meet other people and reduce boredom and reduce isolation.

column2: Group Capacity Development and Office Refurbishment
column3: This is a project by a community group in Newham. The group will use the funding to provide members with management training courses and to refurbish their office to equip them to provide services for disadvantaged and homeless people. This will provide new facilities to develop the capacity of the organisation.

This is a project by a registered charity in Reading. The group will use the funding to hold a drama project that will inspire and motivate people who are affected by homelessness. This will develop confidence and skills and also help to raise awareness of people who are homeless.

This is a project by an incorporated charity in Lancashire. The group will use funding to carry out an outreach project through their website for the benefit of homeless people in the Pendle area. This will enable the target group to access information and sign posting services, including housing and addressing personal issues.

This is a project by an incorporated charity based in Surrey.  The organisation will use the funding to deliver basic construction trade skills and confidence building training to previously homeless young people now living in a residential centre.  This will improve their life chances by increasing their confidence and self-esteem and ability to reengage in employment and/or education.
The Rock Trust work with 16 to 25 year olds who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless. The group will purchase four computers for their internet cafe.

This organisation which works with homeless young people will use the funding to provide a high quality multi-media project, offering participants the opportunity to work with multi-media professionals in weekly workshops to produce films exploring what it means to be homeless in Blackpool.

This community interest company in Liverpool will use the funding to deliver a variety of courses including numeracy, literacy and basic IT skills to vulnerable adults who are homeless. This will provide beneficiaries with new skills and support them to improve their life.What Money is for :Sesssional tutor, sessional cook, sessional advice worker, food for health eating sessions, laptop, cutlery and stationery.

The organisation will use the funding to make a series of films to educate the local community about homelessness and the economically vulnerable in Eastbourne by interviewing potential beneficiaries about the issues that they face on a daily basis, which will be streamed, uploaded and shown in public places to the wider community.

column2: Equiping,Training and Supporting Local Communities in Housing Homeless
column3: This is a project by a charity based in Sefton, Merseyside serving beneficiaries nationwide. The group will use the funding to purchase IT equipment to enable the group to provide training and support to partner organisations. This will build the groups capacity to provide partner organisations with the skills to administer and sustain their own local housing projects.
Not Available
Not Available
column17: Healthy Living, Healthy Lives Community Interest Company

column2: Ashfield Eyecare Services Part of Nottinghamshire Homeless Eyecare
column3: Not Available
Not Available
column17: Shelter, The National Campaign for Homeless People Limited

column3: This is a project by a charity in Bradford. The organisation will use funding to deliver 2 x 10-week programmes developing design and DIY skills, and peer mentoring support network, among young people at risk of homelessness living in supported accommodation. This will enable young people to maintain their tenancies and increase their self-esteem and life chances.

This expanding project by Launchpad Reading aims to improves the physical and mental health and wellbeing of the homeless community in Reading, stabilising their chaotic lifestyle through engagement with routine, regular gardening activities to provide emotional therapy, promote confidence and teach healthier lifestyles. The project acts as a stepping stone to further personal development by the beneficiaries in making more informed life choices.

The group is a recently established church which provides a number of social and recreational activities for the people of Belfast. The project will establish an open cinema club for people excluded from society, mainly those who are homeless.

column2: Nightstop Communities Northwest C I C ( NCNW)
column3: This continuation and expansion of an existing project will aim to provide long-term emergency accommodation for homeless young people in Halton and provide training and life skills to help integrate them back into the community.

This existing project aims to reduce the number of young people, aged 14-25, who are homeless and sleeping rough in the North East of England. The project currently runs in Northumberland, Newcastle Upon Tyne, North and South Tyneside. This grant will allow its expansion into the remaining North East areas.

column2: St Petrock's Advice, Housing and Support Service.
column3: This continuation project will offer homeless or vulnerable people with improved access to housing, supporting them to successfully maintain a tenancy and as a result improve their health and life expectancy. The project will also enable beneficiaries to access training, volunteering and employment opportunities. Success will be achieved by a number of key strategies and activities, such as a daily drop-in advice service with more flexible opening hours and excellent links with support agencies.

Arts Alive in Crickhowell will bring together older people living in sheltered housing and young people at a homeless shelter to create art works exploring themes of housing and homelessness. The project meets the Awards for All aim of 'extending access and participation'. This grant for £5,000 will fund workshop leaders costs, materials including exhibition boards, photography, management, volunteer expenses and project evaluation.

This is a continuation and expansion of a project to by North Worcestershire Basement Projects to provide a drop-in service available for homeless and potentially homeless young people aged 16-25 in Bromsgrove and North Worcestershire. The drop-in service supports vulnerable young people so they can secure/maintain accommodation, develop the independent living skills needed to resettle permanently, address their complex needs and access education/employment.

This expanding project in Hastings, East Sussex, aims to give homeless people skills to become tenancy-ready. The project will be developed in line with tenancy trends, creating a 'Sharers' Network' to counter the Local Housing Allowance (LHA) which takes room occupancy into account. An interview will establish people's needs, after which a training course will be delivered. The project will provide ongoing support, including assistance mediating with landlords and helping with deposits/crisis loans.
column26: The City of Brighton and Hove
column73: The City of Brighton and Hove
column75: St. Peter's and North Laine Ward

column3: This is a project by a registered charity in Norwich. The organisation will use the funding to convert part of its new premises into a workshop offering vehicle maintenance training to young people who are disadvantaged, have difficulty accessing mainstream education or are vulnerable due to homelessness or other factors. This will enable the group to offer a wider range of practical training to vulnerable young people.

column2: Camden and Islington - Multiple and Complex Needs
column3: This is a project by Single Homeless Project (SHP), a charity and registered company based in London, serving the development of the Multiple and Complex Needs partnership in the Camden & Islington target area.

This is a project by a school in Lewisham. The group will use the funding to provide extracurricular workshops, support and guidance for families experiencing severe family disruption, possible homelessness and domestic violence.

First Housing Aid & Support Services provides homelessness related services in NI. The grant will be used to work with young parents aged 16-25 & children aged 2-12 in a play & arts exhibition where they will share with each other & local communities their experience of homelessness.  Parents will work alongside actors from the film company Kabosh to develop and stage a play for local people. The project will engage with children who are homeless in an arts project which will be on display at the Playhouse.

column3: Not Available
